While foot traffic was down 40 per cent as the virus hit, three quarters of stores by rent are now trading. While March trading was weak, it was better than rival mall owners.

More than 75 per cent of Stockland's earnings come from its residential, retail and retirement units and Jefferies said it expects earnings and cashflow to be weak.

While Stockland's balance sheet would face pressure an equity raise was unlikely, the analyst said.

Read more: Stockland says housing inquiry has recovered

8.12am: Xero swings to profit

Xero has swung to a maiden $NZ3.3 million full-year profit, but warned coronavirus will weigh on its fiscal 2021 performance.

The Auckland-based cloud accounting software provider said Thursday that revenue for the 12 months through March rose by 30 per cent to $NZ718.2 million, from $NZ552.8 million a year earlier. Xero made a $NZ27.1 million net loss in 2019.

Xero said it added 467,000 subscribers over the year for a total 2.285 million but warned COVID-19 reduced annualised monthly recurring revenue growth in March. It said the pandemic's impact will be reflected in its fiscal 2021 results and declined to give any outlook, although it does not anticipate significant changes to its long-term strategy.

Shares in ASX-listed Xero last traded at $83.77, up 4.7pc in 2020.

Dow Jones Newswires

Read more: Xero warns of coronavirus hit to come

7.50am: Oil falls

Oil prices fell about 2 per cent overnight despite the first decline in US crude inventories since January, as the US Federal Reserve chairman stoked demand fears with a warning the economy would take many months to recover from the coronavirus pandemic.

Oil had rallied on optimism that slumping fuel demand would recover, while producers have slashed production to cut the mounting supply glut during the pandemic.

But crude slid along with other risk assets like stocks on Wednesday due to the government signals that a rebound may take awhile.

Global benchmark Brent crude settled down 79 cents, or 2.6 per cent at $US29.19 a barrel. West Texas Intermediate crude futures, the US benchmark, settled down 49 cents, or 1.9 per cent at $US25.29 a barrel.

Reuters

7.40am: ASX to slip after Fed's warning

Shares on the Australian market are expected to be down in early trade after the US Federal Reserve chairman warned of extended economic weakness from the coronavirus pandemic.

At 7.10am (AEST) the SPI 200 futures contract was down 58 points, or 1.07 per cent, to 5,366, indicating a loss in early trade.

Chairman Jerome Powell pledged to use the US central bank's power as needed, but called for Congress to agree on additional fiscal support.

Shawn Cruz, manager of trader strategy at TD Ameritrade in Jersey City, New Jersey, said: "He's saying if you want to avoid a slow recovery and long-term economic damage you need a strong fiscal response, effectively placing that responsibility back over to governments instead of central banks".

The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 516.81 points, or 2.17 per cent, to 23,247.97, the S&P 500 lost 50.12 points, or 1.75 per cent, to 2,820 and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 139.38 points, or 1.55 per cent, to 8,863.17.

In Australia on Wednesday, the benchmark S&P/ASX200 index closed up 18.9 points, or 0.35 cent, at 5,421.9 points.

The All Ordinaries closed up 16.4 points, or 0.3 per cent, at 5,513.7 points.

One Australian dollar was buying US64.56 cents at 7.10am (AEST), down from US64.79 cents at the close of trade on Wednesday.

AAP

7.20am: Qld Virgin bid 'laughable'

A political row has broken out over Queensland's plan to bid for troubled airline Virgin Australia, with Peter Dutton branding it "laughable".

The Home Affairs Minister tweeted: "Premier Palaszczuk has almost bankrupted Queensland and now in the middle of a crisis they want to buy an airline. It is laughable. She 'leads' a government which is corrupt and chaotic."

The Queensland government is considering a move to try to rescue its struggling tourism industry and keep the carrier, with its thousands of jobs, flying and headquartered in Brisbane.

New state Treasurer Cameron Dick has told the government's investment arm, Queensland Investment Corporation, to look at buying into Virgin, which went into voluntary administration last month with $7bn in debts.

Mr Dick said the investment "could take the form of a direct equity stake, a loan, guarantee or other financial incentives".

Read more

7.09am: BuzzFeed to quit Australia

Online content juggernaut BuzzFeed has announced it will cease news production in Australia and the UK "both for economic and strategic reasons," diverting resources towards the US market.

Founded in 2006 by Jonah Peretti, the company became famous as an online content aggregator before growing in popularity for its highly-shareable "listacle" articles and viral content.

In the last decade it has become a global media company with news operations that have at times rivalled traditional media companies.

In a statement, a representative for the company said: "both for economic and strategic reasons, we are going to focus on news that hits big in the United States during this difficult period."

"Therefore, we will notify staff in the UK and Australia that we are not planning to cover local news in those countries.

"We will be consulting with employees on our plans regarding furloughs and stand-downs in these regions."

The company will retain some employees who cover news with a global audience: social and celebrity news, as well as investigative pieces.

BuzzFeed launched its UK operations in 2013 and arrived in Australia the following year during a time of global expansion for the company.

6.10am: Wall St tumbles after Fed warning

US stocks fell after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said further stimulus could be needed to support the economy's recovery from the coronavirus-induced contraction.

The S&P 500 dropped 1.8 per cent, extending Tuesday's loss of more than 2 per cent. The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 2.2 per cent, or 500 points, and the Nasdaq Composite slipped 1.6 per cent.

After yesterday's gains, the ASX is set to open firmly lower. At 6am (AEST) the SPI futures index was down 64 points, or 1.2 per cent.

The US declines were broad, with all 11 sectors of the S&P 500 in the red.

Investors have been eagerly seeking any clues about the potential length and severity of the economic downturn. In a speech, Mr Powell revealed growing alarm about the path ahead, describing the outlook as "highly uncertain and subject to significant downside risks."

"Additional fiscal support could be costly but worth it if it helps avoid long-term economic damage and leaves us with a stronger recovery," he said.

Meanwhile, economists surveyed by The Wall Street Journal predicted the US contraction caused by efforts to contain the coronavirus will be larger than previously anticipated. The economists expect gross domestic product to shrink 6.6 per cent this year, measured from the fourth quarter of 2019.

Evidence is growing of the damage already sustained by businesses. A gauge of U.S. business prices posted its largest decrease on record in April as the pandemic curtailed economic activity.

Major U.S. stock indexes have been held up in part by strong investor demand for shares of big tech companies. The S&P 500 has cut its declines for the year to 13 per cent, buoyed by a 28 per cent jump in Amazon and a 13 per cent increase in Microsoft. Some investors say the outperformance of megacap stocks is masking weakness in the broader stock market.

As the economic outlook darkened, the economically sensitive energy, financial and industrial sectors were among the weakest performers in the S&P 500 on Wednesday. Energy stocks fell 4.5 per cent, while the financial and industrial groups fell at least 2.8 per cent.

Tensions between the U.S. and China added to the nerves among some investors, who worry new frictions between the two largest economies could exacerbate the global downturn.

In Europe, the benchmark Stoxx Europe 600 fell 1.9 per cent. Benchmarks in Asia ended the day mixed. India's S&P BSE Sensex index jumped 2.2 per cent after Prime Minister Narendra Modi outlined an economic relief package.

Dow Jones Newswires

6.00am: Hopeful signs in job ad figures

Seek says new job ads posted in April were down 65.6 per cent, year-on-year, and 49.9 per cent lower month-on-month.

The figures were released ahead of Thursday's official jobs data, which are expected to show a sharp rise in the number of jobless.

However Seek says job ads in the first two weeks of May show a marginal improvement, suggesting the jobs market may have turned a corner

New South Wales and Victoria continued to be hardest hit in April, with job advertising down 52.4 per cent and 56.3 per cent respectively compared to March 2020.

5.47am:Tesla dispute may be over

It appears the dispute between Tesla and San Francisco Bay Area authorities over the reopening of a factory in the face of shutdown orders is coming to an end.

The Alameda County Public Health Department announced on Twitter late Tuesday that the Fremont, California, plant will be able to go beyond basic operations this week and start making vehicles Monday - as long as it delivers on worker safety precautions that it agreed to.

It wasn't clear from a news release whether Tesla would face any punishment for reopening last Monday in defiance of county orders.

The release said Fremont police would verify whether Tesla was holding up its part of the agreement. The deal requires that public health indicators have to remain stable or improve for the factory to stay open.

AP

5.44am: Stocks slump on second wave fears

Fears of a second coronavirus wave and downbeat comments by the head of the US Federal Reserve helped push stocks lower.

Wall Street's main indices slid after Fed chief Jerome Powell said the US economic recovery may be slower than desired in the aftermath of the pandemic, but should rebound "substantially" once the outbreak is reined in.

As the shutdowns drag on, they could cause "lasting damage" to the US economy and more policies may be needed to deal with that possibility, including spending beyond the nearly $3 trillion already approved by Congress, he warned.

Chris Beauchamp, chief market analyst at online trading firm IG, said that "while Jerome Powell hinted at more measures to support the US economy, his warning about the speed of the recovery has sapped bullish sentiment."

Edward Moya at online currency trading firm Oanda said Powell's "downbeat remarks ... burst the risk appetite balloon for many investors."

European stocks were also being mauled over concerns of a second wave of virus infections.

The recent optimism that has flowed through markets - helped by trillions of dollars in worldwide stimulus and central bank backstopping - has been given a jolt by data showing fresh outbreaks in South Korea, China and Germany.

"Traders remain worried about the possibility of COVID-19 cases rising again as governments ease their restrictions in relation to the lockdowns," said market analyst David Madden at CMC Markets UK.

In the eurozone, Paris slumped by 2.9 per cent and Frankfurt by 2.6 per cent. Meanwhile, London's benchmark FTSE 100 index shed 1.5 per cent as official data showed the British economy contracted by 2.0 per cent in the first quarter on the back of the COVID-19 outbreak.

That was the worst quarterly slump since the depths of the global financial crisis in 2008, although the figure was better than analysts' expectations of a 2.5-per cent contraction.

Oil prices popped higher after data showed a surprise drop in US crude reserves, a signal that producers are reducing the oversupply in the market. However, they fell back after investors realised the data also showed very weak processing by refineries, an indication that demand by consumers has yet to pick up.

AFP

5.40am:Chanel lifting prices

French luxury house Chanel says it is increasing prices on its handbags and some small leather goods worldwide to take into account a rise in the cost of raw materials amid the coronavirus pandemic.

In an emailed statement responding to a Reuters query, Chanel said the price increases in euros ranged between 5.0 per cent and 17 per cent. "The price adjustments only regard Chanel's iconic handbags, 11.12 and 2.55, as well as Boy, Gabrielle, Chanel 19 bags and certain small leather goods," it said.

"These adjustments are made while ensuring that we avoid excessive price differentials between countries, in line with our commitments regarding price harmonisation." Online speculation of Chanel price hikes prompted face-masked shoppers to line up as early as 5am outside a Chanel store in the South Korean capital Seoul.

Reuters

5.39am:Norway fund puts BHP on notice

Norway's $US1 trillion ($A1.5 trillion) wealth fund is excluding some of the world's biggest commodities firms from its portfolio, including Glencore and Anglo American, because of their use and production of coal.

Underlining the growing role of climate considerations for long-term investors, the fund is also excluding German utility RWE, South African petrochemicals firm Sasol and Dutch company AGL Energy over their use of coal.

Norway's parliament agreed in June 2019 to toughen existing limits on coal investments by the world's largest fund by excluding firms that mined more than 20 million tonnes of coal a year or generated more than 10 gigawatts of power from coal.

At the end of 2019, the fund held stocks worth $US1.6 billion in such companies, according to fund data.

Wednesday's announcement, made in a statement issued by the fund, is the first to show the tougher rules being applied.

The fund, set up in 1996 to save Norway's oil and gas revenues for future generations and which now holds about 1.5 per cent of globally listed shares, sells holdings before announcing any exclusions to avoid excessive market moves. The fund put another set of companies - BHP, Uniper, Enel and Vistra Energy - under observation for possible exclusion later if they did not address their use or production of coal.

Read more

Reuters

5.32am: Fed warns sustained recession possible

US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell is warning of the threat of a prolonged recession resulting from the viral outbreak and is urging Congress and the White House to act further to prevent long-lasting economic damage.

The Fed and Congress have taken far-reaching steps to try to counter what is likely to be a severe downturn resulting from the widespread shutdown of the US economy.

But Powell warns that there still could be widespread bankruptcies among small business and extended unemployment for many people.

"Deeper and longer recessions can leave behind lasting damage to the productive capacity of the economy," the chairman says in prepared remarks before an online discussion with the Peterson Institute for International Economics. "Avoidable household and business insolvencies can weigh on growth for years to come."

The US government "ought to do what we can to avoid these outcomes, and that may require additional policy measures," Powell says.

He says the Fed will "continue to use our tools to their fullest" until the viral outbreak subsides but gives no hint of what the Fed's next steps might be.

Powell repeated his previous warnings that the Fed can lend money to solvent companies to help carry them through the crisis. But a longer downturn could threaten to bankrupt previously healthy companies without more help from the government.

Greater support from government spending or tax policies "could be costly, but worth it if it helps avoid long-term economic damage and leaves us with a stronger recovery," he says.

AP

5.28am: UK slumps at fastest pace since 2008

Britain's economy shrank in the first quarter at the fastest pace since the global financial crisis as the country went into coronavirus lockdown, data showed, prompting the government to warn of a "significant" recession.

Gross domestic product - the combined value of produced goods and services in the UK economy - contracted by two per cent in the January-March period after zero growth in the three months to December, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) said.

The nation's second-quarter contraction is meanwhile expected to be far steeper than the first.

In more grim news, UK output dived by a record 5.8 per cent in March from the previous month. Britain implemented its COVID-19 lockdown - which is only just starting to be eased - on March 23.

"A recession is defined technically as two quarters of decline in GDP. We've seen one here with only a few days of impact from the virus," finance minister Rishi Sunak said in response to the gloomy data.

"So it is now very likely that the UK economy will face a significant recession this year and we are in the middle of that as we speak."

AFP

5.25am:OPEC sees oil market rebalancing

The rebalancing of the oil market is underway and will accelerate, the OPEC cartel said, days after some of its members voluntarily increased their production cuts.

The world oil market was thrown into disarray earlier this year as lockdown measures imposed by governments to slow the spread of the coronavirus led to plunge in demand just as crude producers had been stepping up output in a war for market share.

Prices tumbled, with the price of the benchmark US oil futures contract briefly plunging below zero.

But OPEC and its allies have agreed on major cuts in production, by 9.7 million barrels per day, and the cartel believes an improvement is on the horizon.

"The speedy supply adjustments in addressing the current acute imbalance in the global oil market has already started showing positive response, with rebalancing expected to pick up faster in the coming quarters," OPEC said in its monthly report.

The collapse in oil prices - the main international benchmark has fallen by half since the start of the year - is leading some producers to shut down wells and the cartel now expects non-OPEC production to decline by 3.5 million barrels per day this year.

It believes the worst drop in demand will be recorded in the current April-June quarter.

The easing of restrictions and the massive stimulus programs adopted by governments could now help the market bounce back.

OPEC said it now expects daily demand in 2020 to drop by some 8.5 million barrels per day from last year's level, which is a roughly 8.5 per cent drop.

AFP

5.20am:France puts cork in champagne sales

The French champagne industry's trade body suspended early sales of the iconic sparkling wine in an effort to support prices and deal with a huge stock overhang made worse by the coronavirus pandemic.

Champagne is traditionally a drink for celebrations and gatherings but the coronavirus lockdown orders in much of the world have put a major dent in sales, with lost revenues so far estimated at 1.7 billion euros ($US1.8 billion).

With producers having sold around 100 million fewer bottles so far this year, or about a third of the annual total last year, many are in sore need of cash.

The Comite Champagne that regulates the industry banned until June 8 the pre-sale of bottles that are still in the fermentation process to prevent retail prices from falling steeply.

AFP

urn:contentItem:5VMS-8081-DYN6-W55J-00000-00Do voters long for a policy wonk? Elizabeth Warren hopes so2019-03-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:03ZLexisNexisPOLITICAL NEWSDo voters long for a policy wonk? Elizabeth Warren hopes soBy ELANA SCHORAssociated PressNEW YORK

NEW YORK (AP) - More than 1,000 people packed a New York concert venue for an act that wasn't on guitar and drums. It was Elizabeth Warren, vocalizing hard numbers.

The Massachusetts Democratic senator wove data points into a stump speech that riffed on the policy proposals she's rolled out in her month-old presidential candidacy. "I love that you want to get into more detail about the 2 percent wealth tax," she said to a man asking whether her economic plan would drive the wealthy to move overseas.

Warren's policy-heavy performance last Friday was a hit with her crowd. And that's something she's counting on heavily in her campaign. She has laid down significant markers in a half-dozen different policy areas since the year began, putting pressure on other 2020 presidential contenders while keeping her campaign in the public eye without having to spend a dollar on ads.

But Warren's approach is built on a risky bet: that voters will respond to her detail-driven effort when other Democrats are appealing to hearts as much as their minds and after a 2016 presidential campaign in which Hillary Clinton's policy portfolio wilted in the face of Donald Trump's personal attacks.

While she's successfully forced some of her rivals to respond to her agenda, particularly her two-part plan last week to curb the growing consolidation of the biggest tech companies, other 2020 hopefuls who have rolled out fewer new policy proposals - California Sen. Kamala Harris and Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders - are outpacing Warren in early polls and bested her in their initial fundraising hauls after making their first moves for the presidency.

The contrast between Warren's ambitious agenda-setting and the less wonky paths of other candidates underscores what Democratic strategist Antjuan Seawright described as the party's "diversity of strategy." In a crowded field, Democrats don't just have a historically diverse field for 2020 - they are field-testing different theories of connection with voters.

"The first thing every candidate should do is allow themselves to be introduced to voters and allow voters to find who they are," Seawright said. "Sometimes people are not moved by policy. Sometimes people are moved by your personal story."

Warren doesn't ignore personal narrative in her pitch, bolstering her universal child care plan by recalling her struggle to secure dependable care for her two children. And neither Harris nor Sen. Cory Booker, another Democratic presidential contender whose rhetoric is imbued with emotion and optimism, scrimps on substance when touting their signature policy proposals.

But it's clear that Warren is angling to be known as the idea woman in the field.

She's put out plans for a new tax designed to raise more than $2.5 trillion from the nation's wealthiest 75,000 households, on top of her child care proposal, her bid to rein in big tech companies like Facebook and her commitment to swear off high-dollar fundraisers. Warren leapt into another issue this week, calling for U.S. aviation regulators to follow European counterparts in grounding the Boeing airplane model involved in Sunday's deadly Ethiopian Airlines crash.

Warren is building a "policy-first agenda that's about more than just policy" and making a "cohesive argument about what is broken in America and how she would fix it," said Jesse Lehrich, a longtime Democratic aide who worked on Clinton's 2016 campaign and is not aligned with any 2020 campaign.

Referring to other 2020 candidates who have offered fewer specifics, Lehrich noted that "it's less obvious what their answer to that question is: Why me and not someone else?"

Clinton's campaign is something of a cautionary tale for Warren. In 2016, Clinton put out piles of white papers, but her general election opponent hardly engaged in the policy debate.

"In 2016, we were boxing against Jell-O," recalled Jesse Ferguson, a veteran Democratic strategist who also worked on the Clinton campaign. "Donald Trump would say he agreed with anything or disagreed with anything, without regard to what he believed or what he'd said the day prior."

Ferguson believes things may be different this time around now that Trump has a record in office.

But in 2020, Ferguson said, Democrats can contrast their plans with "what he has actually tried to do as president. He can't run away from his own policy agenda anymore because he's actually tried to enact it."

And while Clinton struggled to get some voters to warm to her personally in 2016, polls show none of the Democrats running in 2020 carrying the same high negative ratings.

Longtime Democratic strategist Jess O'Connell, also a veteran of Clinton's 2016 campaign, lauded Warren for front-loading some of her attention-getting policy ideas before the 2020 primary hits its peak, when Trump is likely to engage more intensely with Democratic candidates and try to knock his potential opponents off course.

"Ultimately, everyone is going to have to do both" policy fluency and personal narrative, O'Connell said, but Warren is "taking advantage of the news cycle" to release some of her big ideas early.

While she's scored early by shaping the Democratic debate on several issues, not all of Warren's forays have taken off. She vowed not to pardon anyone connected to investigations into Trump on the same day the president's former lawyer testified in Congress last month, but the move drew little response from Democratic rivals. She acknowledged even as she swore off high-dollar fundraising that she "will be outraised by other candidates," and the $11 million she already had in the bank before entering the race may not be enough to vault her past Sanders in the battle for progressives' support.

Warren's evident command of the issues resonated in deep-blue New York City. Nearly a dozen voters said after the Massachusetts senator's event that her intellectual chops were a central part of her appeal to them.

"Soaring rhetoric is not what we need now. We need active policy prescriptions," said Davin Hatsengate, 44, a New York City resident who attended Warren's Friday event and lauded her recent pledge to treat all her donors equally, regardless of the effect on her campaign's bottom line.

Emily Price, a 30-something mother of three who also came out to see Warren on Friday, praised Warren for saying more than "what maybe sounds right and feels good in our hearts."

"It's one thing to say nice things and make me feel excited, but to have a plan makes me feel ... a lot more secure," Price said.

Still, even one of Warren's strong supporters acknowledged the challenge in her policy-centric approach.

"Hard facts are something that most of America doesn't deal with," said Madeline Moch, who attended the New York event. "They like things sort of abbreviated and put into a nutshell. And that's how (Trump) got elected."

___

Associated Press writer Meg Kinnard contributed from South Carolina. Associated Press writer Juana Summers contributed from Washington.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average added 90.09 points today, closing at 10,607.23. The Nasdaq composite was up 14.14 on the session, finishing at 1,868.30.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

LOU DOBBS, HOST: Tonight, Andersen fighting for its corporate life. It looses more clients, including the federal government.

We'll have the latest on the company and its employees under siege.

Thinking smaller could lead to bigger profits for department stores. We'll take a look tonight at the future of a troubled industry.

The economy continues its steady recovery. A panel of market and economic experts tonight assess the impact that will have on you, Wall Street and interest rates.

And 20 years later, ET makes a big-screen comeback. The editor of "Variety" on whether the audiences will return as well.

ANNOUNCER: This is Lou Dobbs' MONEYLINE for Friday, March 15. Here now, Lou Dobbs.

DOBBS: Good evening, everyone. We begin tonight with a corporate giant that is under attack.

At this hour, the future of Andersen remains decidedly unclear.

MONEYLINE has learned that talks between Andersen and KPMG for the sale of assets or a merger are moving ahead.

In fact, our sources tell us that those talks between KPMG and Andersen are far more substantive and promising than the talks that occurred earlier this week -- those talks with Ernst & Young and Deloitte.

We have several reports tonight on Andersen. And we begin with Tim O'Brien in Washington.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

TIM O'BRIEN, CNN FINANCIAL NEWS CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Sara Lee, famous for its pastries, is now one of the latest corporate giants to abandon Andersen. So, too, Abbott Laboratories, the healthcare giant.

Without clients, the demise of one of the premier Big Five accounting firms is only a matter of time.

And for the clients Andersen leaves behind, securities experts see a crisis in the making.

JACK COFFEE, COLUMBIA UNIV. LAW SCHOOL: The problem for 2,000- odd American corporations is, they all now know that the other members of the Big Four do not have the capacity overnight to pick up all the Arthur Andersen clients.

O'BRIEN: Andersen says it has no plans to file for bankruptcy, but leaders of the accounting profession say, they're getting ready.

BARY MELANCON, AMERICAN INST. OF CPAS: I have been in contact with the leaders of the 20 largest firms, and they're all committed to do what's necessary to make sure that the profession meets its obligations with a minimal amount of disruption.

O'BRIEN: The Securities and Exchange Commission has moved to relax the rules, allowing Andersen clients who want out to file unaudited financial statements, as long as the audited reports are submitted within 60 days.

HARVEY PITT, SEC CHAIRMAN: The commission is going to take every step that is necessary to make sure that investors in our capital markets have the critical information they require.

O'BRIEN: It isn't only the corporate clients who are bailing. The General Services Administration, landlord and superstore for the federal government, has also suspended Andersen from any new contracts with the United States.

Existing agreements, worth some $60 to $90 million, will still be honored.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

O'BRIEN: Lawyers for Andersen told MONEYLINE tonight they will try to get this case to trial swiftly under the federal Speedy Trial Act. That means within 70 days.

The lawyers may be asking themselves if their client will still be around in 70 days -- Lou.

DOBBS: Tim, this indictment against Andersen has the effect of being really a judgment against Andersen.

The federal government, the Department of Justice in this case because of the impact it has on Andersen, really serving as not only prosecutor, but judge and jury as well. Is that not correct?

O'BRIEN: It is correct. The fact, it may never go to trial. There may not be a company around.

The government wants to use this high profile case to make a point, that obstruction of justice will not be tolerated.

Criminologists will tell you, if you want punishment to be a deterrent, make it swift and make it certain, make it severe.

The question that is left, however, is, is it fair?

DOBBS: Any indication that the Justice Department in its enthusiasm for prosecution is going to bring an indictment anyway soon against the source of all of these problems? That is Enron, its management, its executives?

O'BRIEN: They're not saying anything about that. They are saying it's a live case. And there still may be other indictments, including those who either shredded documents or directed others to do so.

Enron -- they're not saying anything right now.

DOBBS: OK. Tim, thank you very much. Tim O'Brien.

Andersen indictment, of course, is grabbing headlines. But when it comes to corporations and crime, there are plenty of precedents of companies who have tangled with the law.

Allan Dodds Frank has the report.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ALLAN DODDS FRANK, CNN FINANCIAL NEWS CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Some corporate crimes are easy to see. An Exxon tanker spills oil off the Alaska coast, and the oil company ultimately pays a $125 million fine.

In the 1980s, crimes by junk bond king Michael Milken bring down Drexel Burnham Lambert.

Charles Keating of Lincoln Savings becomes the poster boy for dozens of S&L crooks who cost taxpayers hundreds of billions of dollars.

In the 1990s, multinational pharmaceutical companies, including Hoffman-Laroche and BASF, conspire to fix prices for vitamins. Hoffman-Laroche alone is fined $500 million.

By contrast, if Andersen is found guilty of obstruction of justice, it faces a possible fine of only a half-million dollars.

RICHARD SYLLA, NYU ECONOMICS HISTORIAN: The amount of the fine isn't really what's important. It's, you know, how -- how much reputation do you lose? Do people trust you any more?

FRANK: But for some giant companies like General Electric, regulators from one agency or another are always looking for possible violations.

GE, for instance, was found guilty of criminal price fixing in the 1960s. More recently, it has faced civil sanctions for polluting the Hudson River.

RUSSELL MOKHIBER, CORPORATE CRIME REPORTER: These fines have very little deterrent effect. The deterrent effect is the publicity, the publicity by major media outlets that report on these crimes and that shame these companies and these executives into doing the right thing.

So it's not -- it's not the prosecution per se. It's the publicity.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

FRANK: The corporate crime reporters list of the top 100 fines paid by companies over the last decade shows that environmental violations are the most common crimes.

Anti-trust and price fixing conspiracies are next, followed by plots to defraud various government agencies -- Lou.

DOBBS: Allan, thank you very much.

The Justice Department targeted the entire firm of Andersen. Essentially, the Justice Department indicted 85,000 people for the actions of what appear to be fewer than two dozen.

But there is a realization that their future is increasingly uncertain.

Ceci Rodgers has the story from Chicago.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

CECI RODGERS, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): What was once the prestige firm in accounting is on the verge of collapse.

It's a long way down for the 89-year-old Andersen, named after its founder Arthur Andersen, and built on a reputation for high standards.

ALLAN KOLTIN, PRACTICE DEV. INST.: Some say they were like the Marines. Some say they were the elite. Some even said that they were a bit brash. Andersen's the best of the best -- just ask them. And they'll tell you. But they were.

RODGERS: Massive layoffs could begin as early as next week, if the steady exodus of clients continues.

In Chicago, 5,300 jobs are at stake.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I am just getting prepared, just in case, if we do go down.

RODGERS: Andersen has asked its 85,000 employees worldwide to continue working as normal. But that may be nearly impossible amid the uncertainty.

Inquiries are pouring into Accountix, a company that provides staffing for large accounting firms.

Some are from senior Andersen people, others from the top 25 accounting firms eager to snap them up.

RICHARD CORRADO, ACCOUNTIX: A week ago, I would say it's a trickle. As of yesterday afternoon, I would say the floodgates opened up, in terms of looking like a mass exodus from the company.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

RODGERS: As senior partners are already leaving, some said to be walking away from six- and seven-figure investments in the Andersen partnership.

That may be too -- not so big a price to pay, though, if the alternative is staying at Andersen and giving up the opportunity to start over at one of the remaining Big Five accounting firms -- Lou.

DOBBS: Ceci, what is the feeling amongst those Andersen employees with whom you spoke? How do they feel today after the firm has been indicted?

RODGERS: They really feel that an injustice has been done.

Almost to a person, the employees that we've spoken to -- and many of them refuse to go on camera. The company keeps putting out memos not to talk to the press.

But they were very forthcoming about -- they're blaming the government. They're not blaming the senior Andersen partners, not even the ones who did the shredding in Houston.

They really feel that the government is to blame for indicting the entire company, rather than the few.

DOBBS: Ceci, thank you very much. Ceci Rodgers from Chicago.

Well, turning now to Oracle, its shares fell 6 percent today. That after Oracle reported a 13 percent decline in earnings, a decline in revenue as well for the fourth straight quarter.

Oracle also is now warning that its earnings will continue to fall short of expectations.

It now appears that Oracle may have learned a lesson, that it is better to predict less, and when doing so, to aim somewhat lower.

Bruce Francis reports.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BRUCE FRANCIS, CNN FINANCIAL NEWS CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): In ancient Greece, the curious went to an oracle for answers.

In Silicon Valley, what investors have been getting from Oracle the software giant is apologies.

Oracle has struggled to predict the pace of the downturn and the recovery. And now, CEO Larry Ellison says, he's learned his lesson.

LARRY ELLISON, CHAIRMAN & CEO, ORACLE CORP.: We're out of the prediction business. We're not going to predict when it's going to get better.

We're going to assume it doesn't get any better, and we'll tell you it's going to get better after it's already happened.

FRANCIS: In the past 12 months, Oracle has warned no fewer than six times, an average of once every 60 days. That compares to just three times for Microsoft, and once for IBM -- Oracle's two biggest rivals in the database software market.

CHUCK PHILLIPS, MORGAN STANLEY: And one of Oracle's issues has been, they perennially set targets too high, and they don't meet them.

So even if they come in in line with what other software companies are doing, the expectations were so high, the stock underperformed.

FRANCIS: Even though investors always want to know more about the companies they invest in, analysts say that, when it comes to Oracle, fewer predictions from the company, and perhaps fewer misses, too, is a good idea.

IAN MORTON, JP MORGAN CHASE: I think it's a safer strategy for Oracle to be adopting a much more conservative stance these days.

One of the probably issues with the Oracle stock has been, it had been a cloud hanging over the company, and the fact that they had been given -- they had given what was probably far overly aggressive expectations. And I think they set the bar at a much more reasonable level right now.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

FRANCIS: Reasonable or not, Oracle estimates and their results are not likely to improve until capital spending on technology picks up in the U.S. And history suggests that that improvement happens after the economic recovery is well under way -- Lou.

DOBBS: Oracle has really given over these past months some really confusing signals here.

And Ellison saying last night that he's learned a lesson, it seems like that lesson would have been somewhat clear last fall at the very latest.

FRANCIS: It's certainly been better at making software than they have about predicting how corporate -- corporations would buy it.

In fact, it's interesting. Microsoft has always been accused of lowering estimates so much …

(CROSSTALK)

FRANCIS: … or talking us down so much, only so that they could overcome those.

Maybe Larry Ellison could learn a lesson from his chief rival, Bill Gates.

DOBBS: I'm sure one other thing he would like to have is the cash flow of Microsoft, as well.

FRANCIS: I think that's true.

DOBBS: Makes all of that education so palatable. Bruce, thanks.

Still ahead here, Mideast peace envoy Anthony Zinni meeting Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat.

The President's envoy says there is hope. That story is coming right up.

Thinking the unthinkable -- corporate America taking a very hard look at what would happen in another national emergency.

And spring may be less than a week away, but you wouldn't know it in certain parts of the Midwest. We'll have that story for you, and its potential impact on the economy in just a few moments.

Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: A quick follow-up to an angry president. A management shakeup today at the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Four of its top executives have been replaced, reassigned.

The shakeup follows an incident this week when a Florida flight school received letters approving student visas for two of the September 11th hijackers.

That incident embarrassed the agency, raised a firestorm of criticism, and angered President Bush.

The letters were received six months to the day after those two hijackers flew jetliners into the World Trade Center towers.

Signs tonight that Israel and the Palestinians may be taking a step back from the brink of war. Israeli tanks rumbled out of three West Bank towns.

U.S. envoy Anthony Zinni emerged from talks with Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat. But the President's envoy said he believes now that Arabs and Israelis are committed to ending the bloodshed.

But violence, nonetheless, continued. Nine Palestinians were killed, including a woman and her four children.

So far this month, more than 180 Palestinians have been killed in the violence. That's three times the number of Israeli deaths.

Vice President Dick Cheney dropped in on U.S. troops aboard the USS John C. Stennis in the Arabian Sea today. The Vice President is the highest-ranking U.S. official to visit the Afghanistan war theater since the U.S.-led campaign against terror began.

The Vice President told the sailors aboard the Stennis, his stop aboard that aircraft carrier is the highlight of his worldwide and whirlwind Middle East tour.

The Vice President also watched several fighter jets roar off the deck of the Stennis, and Vice President Cheney also toured the vessel's control center, and he had lunch with the troops.

The President received his own show of military might today at Fort Bragg, North Carolina -- home of the U.S. special forces.

The president watched Army Rangers storm a simulated embassy under assault. The President said it drove home the capabilities of the military and the war against terror demands an increase in defense spending.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GEORGE W. BUSH, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: This is the largest defense increase in a generation -- because we're at war.

And Congress needs to pass this budget. And by the way, it includes another pay raise for people that wear the uniform …

(CHEERS)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: And another airport evacuation today -- this time Denver's International Airport. That after a metal detector lost power.

That caused airport officials to halt all flights out of one of the airport's three terminals.

Airport officials say it is unclear what caused the power outage. Flights returned to normal just about two hours later.

And at Orlando International Airport, all eyes are upon some security systems of the future. The prototype security systems are equipped with x-ray vision that can see beneath a passenger's clothing.

Another machine blows quick bursts of air at a person, then sniffs for traces of explosives. It can be used, as well, to detect drugs.

Some civil liberties groups are saying these standards are too intrusive. The test machines are being supervised by National Safe Skies. It's a non-profit organization.

President Bush has his plans for a shadow government in the event of a terrorist attack. Now the CEOs of some of the country's largest companies have a contingency plan of their own.

Steve Young has the report.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

STEVE YOUNG, CNN FINANCIAL NEWS CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Called CEO Link, the new emergency network would enable key chief executives to work with one another and the government, despite the likely harm to communications that would follow a terrorist attack.

Participating CEOs include the chief executives of Bethlehem Steel, General Motors, Federal Express, and the rest of the business roundtable's 150-member chief executives.

AT&T is taking the lead in designing a system that will include a phone network and a secure Web site.

MICHAEL ARMSTRONG, CHAIRMAN & CEO, AT&T: The network that we will establish, first of all, must alert each of us wherever we are in the world. And it'll be set up to accomplish that, whether we do that over wires, or we do that over wireless, or over any other means -- could be satellite.

We will accomplish an alert that they must then come into the system, or respond to the system immediately.

YOUNG: To be sure that only the 150 chief executives can get on to CEO Link, the system will authenticate the number of the calling device, then a pin code, and the caller's voice.

It would enable counterparts and competitors to see the post- terrorist situation and help stabilize it.

Last September, Lockheed, for example, provided a C-130 aircraft so Environmental Protection Agency staffers could fly to New York when the Air Force couldn't quickly supply a plane.

AT&T's CEO thinks the federal government could offer corporate tax credits for anti-terrorism research and development.

PETE SEPP, NATIONAL TAXPAYERS UNION: Tax credits are never the ideal way of making policy. But they're infinitely preferable to direct government subsidies or contracts, which could stifle the very innovation we need for the war on terror.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

YOUNG: The Taxpayers Union says, even though this is the 150 biggest U.S. corporations working together, that shouldn't set off anti-trust alarm bells at the Department of Justice.

And, if there's any doubt, Congress could monitor CEO Link or grant it an anti-trust exemption -- Lou.

DOBBS: Steve, thank you -- Steve Young.

Well, still ahead, the race for this year's Oscars is almost over. But there's talk of a last-minute smear campaign against the movie, "A Beautiful Mind" -- one of the favorites, apparently, of the Academy.

We'll have a lot for you on that story.

The Federal Reserve meets next week to talk about interest rates. We'll ask our roundtable whether the Fed is preparing the ground for a rate increase.

And tonight in our segment, "In Their Own Words," a tribute to America's oldest military academy from today's Secretary of Defense.

Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: There's a lot going on in Hollywood these days.

"ET," the movie, coming back to the big screen. Russell Crowe could snare another Oscar.

Peter Bart, the editor-in-chief of "Variety," joins us. He even has some thought tonight about what appears to be a smear campaign against the movie, "A Beautiful Mind."

What in the world is going on out there?

PETER BART, EDITOR-IN-CHIEF, VARIETY: God, it sounds like the Olympics, doesn't it. I mean, things are getting tough.

DOBBS: Well, I mean, why a smear campaign against a movie? I -- and who's doing it? And why?

BART: Well, of course, no one really knows.

You know, every year the competitive level of the Academy Awards gets a little more intense, just like every other aspect of our society.

And, sure, there are innuendos about what Nash may really have been like -- John Nash, the real character on whom the picture was based.

My other question is, who cares?

Because I think the, you know the 4,000 members of the Academy are all, like myself, up there in age. And I think that everyone's a bit crusty, and been doing this a long time. I don't think they're influenced by rumors and innuendos.

DOBBS: You don't think so. So, we -- who's going to win the category? You tell me.

BART: You know, I think …

DOBBS: Does "Beautiful Mind" make it?

BART: … I think it's going to be so close, that what could happen is that two favorites could cancel each other out. Like "Lord of the Rings" and "Beautiful Mind" and, as with the producer scale, all of a sudden, a "Moulin Rouge" or a "Gosford Park" or an "In the Bedroom" wins.

And this is going to be a year of surprises. And there's a lot of money at stake.

DOBBS: Well, the money that's at stake, as you say, is sizable. It is huge, in fact.

Money also at stake in the release of "ET" returning to the big screen. What do you expect to happen there? Is it going to be a smash again?

BART: Well, that's a wonderful long shot. I mean, this is a picture from the Reagan era, really.

And there have been digital enhancements. But still, the picture is a little old-fashioned. It's being introduced with this huge live orchestra of 200, you know, tomorrow night in Los Angeles.

You know, it could either be "The Godfather," which came out after 25 years …

DOBBS: Right.

BART: … and no one went to see it because it was on television over and over again.

Or it could be like "The Exorcist," which became $100 million picture all over again.

And it's fascinating to take a picture from another generation, you know, and try it out again.

They're spending money on it. About 2,000 screens, big campaign. We'll see.

DOBBS: Ted Koppel, Dave Letterman -- both of whom are beaten nightly by Jay Leno. Dave stays at CBS. Ted beats him the rest of the week.

What's going on, and should we care?

BART: Well, it was the most written about non-event, wasn't it, because Dave stayed put.

I think the main thing Dave wanted was, he was going off on vacation and wanted people to pay attention to him. And he got, you know, a lot of attention. And then …

DOBBS: He wasn't interested in that $30 million?

BART: Well, 31.5 -- I mean, that's a decent wage for a guy, you know. Ted Koppel …

DOBBS: You can get by.

BART: … Ted Koppel could return on the show. A lot of people would like (UNINTELLIGIBLE) I'm sure -- PBS.

You know, if someone would contribute $7.5 million of his $8 million salary, PBS would love him, don't you think?

DOBBS: I would think that almost anyone would love it if somebody would contribute $7.5 million, including Ted Koppel.

Bill Maher, in the middle of all of this, "Politically Incorrect" cut. No fanfare for him. No gnashing of teeth. What's going on there?

BART: It's funny, you know, because three or four million people every night listen to him.

You talk about promotions, you know, Dave Letterman always complained the show wasn't promoted.

No one ever promoted Bill Maher's show. And I thought "Politically Incorrect" really occupied an interesting niche.

That probably won't turn up anywhere, you know, at least on network, because some of the advertisers, again, some of the affiliates were getting dicey.

That -- I'd love to see that in an hour form on cable, perhaps. Don't you?

DOBBS: I -- it'd be interesting. Bill has a unique perspective on the world. And there seems to be plenty of room for unique perspectives on cable and broadcast, for that matter, these days. So …

BART: I agree.

DOBBS: … we'll see how talent wills out.

Peter Bart, as always, good to have you with us. Have a great weekend.

BART: Thank you.

DOBBS: Well, one of Wall Street's best-known, top analysts says the advertising slump is over.

Chris Dixon of UBS Warburg says the advertising recession has bottomed. A recovery will be with us much sooner than is expected.

And Chris is with us tonight. Tell us exactly what's going on. You really believe this is -- it's over.

CHRIS DIXON, ANALYST, UBS WARBURG: I think it's happened. Lee Westerfield, who does our broadcasting work, every week has been has been monitoring very carefully advertising spending.

And what we've seen this week for the first time is eight of the top 10 categories are up. And that compares, for example, with in January we only had one category that was up. In fact, we're up about 17 percent.

So we think this is really affirming a lot of the whispers that have been going on around advertising land.

(CROSSTALK)

DIXON: … here, and it's turning.

DOBBS: It's been described by media companies and advertising agencies as not an advertising recession, but depression.

How much do you expect it to come back, and how soon?

DIXON: Well, what we're saying now is, the advertising for the year will be up about two percent versus a previous decline of about one percent.

But more importantly, Lou, what we're seeing is continued improvement in individual categories.

DOBBS: Right.

DIXON: Auto spend is up almost 18 percent in the up -- in the spot market.

Now, the big indicator is going to be, not only the current NCAA ratings that we're seeing on CBS -- we've got the Oscars, as Peter just alluded to.

But what happens in the upfront market? We think the upfront market's going to be pretty good. We see it up -- being up about four percent. And a lot of that driven by autos.

DOBBS: Well, you're the media savant. What does this mean for the big media companies?

DIXON: Well, what it means is, we're going to see the E-side -- the earnings -- beginning to improve in the second half of the year. And that means that companies like AOL, companies like Viacom, are going to continue to be able to start to post accelerating cash flow.

The past year has been really tough. But these guys have used the opportunity to tighten their belts.

And as we take a look and see a turn in the economy, and now in advertising, it's going to come through first to the company's earnings, their cash flow, and eventually their stock prices.

DOBBS: Well, some of these companies have been beaten down so badly, including AOL Time Warner, as we say, the parent of this network, …

DIXON: Yes.

DOBBS: … that down is starting to look like up.

How significant is it, for example, for AOL Time Warner? For Disney? For Viacom?

DIXON: Well, Viacom, or Clear Channel, which are the first two …

DOBBS: Right.

DIXON: … companies we see moving -- of almost 80 cents of every dollar of new dollars of advertising will flow to the bottom line.

DOBBS: Now, that's for Clear Channel and …

DIXON: For Viacom specifically.

DOBBS: … Viacom, as well.

DIXON: At AOL we estimate it to about 35 cents, and at Disney to about 25 cents. So this is a significant …

DOBBS: What's wrong with the AOL management? Shouldn't they be getting a little more leverage there?

DIXON: Has to do with a mix of businesses. At this point, we've got -- AOL is not in the radio business. AOL is obviously in the Internet the business, which has been a laggard. But clearly the cable television business, as well as things like WB. And of course --

DOBBS: How about radio?

DIXON: Radio is the first one to move. It tends to be easy to get into. Advertising companies come in and say, gee we can start a radio campaign and run with it. It's much easier and doesn't cost as much. That's the first place that advertisers tend to commit dollars.

DOBBS: Well, now that you believe that you have seen a significant turn, there are obviously a lot of other influences on the valuation of these stocks. How soon would you advise investors to start looking at them?

DIXON: Well, we have been saying for the past three months is the opportunity would be to pick them off as they're volatile, that is buy them on weakness. Now we're saying that we think the stocks have defined the trading range, and we're a buyer at these levels. So whether AOL has been trading between a low of 23 to 29, right now we would be adding the positions in AOL. Viacom between 37, touched 50 today. Fine. We don't think it's going back to 37, we're a buyer.

DOBBS: Aggressively or just tepidly?

DIXON: I think what we are saying is this is a firming trend. We do have to get through the next two months. But, clearly, we seem to see the light at the end of the tunnel and it's not an oncoming train.

DOBBS: Still caution. Is that what I hear in your voice?

DIXON: Cautious optimism.

DOBBS: There you go. All right, Chris. Thanks very much. Chris Dixon, as always, good to have you here.

DIXON: Thank you.

DOBBS: Coming up next, more good economic news today, just days before the fed meets to talk about the direction of interest rates. Our round table will be here to tell us whether a rate hike is in the cards, and precisely what will happen to this economy and these markets.

Also, department stores struggling to raise their sales, despite an improving economy. They are struggling period. We'll tell you what their doing to save themselves from demise.

And just as you were thinking about spring, a winter storm. We'll tell you all about it. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: The world's leading oil producers today decided to leave oil production unchanged, at least until the end of June. That OPEC decision made in Vienna where they're meeting. It also raised fears that gasoline prices, however, will be moving higher. Charles Hodson reports for us from Vienna -- Charles.

CHARLES HODSON, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Hi there, Lou. Yes, it was very much the decision that everyone including the markets were expecting. And in -- certainly in terms of OPEC itself, this was a no-brainer. The 21.7 million barrels as day that the oil cartel has been producing for the first quarter this year, that will continue to be what they produce in the second quarter, as well. And they are calling on Norway, Oman, Mexico and Russia, among non-OPEC members to help them out with that.

But let's just have a look at in whose name they're doing this, and this is in the name of price stability. OPEC's target for crude oil, which is their own basket of oil, which is usually $2 or so cheaper than Brent crude or the New York crude. They want to see it in the $22 to $28 range, with an average of $25. Now it's not until, according to the hawks anyway, until we reach $28 a barrel for OPEC crude that OPEC will think again about turning the taps a little wider and giving the economy slightly cheaper oil.

We could look at oil going all the way up to $30 a barrel, at least in the view of the OPEC talks, before we get a shift in the production levels. Of course, there are a lot of uncertainties down the track. We're looking at uncertainties about Iraq, what the military situation will bring there. Whether that will bring any disruption to supply, whether a broader Middle East crisis could also disrupt supply, whether Russia, for example, will play its part in delivering the production cut backs and a lot of people in the markets are pretty skeptical about that one. And above all, how quickly the recovery continues from here. Because obviously, it's a fairly fledgling, a fairly sickly recovery, than cheap oil is going to be very bad for it. So there are a lot of imponderables, OPEC is not planning to meet for another three-and-a-half months. And really the ministers could come under a lot of pressure, not least from Washington before then -- Lou.

DOBBS: Charles, thank you very much. Charles Hodson live from Vienna.

Fears of higher oil prices, not the only thing raising some concerns that the fed may have to adjust rates. There was some -- more positive news today on the economy and those reports adding to the belief among some policymakers may start preparing for a rate hike when they meet next week. Kathleen Hayes with the report.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

KATHLEEN HAYS, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Signs of economic recovery have turned from a trickle to a flood. In February the first back to back monthly gains of industrial production in a year-and-a- half as inventory rebuilding boosts orders and output. And in mid- March, a substantial jump in consumer sentiment.

This turn in the economy has coincided with a sharp move higher in bond yields, as traders bet on an eventual move by the Federal Reserve to hike its key short-term interest rate. And now corporate giants like GE have come to market selling billions of dollars of bond, hoping to issue their debt before rising rates make borrowing more expensive. But some economists say there's no need to rush.

STEVE EAST, FRIEDMAN BILLINGS, RAMSEY: I think the long rates as the year progresses, the bond market will see that inflation in fact is going down and not up. And that long rates, say, the middle of the summer will be at lower levels than we see now.

HAYS: Chain producer prices in February underscored how weak inflation forces remains in many parts of the U.S. economy, as firms find it tough to raise prices in a weak global economy. And That global weakness, along with the dollar's high level are expected to hurt exports, which may keep growth and manufacturing slow and the Federal Reserve in check.

DAVID HUETHER, NATL. ASSN. OF MANUFACTURERS: If we look at the recessions, every recession dating back to 1945, typically, the manufacturing sector expands by about 6 percent during the first six months after a recession. And we're expecting growth of about a third of that amount.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HAYS: At next week's policy meeting, the fed is expected to shift its policy stance is expected to shift to neutral, away from a bias to cut rates. But most economists are not look for a rate hike until May or June at the earliest -- Lou.

Kathleen, thank you very much. On Wall Street, today stocks finished the week on a positive note. Today's economic report suggesting the economy doing very well, thank you. Blue chips up five of the past six sessions and up five weeks in a row. The Dow Jones Industrials gaining 90 points. The Nasdaq up 14 points. The S&P 500 rose just over 13 points. A mixed performance for the week. The Dow is up for a fifth straight week. The Nasdaq down more than 3 percent this week, the S&P 500 up slightly.

For more now on the markets I'm joined by Ron Hill. Ron, good to have you here.

RON HILL, BROWN BROTHERS HARRIMAN: Nice to be here, Lou.

DOBBS: We're seeing a split market here, what does that suggest to us?

HILL: Well, I think people are still highly uncertain. A lot of people that I have spoken to have put on bull market portfolios after September 21. And so they're unhappy. People who put on bear market portfolios are unhappy too, because nothing has moved enough to make either one exactly right. They are kind of frozen.

DOBBS: Well, you tell us, who's right?

HILL: Well, we believe the fed with all those rate cuts is going to eventually have all that liquidity come into the stock market, that tends to lift everything; better economy, better profits, better stock prices. That is sort of the mantra right now, I think, Lou.

DOBBS: We're 14 months after the first of the many of the most aggressive rate cutting year in the history of the fed.

HILL: Exactly.

DOBBS: Where is it?

HILL: It's all sitting in money market mutual funds. It's out there in cash. And I think people have no real conviction to get back in the market yet. Perhaps you need to see stronger price action to pull some people in off the sidelines.

DOBBS: Would you advise people to jump in?

HILL: We are telling people. I have just been traveling a lot telling clients, we think you should get in ahead of this.

DOBBS: Are they listening?

HILL: A lot of them are still waiting. They'd like to this break out. They'd like to see a big volume break out. We just haven't seen it yet.

DOBBS: And what sector seems strongest to you?

HILL: We think it's going to be a cyclical-led recovery, so it's going to be information technology, industrials, sort of the hard goods side of consumer discretionary. That's where we are encouraging people to put money right now.

DOBBS: Still some very high multiples in IT, in technology.

HILL: It is true. But you know, we have had the first move in technology, now we're having a pullback. Normally what happens is the second move is when the earnings revisions start to run ahead of the market. That's what we're looking for now.

DOBBS: Ron, thank you very much. I'm going to, if I may, introduce some few folks who are going to join you. Ron, thanks for staying. Chris Dixon, kind enough to stay with us to participate in this roundtable. It's called other things, but we won't -- Greg Clarkin, covering the Nasdaq all day, Christine Romans, covering the Big Board, Jan Hopkins, covering the world, and Kathleen Hays back with us.

How likely is it that we will see anything of substance out of the Fed next week?

HAYS: I think what the Fed is going to do is shift this policy stance. But this is so important, because when the Fed worries about the economy in its policy statement, it says our next move, if anything, is to cut rates. Now it's going to clearly signal, don't worry about rate cuts anymore, we're in neutral. But people I think are going to look very closely what it says about the economy, they get a sense of how worried is the Fed or how strong…

DOBBS: Whether to listen to Ron Hill.

HAYS: Exactly. Because the Fed is kind of cautious. They figured the rate hikes are pushed off in the year. If they are really optimistic on the economy, they say, oh my goodness, maybe the rate cuts are coming sooner than we think. I mean, rate increases are coming sooner than we think.

DOBBS: Let's hope not.

JAN HOPKINS, CNN FINANCIAL NEWS CORRESPONDENT: But you know, it's interesting, if the Fed is talking about the economy doing well, that could help the markets, because no one thinks that the Fed is going to raise rates right away. It could encourage all of these investors that Ron's been talking to to put money in the market, and then push things higher.

CHRISTINE ROMANS, CNN FINANCIAL NEWS CORRESPONDENT: But they are starting to put money in the market, because this week we saw the (UNINTELLIGIBLE) data that shows that indeed doubled the inflows into equity funds this week from the week earlier. Five weeks up for the Dow, three weeks in a row up for the S&P. We haven't seen that in a long time. People are cautious, but they're starting to test the waters.

GREG CLARKIN, CNN FINANCIAL NEWS CORRESPONDENT: You know, technology speaking, it's this whole other issue, IT spending. And despite the fact that you are getting good macroeconomic news, you still have this disconnect with IT spending. A lot of folks believe that's going to be a long time coming before that rebounds.

DOBBS: You are talking about IT as an investment -- an attractive investment target. Against that, why?

HILL: Well, we think that, you know, there's going to be another semiconductor cycle that these -- technology is predicted to have profits grower faster than any other segment for this year, up about 50 percent. If that comes through, I think these stocks will run for a while, and then they'll take a pause later. But right now, we think it should be semiconductors, equipment makers, the bottom of the food chain, and see if everything else follows along.

DIXON: (UNINTELLIGIBLE) 2 to 3 percent. But that's really all about corporate confidence. What's interesting is, when we looked at advertising, when we looked at how companies are going to be spending with its IT, it's about building corporate confidence. What we have seen in the market is consumer confidence. The next step is to really see how companies feel about themselves, are they going to start to spend. And if they start to do that, then we can really have a sustainable (UNINTELLIGIBLE).

DOBBS: Well, that corporate confidence comes, does it not, from the same point as investor confidence -- earnings? Real earnings, not cash flow, not the suggestion that we're going to see a little bump, but real final demand working its way in and creating earnings.

HAYS: Absolutely. And I think you're so smart to point that out, because we're going to get good economic numbers.

DOBBS: I think you're smart.

(LAUGHTER)

HAYS: But first quarter gross domestic product, people are talking 4 percent, 5 percent, even 6 percent. But if you have that swing in inventory, that's great, but if doesn't translate into the earnings, I think the stock market, you know, Ron, you don't get any further down the road than you have gotten between the bulls and the bears then.

HOPKINS: You know, it's interesting. Corporate CEOs I think have been burned by making predictions that turned out to be wrong. And so now they're going to be behind the curve.

(CROSSTALK)

HOPKINS: So now they are going to be behind the curve. They're going to really have to see the earnings before they start investing in information technologies.

DOBBS: So we should actually…

(CROSSTALK)

ROMANS: Well, this is why so many people are starting to talk about dividends again, companies that pay dividends. You know, you're getting back to some basics in the market and what a lot of guys and women on Wall Street are recommending in terms of stocks to buy, because there is still that question about the validity of corporate earnings here. People are still scared.

CLARKIN: Let me to go back Oracle, which Lou points out -- very smart of you to point out.

(LAUGHTER)

DOBBS: Thank you.

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: I think you and Kathleen are the smartest people here.

CLARKIN: Exactly what tech investors are worrying about, what Oracle said, is that big customers, potential customers are still pushing out orders. You are still not seeing that order flow yet, and that's exactly what's hanging over a lot of these big tech companies.

HILL: I think what you're going to see that, you know, first quarter profits are going to be down less than fourth quarter profits. You have got a trend where profits are getting less and less negative; positive I think in Q2. Let's watch the earnings sort of warnings season, which starts officially today, goes for the next two weeks. And I think, you know, we're going to see fewer, you know, preannouncements, and probably more upside surprises than downside surprises in quarter reports.

DIXON: It's going to be lumpy. I mean, there's still going to be a couple of disappointments. People are going to miss some of the numbers. But that's really the opportunity now. And volatility, if you are a bull and you see a turn coming, it's really the opportunity that you want to use to your advantage.

DOBBS: What about the year ago comps in terms of earnings? Just impossible for this quarter -- let's think to the second, is that what you're suggesting?

HILL: Exactly. I think down 13 percent on operating earnings year over year, maybe plus three. It's the second half of the year when you have got big double-digit gains against very easy comparisons, and that's going to really I think -- people should buy ahead of that, historically, and I think they will.

DOBBS: Next week, the most important elements? Obviously, the Fed meeting. Anything else of importance that our viewers should be looking for?

HOPKINS: I think that we should be looking at whether there are going to be Andersen effects, companies that can't get their audit reports on time because of all of the problems with Andersen. We haven't seen that yet, but we could see it.

DOBBS: Well, apparently, very few people have been reading them very diligently, anyways.

(LAUGHTER)

HAYS: But don't you think it's going to be fun to see this H- P/Compaq vote? I mean, (UNINTELLIGIBLE), but it's a great, great Wall Street story, whether Carly wins or Walter wins.

DOBBS: And of course, we are reporting tonight, but our sources tell us that talks between Andersen and KPMG are progressing in far more substantively. We just want to say thank you very much to Chris Dixon, to Ron Hill, Greg, Christine, Jan, Kathleen, as always, everybody have a great weekend. Thank you.

Still ahead here, I'll be working. And when I continue working, we'll be telling you about some department stores who are in real trouble, but coming up with new strategies for survival. We'll tell you all about that in just a moment. And celebrating West Point's 200th anniversary. This is a celebration we can all take part in. And we'll tell you what today's defense secretary said about America's oldest academy. That's coming up in "Their Words."

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: Tough times in retailing, just the latest blow to this country's struggling department stores. After pursuing a strategy of consolidation and growth, the big stores are under increasing pressure to reinvigorate and reconnect with shoppers. Peter Viles has the story.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

PETER VILES, CNN FINANCIAL NEWS CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): If you could look at the bright side, none of the big department stores is in bankruptcy, none hurting as bad as the Gap. But that said, the pain continues for this American institution. And it is partly self- inflicted. A decade of consolidation and cost cutting has done nothing to excite consumers who are choosing the convenience of discounters.

HOWARD DAVIDOWITZ, CHAIRMAN, DAVIDOWITZ & ASSOCIATES: Young people are totally turned off by department stores. Department stores historically have been the home of brands in America, but they're the same brands. It's Liz Claiborne, Tommy Hilfiger, Donna Karan. So you can't tell the difference of what department store you're even in.

VILES: It shows up in the stocks. Over the past five years, shares of Federated gained just 17 percent, May department stores just 12. Saks shares lost 32 percent. But look at the discounters. Wal- Mart and Target both up more than 300 percent.

(on camera): So, department stores are trying to reconnect with consumers. Bloomingdale's, which is already considered to be one of the best at that, is negotiating to open a smaller store, maybe even a boutique here in New York's trendy Soho neighborhood.

Other innovations strategies: Neiman Marcus invested in two brands that it sells, Kate Spade handbags and Laura Mercier cosmetics. And May is betting on brides, purchasing three bridal chains.

DANA TELSEY, BEAR STEARNS: The key is you need better customer service, you need fresher looking stores and some differentiated merchandise.

VILES: For all their troubles, department stores still rack up massive sales. Federated outsells Amazon.com five to one.

DAVID MOIN, WOMEN'S WEAR DAILY: I still think it's viable because there's a ton of business being conducted at department stores. You have Federated, $18 billion in sales; May company, about $14 billion; Dillard's approaching $10 billion. People are still there. The problem is the stores are not making a lot of money.

Department stores have a trump card, though, and they play it once a year in the fourth quarter. When Americans are in a hurry, they often go back to the big old stores they have always known.

Peter Viles, CNN Financial News, New York.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

DOBBS: "WOLF BLITZER REPORTS" begins in just a few minutes, coming up at the top of the hour. For a preview now, let's go to Andrea Koppel in Washington filling in tonight for Wolf -- Andrea.

ANDREA KOPPEL, CNN STATE DEPARTMENT CORRESPONDENT: Thanks, Lou.

Coming up, the fate of U.S. Navy pilot Michael Speicher (ph). He was the first American lost in the Gulf War and 11 years later, he is the only American still unaccounted for. We'll look at what the Pentagon says about what happened to him and what his friends and family say. That's just ahead on THE WAR ROOM -- Lou.

DOBBS: Andrea, looking forward to it. Thank you very much.

Well, with less than a week left of winter, there is no sign of spring for most of the Midwest today. One of the season's biggest snowstorms blanketing much of the plains states, up to two feet of snow covered parts of Minnesota, Wisconsin and Iowa. And Northwest, the major carrier at the Minneapolis airport, had to cancel 300 of its flights as the storm moved in dropping all of that snow. And that winter weather helped lead to an increase in wheat prices on the Chicago Board of Trade. That amid peers that winter wheat crops may well be damaged.

Coming up next, in their own words, what top newsmakers said today, including words of praise from a very modern defense secretary for a very old, venerable institution.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: Tonight, comments from the day's events and those newsmakers who were contributing. Ranging from the fate of the North Korea defectors to a family's sacrifice in the war against terrorism, and a tribute to West Point. All from the newsmakers of the day "In Their Words."

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ROLIO GOLEZ, PHILIPPINES NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISER: The 25 North Koreans are going to be allowed to stay here for a maximum of three days. After which, they will be going to South Korea. This has been arranged already. It's OK with the president, with the department of foreign affairs, the vice president, the secretary of foreign affairs and everything has been arranged already.

SEN. ORRIN HATCH (R), UTAH: Mr. President, I fear that the judiciary committee was not as fair as Judge Pickering's record. I'm greatly disappointed and profoundly concerned for our country. What is now occurring is far beyond the mere tug of war of politics that unfortunately surrounds the Senate judicial confirmation or has surrounded it since Robert Bork.

SEN. HARRY REID (D), NEVADA: I'm terribly concerned, however, that some people, even some colleagues, are making this committee vote over one person into an unfortunately acrimonious fight. It's not the vote of people of good will in the confirmation of a judge, but the voices of anger and disappointment that will hurt our institution.

BUSH: I had the honor of meeting with the widows of two of the soldiers who died. They, too, and their dad and their mom of one of the guys. To a person, they said, Mr. President, you know, don't falter. These people just lost a loved one and they are just as resolved about winning this war on terror as I am. And I was very impressed by their steadfast support for what we're doing and their understanding of the sacrifices necessary to defend freedom.

RUMSFELD: For two centuries, the long gray line has marched into the history books, heroic in war and vigilant in peace. Over the decades, graduates of West Point have become leaders in literally every walk of life. And today, many of those leaders are active in the global war against terrorism, men and women serving in far-flung places across the globe. We respect their service to our country and we thank them.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

DOBBS: Indeed, we do. That is MONEYLINE for this Friday evening. Thanks for being with us. I'm Lou Dobbs. Good night from New York. Have a very pleasant weekend.
