Aired 7:30-8a ETLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

[07:30:44] ERICA HILL, CNN ANCHOR: World markets, as you can see there, mixed this morning. U.S. stocks appear to be set for a solid opening. A rally, though, fizzled yesterday as Dow and S&P 500 remain on pace for their worst December since 1931 which, of course, was in the middle of the Great Depression.

So you may be wondering what's going on. Joining us now is CNN political commentator Catherine Rampell who is a "Washington Post" opinion columnist. And, CNN senior economics analyst Stephen Moore, who was also an economic adviser to the Trump campaign.

As we look at all of this, let's just pull back for a minute because there is a lot of up and down, as we know, in the markets and you're told all the time by financial advisers -- whether it's the people you call on the phone or if you have someone you talk to about your money regularly -- don't look at this on a day-to-day basis. Don't go and look at your 401K.

STEPHEN MOORE, CNN SENIOR ECONOMICS ANALYST, DISTINGUISHED FELLOW, THE HERITAGE FOUNDATION, FORMER TRUMP ECONOMIC ADVISER: Yes.

HILL: But, Catherine, as people at home are looking at this it's hard not to look at the headlines every day and say whoa, what's really going on with this market.

How concerned should people be?

CATHERINE RAMPELL, CNN POLITICAL COMMENTATOR, OPINION COLUMNIST, THE WASHINGTON POST: Well, a lot of the slide in the market recently, or at least the whipsawing, has to do with recent policy uncertainty, right, about the trade war, news that we do or don't have a deal with China.

There's other uncertainty, of course, about the Affordable Care Act because a judge struck it down as unconstitutional last Friday. So we saw a big decline in health-related stocks on Monday.

So some of this has to do with recent policy uncertainty which may or may not get resolved. Some of it has to do with potentially actual weaknesses in our economy, right, if you look at housing, for example, or you look at other signs that there might be some lurking risks in the economy, like the inverted yield curve.

But there doesn't seem to be an indication that we are like on the verge of a recession if you look at forecasts.

For example, "The Wall Street Journal" surveyed a bunch of economists and they said -- more than half of them said they are expecting a recession by 2020. It does seem like there might be a recession sometime in the next few years.

But, you know, if you're worried about the stock market, if you're worried about the economy, I do not recommend looking at the day-to- day fluctuations, although they are a little bit telling about what risks may lie in store.

HILL: I hear you laughing, Stephen. Is that in agreement or is it --

MOORE: Yes, I'm going to jump around that one. My wife -- my wife is guilty of it. She -- every night she calls me. Oh, honey, we lost $5,000 today or we gained $3,000 or $5,000 the next day.

I agree with that. Look, especially, by the way, if you're a long- term investor. If you've got your money in a retirement account or even if it's a three- or five- or 10-year investment, you don't want to look at these daily changes in the stock market. It's only going to make you seasick.

Look, I think that the economy is still very fundamentally strong. And, in fact, it's really interesting -- I've been studying this stuff for 25 years. I've very rarely seen such a divergence in terms of where the real economy is, which is extremely positive still.

Yes, I mean, we've come down from these incredible highs we had six months ago. But manufacturing is strong, construction is strong, industrial production is strong. Consumer confidence is still near its 30- or 40-year high. And yet, the stock market keeps falling.

RAMPELL: But --

MOORE: I agree -- I agree with Catherine --

RAMPELL: There are some --

MOORE: -- and I think the main --

RAMPELL: Yes.

MOORE: -- point is this China trade war. But I'm actually somewhat optimistic that in the next 60 or 70 days we are going to get a deal. And if that happens, the stock market goes through the roof.

HILL: Alan Greenspan, speaking with CNN's Julia Chatterley yesterday, said basically prepare first. I just want to play a little bit of what he had to say.

MOORE: OK.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JULIA CHATTERLEY, CNN ANCHOR, "FIRST MOVE WITH JULIA CHATTERLEY": Do you think we're still in a bull market -- an equity bull market?

ALAN GREENSPAN, FORMER CHAIRMAN, FEDERAL RESERVE BOARD: Not really, no. It's beginning to fumble. You can see it by the reaction in recent days.

It would be very surprising to see it sort of stabilize yet and take off again, but it's happened in the past. However, at the end of that run, run for cover.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HILL: And, Stephen, your point, I think, with China could change things. Then you hear Alan Greenspan saying even if this happens, at the end of it --

MOORE: I think it could.

HILL: -- run for cover. Those are sobering words.

MOORE: They sure are. I mean, look, Alan Greenspan's a smart guy, you know. He ran the Federal Reserve, obviously. He did a -- he did a pretty darn good job at the Fed for -- I think he was there over a decade.

But, you know, he's not an oracle. None of these people at the Fed are.

I'm going to stick with my prediction that I'd put it maybe better than 50-50 odds that as we get close to that 90-day deadline that Trump set in Buenos Aires with President Xi to get some kind of concessions from China -- if that happens I think you're going to see some real jubilation in the stock market.

[07:35:15] Look, I think President Trump has really almost staked his presidency on getting this deal done. And it's all, right now -- the ball is in -- it's hard to predict because the ball is in Beijing's court whether they're going to come forward.

And by the way, last week we saw what a -- what a, you know, bad actor China is on the international scene with the hacking of American companies. They're stealing our technologies.

This is a fight Trump has to win. It's a Trump -- it's a fight, frankly, America has to win.

HILL: I want to look at another fight that's coming up or the president seems to be picking with his own Fed chair, Jerome Powell. So we know, too -- we're waiting today, obviously, for a possible Fed rate hike.

Catherine, we look at this, though -- these unprecedented attacks on the Fed. What's the overall implication there? What's the lasting impact? RAMPELL: I think the lasting impact of this is very dangerous, is how I would put it.

So, essentially, the Fed has worked over the decades -- this is a multi-decade-long project to establish credibility to show that they are politically independent. That they are now swayed by the day-to- day considerations, politics of the next upcoming election, and that is critically important for price stability and for growth.

I mean, if you want to look at a useful counterexample, look at places like Venezuela or Argentina or pre-Euro Italy or other places where politicians got control of the printing press.

So it is critically important for the Fed to both maintain its political independence and the perception of political independence.

And when Trump starts browbeating them and saying I think that they should keep rates low because we want to juice growth a little bit more, that threatens the Fed's credibility and could actually backfire if you're looking at what Trump's ultimate objective is because the Fed might say look, we don't want to look like we're caving to political pressure. Maybe we should err on the side of raising rates if there's some ambiguity about whether we should or whether we shouldn't.

So they may decide that --

MOORE: That may --

RAMPELL: -- if -- that if Trump is going to publicly browbeat them and try to arm-twist them -- which again, goes against decades of precedent for what presidential administrations do -- they may say we need to assure markets that we are politically independent and we're going to raise rates.

MOORE: Well --

RAMPELL: I don't know that they're going to do that, but that could certainly be an outcome.

MOORE: Well, let me -- let me respond to that.

HILL: Real quickly, Stephen.

MOORE: Look, the fact is that three months ago Donald Trump criticized, very severely, the Fed decision to raise rates, and it turns out Donald Trump was exactly right. That, in fact, since then the stock market has been on a long-term -- we've lost 10 percent value.

And the economy -- you know, there's a deflation now. I mean, you look at what's happened to the oil price, you look at --

RAMPELL: But that's because of his trade war. I mean --

MOORE: -- the price of copper and cotton and so on. RAMPELL: But, you know -- but you said -- you just said --

MOORE: And so, I'm -- look, my only point is this. Catherine --

RAMPELL: You just said that the economy is fundamentally strong.

MOORE: Let me just make this point.

RAMPELL: You can't have it both ways.

MOORE: It is strong.

RAMPELL: Either the economy is fundamentally strong --

MOORE: No, I --

RAMPELL: -- which justifies raising rates.

MOORE: The economy --

RAMPELL: Or it's fundamentally weak --

MOORE: Catherine, let me -- let me finish my point.

RAMPELL: -- which suggests a pause.

MOORE: The -- no, no, no, no. The economy is strong. The problem that we face in the future is a deflation because of these raising of interest rates.

I want the Fed to set a stable --

RAMPELL: What?

MOORE: -- price system. We don't have stable prices now. Catherine, we have deflation.

Look at what's happened with the -- you know, we've got a 10 percent decline in corn prices, soybean prices, cotton prices. But that -- yes -- no, there was a deflation on --

RAMPELL: We don't -- we don't have deflation right now. You can look at the CPI. There is not deflation right now.

HILL: One thing that we do have, though -- we do have a time limit, so I'm going to have to cut you both off there.

MOORE: Oh, damn.

HILL: The good news is you know we'll bring you back again and we're not done with this topic.

Stephen, Catherine, appreciate it.

MOORE: OK.

HILL: Thank you, both.

RAMPELL: Thank you.

HILL: John --

JOHN BERMAN, CNN ANCHOR: I'm going to use that. We have a time limit -- all right.

Who is Facebook sharing your personal data with? "The New York Times" report -- you know, the headline is this -- your private messages may not be so private. That's next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

[07:42:47] HILL: This morning, Facebook is facing another stunning privacy scandal. And, yes, we're talking about your information. "The New York Times" reported the social media giant gave more than 150 partner companies intrusive access to users' personal data -- something that went on for years.

CNN's Brian Stelter joins us live to help explain.

So, first of all, these internal documents here that we do have, what do they reveal about the information that Facebook was sharing with these partner companies?

BRIAN STELTER, CNN CHIEF MEDIA CORRESPONDENT, ANCHOR, "RELIABLE SOURCES": Yes, there was a wide variety of private information being shared with these trusted partners. The companies say that this data was not abused, but the point Erica is that the public didn't know. Users didn't know about these various uses of data.

Here are a few examples involving different big tech companies. Sony and Microsoft, for example -- Amazon able to obtain e-mails with -- private messages with friends. Netflix, Spotify, and the Royal Bank of Canada able to read, write, and delete private messages.

Yahoo! able to view a real-time feed of friends' post. And, "The New York Times" which broke this story, also had access years ago -- access to friend lists.

Now these companies, like Spotify and Netflix, they say they did not abuse this access. In many cases, they say they never even looked at all.

The point, though, is that Facebook left the door open. They left the door open for this access --

HILL: Right.

STELTER: -- and that seems very worrisome.

HILL: Well, also, I mean, there are -- there are so many sort of layers to this, too. Although you may -- you may not have done it but if you knew you could do it should you have raised a red flag? That's a separate issue there. There is the range of information, as you pointed out there. The ability to delete people's messages -- messages they thought were private.

Facebook is obviously responding. Are they shedding much light on this?

STELTER: Well, the company is saying what it's said, frankly, all year long, which is we need to do better, we've got problems.

Here's a part of the statement from one of the company's representatives, saying, "We know we've got work to do to regain people's trust. Protecting people's information requires stronger teams, better technology, and clearer policies, and that's what we've been focused on for most of 2018."

And look, Facebook has been under scrutiny all year long about these issues for a number of reasons. There's this tension baked into the platform.

Facebook is where I go to find out about my friends' and families' lives, their health concerns, their babies, their plans. And yet, Facebook also profits from all that data and works with all these other companies. And the headline from "The New York Times" overnight is that all these other companies also were able to be in that relationship and unbeknownst to users.

[07:45:06] Now, technically, if you click the box -- if you hit OK, you might -- you might -- Facebook might say you've given permission.

HILL: Right.

STELTER: You've allowed it. But I don't think users actually know what's going on.

So there's two questions this morning. One, did Facebook violate its 2012 agreement with the FTC -- its consent decree? The company says it didn't; others say it may have.

And number two, what are regulators going to do now? What is Washington going to do now to provide more oversight for these big companies?

HILL: And question three -- and I think a lot of people at home have, too -- is any of this still going on --

STELTER: It's still going on.

HILL: -- and who may still have access, if anyone? What are they doing with that?

STELTER: Right.

HILL: A lot of questions, not always a lot of answers. We get them from you, though. So, Brian, we appreciate that.

STELTER: Well, thanks.

HILL: Thank you -- John.

BERMAN: All right.

Those Russian social media ads and posts designed to influence our election, they seem silly and almost obvious now. So why were they so effective and what does that say about our deeply divided society?

Senior political analyst John Avlon has your reality check -- sir.

JOHN AVLON, CNN SENIOR POLITICAL ANALYST: That's right.

So, the pair of new studies commissioned by the bipartisan Senate Intelligence Committee first found that Russia's social media messaging ahead of the election, quote, "Clearly sought to benefit the Republican Party and specifically, Donald Trump, as early as the GOP primaries." And not to mention, of course, all of the requisite hitting on Hillary.

But what's really stunning is how Russia's efforts to spread misinformation over social media preyed on America's identity politics divides. They targeted tribes on the far-right and far-left. And to look through their characters of identity politics is to see how easily duped we are by dividers.

For example, Russian trolls targeted memes to the religious right in the name of the so-called Army of Jesus and their appeals were not exactly biblically-based.

Here's a picture of Jesus arm-wrestling the devil as a proxy war for Clinton versus Trump. Or this meme showing Trump and Pence as the Jesus team and Hillary and her running mate, Tim Kaine, as the Satan team. There's even an image of Jesus wearing a MAGA hat.

And if you liked these you were duped by the Russians.

On the left, Russian trolls also targeted an African-American activist community, pretending to care about Black Lives Matter and victims of police violence on the prolific Blacktivist page. At the same time, Russian trolls were pumping up the so-called Blue Lives Matter movement, showing police funerals and blaming them on Black Lives Matter activists.

Supposedly, patriotic gun rights memes were created and promoted by Russian trolls, like this image declaring that, quote, "The 2nd Amendment Is My Gun Permit" -- as well as LGBT pages like this adult coloring book offering a look at a quote-unquote "Buff Bernie" which we did not need to see.

There were anti-immigrant memes that echoed Trump's fearmongering about illegal immigrants voting. And pages that celebrated the Confederate flag as heritage, not hate, and promoted Texas secession as the next step after Brexit.

There were memes that mocked politically correct culture and concerns about white supremacy and also attacking John McCain.

Perhaps most sinister was when all of this fakeness aligned to attack real journalism, from fake George Orwell quotes to memes that compared North Korean propaganda to real news.

Now, if all this is enough to give you whiplash, that was part of the point. The goal of this kind of disinformation is to confuse, divide, and distract -- to create anger and apathy, sometimes with the specific goal of driving down election turnout, such as this meme aimed at the African-American community or promoting the Green Party candidacy of Jill Stein, who received more votes in key swing states of Wisconsin, Michigan, and Pennsylvania than Trump's victory margin.

In all, 10.4 million tweets, 116,000 Instagram posts, 61,000 Facebook posts, and 1,100 YouTube videos.

But on the most fundamental level, the Russian trolls understood that our identity politics divides, the kind that focus on common enemies rather than our common humanity, is the real source of weakness in our society and they exploited it with unwitting Americans' help.

Now, there's a phrase used by the mass murdering founder of the Soviet Union, Vladimir Lenin, that applies to folks who liked and shared these links -- "useful idiots."

And that's your reality check.

BERMAN: Sobering, and I'm not just talking about like the muscular workout Bernie Sanders. The whole thing is sobering.

HILL: Yes, the whole thing is.

AVLON: It's surreal and sobering.

BERMAN: All right, John. Thanks very much.

HILL: Hacked cables revealing how the international community really feels about President Trump, Iran, and Russia. "The New York Times" reporter who broke this story joins us, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

[07:53:24] HILL: "The New York Times" has obtained more than 1,000 hacked European diplomatic cables. Those cables reveal the international community's serious concerns about President Trump, Russia, Iran, and more.

Let's discuss with the reporter who broke the story, national security correspondent for "The New York Times" and CNN political and national security analyst, David Sanger.

David, good to have you with us, as always.

Give us a sense as we look at these. James Clapper was with us a little bit earlier and he said this certainly doesn't rise to the level of WikiLeaks in terms of the information that is now out here. But still, it's significant that somebody thought it important enough to steal it, post it somewhere to be found, and then have those folks share it with you.

DAVID SANGER, CNN POLITICAL AND NATIONAL SECURITY ANALYST, NATIONAL SECURITY CORRESPONDENT, THE NEW YORK TIMES: Well, Erica, I think that's right. I think Gen. Clapper is correct. This is not on the scale of WikiLeaks, which was 250,000 U.S. cables. And, frankly, Americans cared more about those cables because they were American in origin and I think did reveal a bit more.

In this case, the hackers who followed all the patterns of a Chinese People's Liberation Army group -- I don't think intended for any of these to become public.

They did a sort of traditional phishing campaign against the European Union. They got in through Cypress, a small and less well-defended member of the E.U. And then, used that access to get all of the documents that -- appear to have gotten all of the documents that are exchanged daily among European diplomats through the E.U.'s main network.

[07:55:00] In doing so, they briefly passed through some public sites on their way up to the cloud, and it was there that a company called Area 1 found them and turned about 1,000 of them over -- a little more than 1,000 of them over to us.

What they reveal, as you suggest, is that the diplomats get assurances from the National Security Council that President Trump didn't mean exactly what he said when he spoke with Vladimir Putin at that famous Helsinki press conference.

They worry that the Russians have already put nuclear weapons into Crimea. They are concerned that Iran will use the excuse of the U.S. coming out of the nuclear deal to restart their nuclear program.

HILL: They also, too, were looking at even just a cable that refers to a July meeting with E.U. officials and Xi Jinping talking about U.S. demands -- both U.S. -- what we're hearing from the U.S. and U.S. demands are inconsistent.

When that's the message that's going out which isn't shocking, perhaps, to a lot of people who have been following the headlines, obviously -- but does having this out there do any damage to relationships with these countries?

SANGER: You know, at this point, given the state of relations between the European Union and the United States, I don't think so.

The cable you refer to though, Erica, I think was one of the most interesting. It was a private meeting between Xi Jinping, the president of China, and the Europeans in Beijing. It was an E.U.- China summit in which President Xi basically says the Americans never live up to their word. President Trump is bullying them.

But then he goes into this fascinating long reverie about how China, for 100 or 200 years, has bent to larger powers and in this case, now feels strong enough that it doesn't plan to go do it again. And what's interesting is that the president views this entire thing transactionally --

HILL: Yes.

SANGER: -- and Xi views it as part of a long historical continuum in which the tide has turned and China is going to make sure that it doesn't get run over again.

HILL: It certainly sets it up there, doesn't it?

As we talk about all of this -- and even just putting it into context as you did off the top -- these cables and this communication versus some of the other things that have been hacked and then leaked -- it still begs the question of what's the conversation like at "The New York Times" when Area 1 comes to you and say we have 1,000 cables that we found that someone hacked. We want you to have them. We think you should publish them.

How is that decision made because there's still people at home who are going to say why should we see these?

SANGER: You know, that's a very good question and we debated this at some length, and here was the reasoning.

First of all, these were posted in an open site. It's not as if we got them through a hacking process or that Area 1 did, as well. The Chinese, in moving them -- or whoever the hackers were, though they certainly appear to be China-based -- did that.

Secondly, there were no big national secrets here. There were no nuclear codes. These were at the restricted level and confidential level. They were not top-secret documents.

And thirdly, as we looked at it they sort of gave a backstory, one that you would frequently get in background conversations with European officials and others, to their interchanges with the president, with the Chinese, with the Iranians. And it just sort of confirmed how they're talking to each other on it.

There were no great privacy revelations here, Erica. These weren't -- these didn't get into personally private data in any way. They were the kind of discussions you would get in a background candid conversation if you sat down with a European official.

HILL: They also, which I know you've pointed out and which James Clapper also did point out as well this morning -- they also pinpoint the fact that people have been concerned about the communications systems within the E.U. for some time and there's a question about what this could lead to in terms of changes.

David, we're out of time.

SANGER: Absolutely.

HILL: You're always appreciated. Thank you. SANGER: Thank you.

HILL: Michael Flynn's legal journey is far from over. NEW DAY continues right now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: The FBI broke standard protocol in the way that they came in and ambushed Gen. Flynn.

JAMES COMEY, FORMER DIRECTOR, FBI: I'm very proud of the way the FBI conducted itself.

EVAN PEREZ, CNN SENIOR JUSTICE CORRESPONDENT: This judge repeatedly went back to Flynn to make him say that he was, indeed, guilty.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: He stepped in front of a judge and said nope, I lied and I intended to. None of this makes sense to me.

KEN STARR, FORMER SOLICITOR GENERAL: We have a rule of law country. We saw that with checks and balances of Judge Sullivan.

REP. HAKEEM JEFFRIES (D), NEW YORK: Jared Kushner was authentically serious about trying to get something done to reform our broken criminal justice system.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Formerly incarcerated people, directly impacted people refuse to die on this.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: To see bipartisan legislation out of Washington these days is force of revelation. Who knew it could happen?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ANNOUNCER: This is NEW DAY with Alisyn Camerota and John Berman.

BERMAN: Good morning. Welcome to your NEW DAY. It is Wednesday, December --

A rally fizzled yesterday as Dow and S&P 500 remain on pace for their worst December since 1931 which, of course, was in the middle of the Great Depression. According to documents reviewed by The New York Times, Facebook arranged to share user data with 150 companies in an attempt to get more users while thwarting the platform's own privacy rules. Amazon got users' names and contact information through friend networks, and Netflix and Spotify had the ability to read Facebook users' private messages. The Senate Intelligence Committee is set to release two reports on Monday detailing the breadth of the Russian social media campaign to sow discord in the United States. The reports are based on troves of data that Facebook, Twitter, and Google handed over to the committee about the Russian campaign to influence the 2016 U.S. presidential election and American politics generally. A cybersecurity firm says hackers were able to infiltrate a European Union communications system for years and copy thousands of sensitive diplomatic cables, The New York Times has reported. The Dow Jones industrial average today climbed 82.61 to 11,018.72 while the Nasdaq tumbled 189.22 to 4,644.67. Christopher Chaney of A.G. Edwards discusses today's Nasdaq tumble. Vince Farrell of Spears, Benzak, Salomon & Farrell discusses the volatility in the stock market.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

JAN HOPKINS, CNN ANCHOR: You're looking at live pictures from the New York Stock Exchange. We are less than 60 seconds away from the closing bell.

Good afternoon, I'm Jan Hopkins.

Let's find out how these markets are doing in this last minute of trading.

Greg Clarkin, first.

GREG CLARKIN, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Well, Jan, make no mistake about it, the general is definitely in charge today. I'll show you how shares of General Electric led the Dow to an almost triple-digit gain.

SUSAN LISOVICZ, CNN CORRESPONDENT: I'm Susan Lisovicz at the Nasdaq.

The Nasdaq rallies back briefly after yesterday's triple-digit loss only to fall even further, plummeting to a 4 percent decline on the day.

JEFF FLOCK, CNN CORRESPONDENT: I'm Jeff Flock at the IRS' busiest tax preparedness center in the country. I'll be back in a little bit with the future of your tax returns.

HOPKINS: Plus, do you drive to other neighborhoods for cheaper gas? We'll be talking about zone pricing and why it means higher gas prices in general.

It's Wednesday, March 29th. Welcome to STREET SWEEP.

We have a tale of two markets today. A good day here at the New York Stock Exchange. A late-day rally in blue-chip stocks led by General Electric.

Greg Clarkin joins us from the floor to tell us about the Dow Jones industrial average -- Greg.

CLARKIN: And Jan, I'll tell you if every stock has its day, today was definitely the day for some of those neglected stocks, especially the retailing components of the Dow. We saw shares of Wal- Mart at the close up better than $4, up almost 4 1/2. Shares of Home Depot up almost $4. A couple of stocks that had been neglected by investors who have been chasing those spectacular gains in the tech sector up until recently, that is.

Today, we saw a lot of folks moving money, redeploying their funds out of that tech sector, kind of rushing back to the safety of some of these very familiar names with maybe less than spectacular growth prospects, but still, today they were really the stars. Stocks today extended the dramatic rally that began late yesterday, an encouraging end to what was a hairy week on Wall Street. But getting there was not all smooth sailing. The Dow was down more than 50 points at its low today, back in bear market territory, but the index regained its footing, ending up 115 points at 9,504. From the low yesterday, it has gained nearly 400 points. The big winners included IBM, Microsoft, which rallied yesterday, financial stocks American Express and Citigroup, and the oldest Dow component of them all, GE.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

WILLOW BAY, CNN ANCHOR: A powerful rally cuts across Wall Street.

ALLAN CHERNOFF, CNN ANCHOR: But the memory of a tumultuous week won't fade fast. This is MONEYLINE.

BAY: Stocks surge across the board, buyers rushing in, after three brutal sessions.

CHERNOFF: After this week's rollercoaster, we'll put investors on the therapy couch: how to cope when bull turns to bear.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I'm nervous about the market.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAY: Senators offer up an aggressive plan to jump-start the economy. Is the president on board?

CHERNOFF: And a big screen drama: theater chains on the brink. We'll look at how technology may play a starring role in a turnaround.

ANNOUNCER: Live from coast to coast, this is MONEYLINE.

BAY: Welcome to MONEYLINE. I'm Willow Bay in Los Angeles.

CHERNOFF: Hi, Willow. Hello, everyone. I'm Allan Chernoff in New York.

BAY: We begin tonight with a sigh of relief on Wall Street. Stocks today extended the dramatic rally that began late yesterday, an encouraging end to what was a hairy week on Wall Street.

But getting there was not all smooth sailing. The Dow was down more than 50 points at its low today, back in bear market territory, but the index regained its footing, ending up 115 points at 9,504. From the low yesterday, it has gained nearly 400 points.

The big winners included IBM, Microsoft, which rallied yesterday, financial stocks American Express and Citigroup, and the oldest Dow component of them all, GE. The S&P 500 jumped 22 points to end at 1,139, a gain there of 2 percent. And the Nasdaq advanced for the second day in a row, up nearly 31 points, closing at 1,928.

CHERNOFF: Today's bounce back didn't come a minute too soon for investors whipsawed over the past five sessions. Greg Clarkin takes us through a week that brought the Dow Industrials within a hair of a bear market for the first time in more than a decade.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

GREG CLARKIN, CNN FINANCIAL NEWS CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Monday, the week began innocently enough with investors optimistic ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting. Dual rallies on the Dow and the Nasdaq had traders feeling good and analysts saying prices were just too attractive to pass up.

(AUDIO GAP)

CLARKIN: … Tuesday, the markets played the waiting game, edgy and anxious as the Federal Reserve met with interest rates hanging in the balance until…

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Twenty seconds to go here as we await for this decision by the Federal Reserve. Again, the big debate has been: 50 or 75.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CLARKIN: It was 50 basis points, Alan Greenspan rate cut not enough for anxious investors who drove the Dow lower by more than 200 points, and knocked the Nasdaq down by close to 5 percent.

Wednesday, the selling began anew as traders struggled to keep up. The Dow ended down 2 1/2 percent; the Nasdaq dropped 1 1/2 percent.

Thursday, a traumatic morning on Wall Street as investors sold early and often. The Dow plunged almost 400, dropping to within points of 9,100, deep in bear market territory, as sell orders rained down on Wall Street. A late afternoon rally saved the blue chips, they finished with just a 97 point loss, the Nasdaq, meanwhile, staged a sharp rally.

Friday brought green arrows and relief on Wall Street. The Dow jumped more than 1 1/2 percent; the Nasdaq posted a similar rally. Analyst are optimistic, as well as realistic.

SAM GINSBERG, GRUNTAL & CO: We do have the chance to rally here, but again, I will repeat that this market absolutely does not go up in a straight line, and it does not go down in a straight line, so be prepared for the swings, be prepared to be confused.

(END VIDEOTAPE) CLARKIN: And confusion was indeed the word of the week, traders and analysts were confused as to where the lurching markets would go next, while investors just tried to hang on and survive one of the choppiest weeks in recent memory -- Allan.

CHERNOFF: Greg, the week at the Fed simply couldn't provide the stock market.

CLARKIN: Exactly. A lot of disappointment there on Tuesday.

CHERNOFF: Greg Clarkin, thanks very much -- Willow.

BAY: Allan, taking a quick look at the damage to the Dow this week: not as bad as you might suspect, the Dow fell more than 3 percent. Last Friday, the index closed out its worst week since 1989, and the Nasdaq gained ground on the week, up 2 percent. It is the first winning week for the index since January.

So, what drove tech stocks higher today? Well, let's go to John Metaxas at the Nasdaq market site for the look at the big movers there -- John?

JOHN METAXAS, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Well, Willow, the last couple days, we finally got some positive action after that disappointment earlier in the week over that 50 basis point cut. And with the rally in the Nasdaq came some fantastic performances for some stocks this week.

Let's take a look at the leaders. Rambus, one of the biggest gainers on the week, up 62 percent, and this is coming of off depressed levels last Friday. The chips had a fantastic week here today, chip equipment stocks such as Applied Materials and KLA-Tencor with double digit gains. Some of the big-cap Nasdaq stocks also surged. Dell Computer up 16 percent on the week, Oracle up 13 percent.

Now the gains today, part of the post-Fed rally, if you will, came despite the fact that there was negative news and negative sentiment. Analysts were down -- were lowering their estimates on Cisco Systems, there were concerns about them even meeting some of the lowered numbers. The stock was down 5 percent today, it was the most actively traded. But Cisco did not drag down the Nasdaq today, the Nasdaq proved resilient.

Our second most active stock, Immunex, down 39 percent after they said yesterday they would stop testing Enbrel on chronic heart failure. Immunex was down, but the biotechs managed a rally today. Microsoft, a big gainer, up 4.7 percent, and the advancers did have it over decliners by a two-to-one margin today.

Analysts are not willing to proclaim the bear dead, but some are saying maybe we're seeing the beginning of the end of the bear market -- Allan.

CHERNOFF: Just perhaps he's going to head into hibernation.

METAXAS: Just perhaps.

CHERNOFF: John, thank you very much.

While Wall Street was on a rollercoaster ride this week, Washington showed signs of movement on a potentially key economic issue, a huge retroactive tax cut aimed at boosting the economy right away. And today, President Bush signaled he's open to working out a plan. Peter Viles has the story.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

PETER VILES, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): It took some of the darkest days Wall Street has seen in years and some strong criticism. "The Wall Street Journal" accused Washington of, quote, "fiddling while the economy burns." But Washington is finally stirring. Members of both parties now pushing for immediate tax cuts to jump- start the economy, up to $60 billion beyond what is in the president's 10-year plan.

And today, the president said he's willing to consider it.

GEORGE W. BUSH, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We can accelerate tax relief and should accelerate tax relief, and keep the size of the tax relief package at the same level.

VILES: The version of the Bush tax cut that passed the House contained only $5.6 billion in income tax cuts this fiscal year, but House leaders now say they are open to much more.

JOHN RYDING, BEAR STEARNS: I think what Washington is reacting to now is the decline in the equity market, which over the last couple of weeks, has been fairly severe, making people think that the economy is in much worse shape than perhaps people inside of Washington, D.C. thought.

VILES: Senate Democrats Jon Corzine and Bob Graham say they can cut $60 billion in taxes this year by slashing the 15 percent bracket to 10 percent. Savings for a family of four: $840 this year. Senate Republicans say they too want 60 billion in immediate cuts, but they have not determined which taxes to cut or how to distribute the tax cuts.

A potential snag, though: Republicans want to link this year's cuts to the president's 10-year plan. Democrats, however, want to the vote on the immediate tax cuts first.

SEN. TOM DASCHLE (D-SD), SENATE MINORITY LEADER: Why not take what we already agree on, in the name of expeditious response to economic concerns raised by leaders in both parties, why not get this money out now?

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VILES: Economists have generally dismissed the impact of a $5 billion tax cut this year as insignificant; 60 billion, however, is real money, and could add more than 1/2 of percentage point to economic growth -- Allan.

CHERNOFF: And Peter, we'll be talking to a few key players on that issue in just a few minutes. Thank you very much -- Willow.

BAY: Allan, still to come on MONEYLINE: so, how is President Bush doing in his new job? We'll have the latest poll numbers, what Americans think about his performance, his tax plan and whether the U.S. is headed into a recession, and it's -- as we just reported, some Republicans and Democrats push for a tax cut now. We'll hear from both sides of the aisle about how to pay for it, Senators Chuck Grassley and Kent Conrad.

Plus, Bobby Knight will soon be back in business on the basketball court. We're expecting to hear within the next hour from the controversial coach. CNN will bring you there live.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: A new CNN-Time Warner poll is out, showing a majority of Americans approve of how President Bush is handling his job, but say they are nervous about the state of the economy.

The poll, conducted March 21st to 22nd, gave the president a 55 percent approval rating, but 53 percent think the president pays too much attention to big business.

Regarding the economy, 58 percent think that Mr. Bush's comments about a possible recession have affected the economy. Forty-nine percent of Americans think we'll see a recession within the next 12 months. Now that's far more than in 1989, on the eve of the last recession. And nearly half of Americans say the stock market's decline has affected their family, far more than after the crash of October of 1987.

Now, as for tax cuts, some 51 percent support the president's tax cut plan, up slightly from last month.

CHERNOFF: Despite that support, some Senate Republicans do not think the Bush tax plan works fast enough to jump start the slowing economy. As Peter Viles reported, they're calling for an immediate $60 billion tax cut, in addition to the Bush plan.

To talk about it we're joined right now, from Cedar Rapids, by Iowa Republican, Senator Charles Grassley.

Senator, thanks for joining us. And you just saw the numbers. Do we really need this immediate action from the Senate, from the Congress?

SEN. CHUCK GRASSLEY (R), IOWA: Well, first of all, there's more tax revenue coming in. People are over taxed, and so it's right to give the money to the people to spend. And we need to move that money out of Washington into the taxpayers pockets. It'll stimulate the economy. It's the right thing to do.

But the suggestion that we just ought to do it for one year and do that separately, and not have the long-term tax restructuring that the president's plan had, would be the wrong thing to do, because, really, the economic good of $60 billion this year in the taxpayer's pocket is a spit in the ocean to the economic good that will come from the restructuring of the tax code.

And since we have a 50/50 Senate, I think we ought to be able to work out a compromise between putting the $60 billion into the taxpayers pockets, which I think the Democrats want to do as well as Republicans, and then restructure the tax code. Maybe not exactly the way the president wants it done, but restructure it so we have 10 years of economic growth comes from it.

CHERNOFF: But Senator, to push the entire plan through, it appears that it would take some time, and a lot of people saying we need immediate help for the economy.

GRASSLEY: Well, even if we pass a tax bill this very day, by the time that the Treasury Department could notify everybody to change their W-2 form, they tell me, in Treasury Department, it would take six to eight weeks.

So, if you think that you can pass a bill today and verify that the right tax payers are getting the money, it isn't possible to write a check and you don't want to, obviously, send an airplane over the United States and scatter the money around. We've got to make sure that it's done in a verifiable able way, going to the taxpayers, and the best way to do that is to adjust the with holding that takes place.

CHERNOFF: So, very briefly, Senator, then it just simply does not matter if we get that $60 billion through? Are you saying we shouldn't even bother with that?

GRASSLEY: Oh, just the opposite. You ought to listen very closely. I said that it's very important that we do it for two reasons. One, the taxpayers are over taxed. When they are over taxed they ought to be allowed to keep the money. And secondly, if you leave it in Washington it will be frittered away in spending, because it's burning a hole in taxpayer's pockets, and thirdly, it will be a real economic stimulus to get it out.

CHERNOFF: OK, Senator Grassley. Thank you, very much.

Let's now move over to the Democratic side of the aisle.

Senator Kent Conrad, of North Dakota, and he comes to us from Capitol Hill.

Senator, you heard what your friend from other side of the aisle said. Do you think we need the $60 billion immediately, or should we attach it to the entire Bush tax plan?

SEN. KENT CONRAD (D), NORTH DAKOTA: Well, a number of us on the Democratic side have been advocating for weeks that we have immediate stimulus. And we have fought the president's for having virtually no stimulus this year, so it's too small now, and it's too big over the ten-year period that threatens to put us back into deficit, and to raid the trust funds of Social Security and Medicare.

So, on our side, we believe we should take immediate action on the $60 billion of stimulus for this economy now, and then later this year, take action on a 10 year package that's affordable and that's fair. But we don't think we should delay the $60 billion stimulus to wait for the larger package to pass, because that will take months.

CHERNOFF: Well, it sounds like some of the Republicans, in fact, do want to have that delay. Can we resolve the issue in the Senate?

CONRAD: Look, we've already agreed on how much money should go out. I think the Republicans, as they think about it, will realize that waiting for the whole package makes no sense at all. That just delays getting money out into the economy, into people's pockets that can help give some lift to this economy.

CHERNOFF: Briefly, Senator, how much help would this really give the economy? It would average to $300 a person. Is that really a big deal?

CONRAD: Well, it depends on where you are. We are proposing rate cut plus direct payments to individuals. That could be as much as $900 a taxpayer. What difference would it make? Economists tell us it could add 3/4 to 1 percent to the growth of our gross domestic product.

When you're growing at next to nothing, that helps. It doesn't solve the problem. Let's not overstate it, but it would help, along with monetary policy by the Federal Reserve Board to keep lowering interest rates, because that's the main driver here. That's the thing that can most help. But we also believe this additional stimulus will be of assistance too.

CHERNOFF: Senator Kent Conrad, thank you very much -- Willow.

BAY: Allan, straight ahead, the list of layoffs is getting longer at two of America's most well-known tech names.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: Topping tonight's corporate headlines: The growing tally of high-tech layoffs. Job cuts mount at Motorola, the world's number two cell phone maker, slashing another 4,000 jobs. Since December, Motorola has announced 22,000 layoffs. That's 15 percent of it's work force.

And networking giant, 3COM, cutting another 170 jobs in its broadband division, bringing total cuts there to nearly 1,400. The move was widely expected. Earlier this week, 3COM CEO, Bruce Caflin, warned of continued layoffs, saying "Business is only going to get worse before it gets better."

Checking those stocks: both barely budged the session, Motorola closing at just under $16.

CHERNOFF: Moving to tonight's tech watch: a makeover for Micron Electronics -- the company today abandoning its lagging PC business. Micron is far from a major PC player but this is no small decision. Ninety-seven percent of Micron's sales come from PC's, and that was a billion-dollar business last year.

Micron Electronics, in fact, will no longer exist. The company is buying Atlanta-based Interland, and the new company will be known as Interland. The transformed firm will be 100-percent focused on the Internet, and will become the nation's third-largest Web-hosting provider. Micron fell fractionally in trading today, but a makeover may be just what the company needs. It's stock is off 81 percent over the past year.

BAY: Just ahead, farmers worry over the spread of foot-and-mouth disease in Europe, as officials warn half of Britain's livestock could be at risk.

Plus, as the California electricity crisis grinds on, we'll check out some of the real-life victims of the power squeeze.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CHERNOFF: The outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease across the Atlantic may be getting much worse. British officials today said it may be months before the situation is under control, and scientists warned up to half of Britain's 63 million livestock may have to be slaughtered if the spread cannot be stopped.

Concerns about another animal disease reaching U.S. shores: Authorities in Texas said they would put to death 22 cows imported from Germany to test for mad cow disease.

BAY: A different kind of crisis has California in its grip: the power crunch that forced regulators to impose rolling blackouts earlier this week.

The financial impact of the crisis continues to spread. Small power generators, which mostly produce so-called green power, have not been paid by the state's nearly-bankrupt electric utilities. As a result, many face serious financial troubles of their own, and some have been forced to shut down. That is contributing to blackouts and even shortchanging schools.

Casey Wian has the story from Imperial County, California.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

CASEY WIAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): It's career day at Calipatria High School.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: So you work with your mind and you work with your body.

WIAN: Students pay close attention. They know jobs here are scarce. Imperial County, located inland along the Mexican border, is by most measures California's poorest county, with unemployment exceeding 30 percent. Now the largely agricultural community faces a new threat: California's energy crisis.

The Calipatria school district gets 72 percent of its revenue from the property taxes of a single company, geothermal power producer, CalEnergy. And the company says this time it doesn't have the money to pay, nearly $4 million due April 10th. That's because CalEnergy hasn't been paid by its biggest customer, Southern California Edison, in nearly five months.

Calipatria High is in the midst of a rebuilding program. Its classrooms have structural problems, so students will soon move into these temporary portable classrooms -- and these even older rooms. But uncertainty over tax revenue is jeopardizing the county's ability to pay for improvements.

JIM HANKS, CALIPATRIA UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT: Long-term, as far as property bonds for new facilities that were in planning stages and preparing for is put on hold. And it could have a major impact, not only on the facilities, but also on the students' education.

WIAN: CalEnergy's local suppliers, such as welding contractor Jason Turner, are also suffering because the company is delaying their payments.

JASON TURNER, PERFORMANCE MECHANICAL CONTRACTORS: We were once considered a stable company, now we're living pretty much week-to- week, struggling to meet the payroll.

WIAN: Southern California Edison owes CalEnergy $140 million for electricity supplied since November, says CalEnergy's parent company.

DAVID SOKOL, MIDAMERICAN ENERGY HOLDINGS: We've tried to keep the lights on in California. But the reality is, Edison's getting paid every day for our power, their rates come in every day. They've accumulated now $2 billion in cash, but they haven't paid us a dime.

WIAN: While CalEnergy has continued to produce power without getting paid, several other renewable, or green, power producers have been forced to shut down. They provide 12 percent of California's power, and are owed more than a half billion dollars.

(on camera): Without the financial squeeze, renewable energy producers say they could have generated enough power to save California from this week's statewide rolling blackouts.

(voice-over): Utilities dispute that claim. Southern California Edison and PG&E both say they want to pay their creditors, but are restricted by their own financial problems. California Governor Gray Davis has announced plans to force utilities to pay renewable energy producers in advance for the power they receive in the future.

And Thursday, a judge gave CalEnergy the right to break its contract with Edison and sell power elsewhere. Its parent company has now pledged to make the property tax payment to Imperial County. But officials here, and in eight other California counties facing tax shortages from renewable energy producers, say the continuing financial uncertainty could hurt students for years. Casey Wian, CNN Financial News, Calipatria, California.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CHERNOFF: Coming up: we'll check out what all the gyrations on Wall Street have done to investor emotions.

BAY: Plus, a champion basketball coach takes the reins at a new institution. We're expecting to hear from controversial Bobby Knight, and we will bring that to you live when it happens.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Talk about Texas Tech…

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CHERNOFF: Bobby Knight, making his return to college basketball. Let's go to live right now to Lubbock, Texas, where the announcement is being made. Bobby Knight, going to Texas Tech.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Now I want to introduce -- to call to the stadium someone to introduce the newest member of the Texas Tech coaching fraternity. This is a person who needs no introduction in Lubbock, the athletic director and past basketball coach at Texas Tech, Coach Gerald Myers.

(APPLAUSE)

GERALD MYERS, TEXAS TECH ATHLETIC DIRECTOR: Hey.

(APPLAUSE)

MYERS: Thanks for being here. Hey, you're awesome to be here for this great turnout. This is awesome.

Sometime you have a chance to be involved in something that's really special, and this is one of those occasions. This is the beginning of something that's going to be really special for Texas Tech and for Texas Tech basketball.

(APPLAUSE)

MYERS: Bob Knight is a guy I've known for a long time. He's been a great friend. He's a guy that I have admired as a coach and a person. And with him here today is his wife, Karen, and his two sons, Tim and Pat. Tim and Pat, would you stand!

(APPLAUSE)

MYERS: All of you know -- all of you know a lot about Coach Knight as a basketball coach. But you're going to get to know him as a person, as a member of this community, that you will really enjoy. And it's my privilege, my honor, and I am most pleased to introduce our new coach, Bob Knight.

(APPLAUSE)

BOBBY KNIGHT, HEAD BASKETBALL COACH, TEXAS TECH: OK, thanks.

(APPLAUSE)

KNIGHT: OK.

MYERS: This is not the time for sweaters, so we got him a sweater vest for a substitute. But he'll have a red sweater.

Coach, I want to present this to you from -- in the Texas Tech colors, a sweater vest. But he'll be in a vest eventually.

(APPLAUSE)

KNIGHT: All right, coach.

KNIGHT: This…

(APPLAUSE)

KNIGHT: This is without question the most comfortable red sweater I've had on in 6 years. I can't tell you.

(APPLAUSE)

KNIGHT: I can't tell you how good this one feels.

Now, I got a couple things I want to ask. Now, how much of you guys over here -- where was our bench, Gerald, when we played here? Right down on this end. Now, how of you guys wore those camouflaged outfits when I came out on the floor?

(APPLAUSE)

KNIGHT: Now, I want all the camouflaged guys with the hunting caps and everything that night we played here a couple years ago -- I want you all to stand up. Wherever you are, I want you to stand.

BAY: Bobby Knight there, all dressed in red as the new head coach of the Red Raiders at Texas Tech.

And on Monday night Bobby Knight will be our guest on "LARRY KING LIVE."

ANNOUNCER: This is MONEYLINE.

BAY: In tonight's headlines, for the first Friday this year, both the Dow and Nasdaq end the day in the plus column, capping a week of extreme market turbulence. But despite today's run-up, the Dow finished the week solidly in the red.

The market downturn has many investors struggling to cope with their stress. We'll take a look at the psychology behind dealing with a down market.

And in tonight's Oscars Inc, the fate of movie theater chains: bankruptcy, consolidation, and major technical upgrades. We'll take a look at this industry in motion.

CHERNOFF: But first, more on the positive day for the markets. Leading the indices higher, buying interest in financials and technology. This is only the second Friday the Dow has finished higher so far this year.

The index hit a couple of rough spots during the session, falling back into bear market territory. But ultimately, the Dow closed up 115 points, at 9504. The S&P 500 spent the session in positive territory, finishing up 22 points at 1139. For the second day in a row, the Nasdaq finished in the plus column, up nearly 31 points at 1928.

Let's check out some of the big movers on the day,

On the up side, Advanced Micro Devices, Microsoft, GE, all tacking on more than two. But JDS Uniphase lost 2 1/4 and Cisco fell more than one.

Big tech stocks had a strong session, with gains in chips, software, and computer stocks. But most market watchers say tech stocks can't fully recover until their earnings do.

Bruce Francis has the story on the outlook for techs.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BRUCE FRANCIS, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): The bottom for tech stocks has been hard to spot. And it will remain elusive, analysts say, until tech earnings stop their decline and turn around.

ASHOK KUMAR, US BANCORPPIPER JAFFREY: There is increased possibility that instead of recovery in the second half of this year, we could be looking into a recession. And if that's the case, we have not seen the worst of the stock market.

FRANCIS: The tech earnings outlook continues to get dimmer. According the first call, tech company preannouncements are running 77 percent ahead of the fourth quarter's record-setting pace. And 81 percent of those preannouncements are negative, also a record.

Those warnings are cutting deep in projections. Originally, analysts expected first-quarter tech earnings to increase 4 percent. Now they're expecting a huge 32-percent decline. For the second quarter, projections for a 2 percent increase have turned into a 30- percent decline. For the third quarter, an 11-percent increase has turned into an 18-percent decrease. And it gets worse.

CHUCK HILL, FIRST CALL/THOMSON FINANCIAL: In the last two weeks, it's spilled over into the fourth quarter. Just in a couple weeks, we've gone from 15 percent growth expected in the fourth quarter, down to 6. FRANCIS: With timid consumers and corporations, and tapped-out telecoms and dot-coms, tech spending is in the doldrums.

HILL: So whether the Fed does a half a point or three quarters of a point, is immaterial to these kind of problems.

FRANCIS: Another layer of concern for tech companies: the strong dollar, which makes high-tech exports pricey, just where tech companies are looking for growth.

KUMAR: For a company such as Intel and Compaq and Dell -- a lot of the large IT companies -- they get over 60 percent of their revenue from the international market. So Europe represents 40 percent of their revenue. And then Japan and Asia-Pacifics, all those currencies are weak against the dollar.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

FRANCIS: Now, when it comes to Intel, Kumar doesn't think the chip giant will again reach its 1999 revenue levels until 2003.

That's a long, rough road back.

CHERNOFF: Certainly is. Bruce Francis, thank you -- Willow.

BAY: Allan, coming up on MONEYLINE: we'll talk to one market watcher who says you can blame all this volatility on one man.

Plus, turbulent stocks have many investors coping with stress. We'll take a look at the psychology of a bear market.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CHERNOFF: The stock market's plunge in recent weeks is causing stress for many investors, so much so that many have been seeking counseling from psychotherapists. The anxiety is evident in almost any discussion about the stock market.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I'm nervous about the market. I'm nervous with interests rates dropping and stock market still dropping.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: There is definitely a worry when you see it going in red for so long. And you know, who would have thought that it would have dropped over 60 percent.

CHERNOFF (voice-over): Emotions are raw for many investors, who have watched their portfolios rapidly shrink in value.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I just retired from teaching in May, and my pension is based on mutual funds, and mutual funds are down, I believe, right now, about 60 percent.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm very uncomfortable but I'm trying to be patent. CHERNOFF: It's a withdrawal from an addiction to fast money, argues Dr. Barry Lubetkin, a Manhattan psychologist who says clients are complaining more about the stock market than at any point in his 30-year career.

DR. BARRY LUBETKIN, INSTITUTE FOR BEHAVIOR THERAPY: They're frightened. They're uncomfortable. They're confused.

CHERNOFF: Lubetkin describes a four-stage mourning process which he believes investors are suffering through. First: denial, refusing to believe that one's stocks can keep falling. Second: anger, with investment advisers and with one's self for not selling. Then, depression, and finally, acceptance.

LUBETKIN: Most of the people right now are at somewhere between the denial and the anger stage. They're angry because they feel that they've been ill-advised, but at the same time, many of them are denying that we really are in a bear market.

Some are beginning to move into the depression stage. I've had several patients who've come to me who've said that they really feel that they really need antidepressant medication, because they're obsessing about their losses.

CHERNOFF: Other psychologists report their clients are further along, having reached the final acceptance stage.

DR. RICHARD GEIST, PRESIDENT, INSTITUTE OF PSYCHOLOGY AND INVESTING: People at this point are in that state of feeling, I don't care anymore, and that usually corresponds with a bottom in the market.

CHERNOFF: Markets are a function of group psychology, and strategists agree, when investor emotion falls to the acceptance stage, they argue it's usually a positive sign for stocks, because the worst of the selling has already occurred.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CHERNOFF: Psychologist Robert Leahy is telling his clients in Manhattan to put it all in perspective, thinking of your life in balance -- meaningful work, good friendships, health, and stock holdings, Dr. Leahy says, are only one part of it -- Willow.

BAY: Allan, we'll try to remember that. Balance.

With more on the outlook for stocks and how to deal with these wild markets, we turn to Scott Black, he's the president of Delphi Management, in tonight's "MONEYLINE Focus."

Scott, welcome back to MONEYLINE.

SCOTT BLACK, PRESIDENT, DELPHI MANAGEMENT: Thank you, Willow.

BAY: Investors today seem to believe that the rally that began yesterday was somewhat convincing. How convincing do you think it was?

BLACK: I'm not a technician, but I don't think it's convincing. Because the fact is that the stock market is not uncoupled from the economy.

I'd like to say this first: the Alan Greenspan moved too little. Instead of 50 basis points, he really should have given us the psychological boost of 75 basis points.

And also, we need fiscal stimulus in a hurry. In every recession since 1946, the consumer has led the way out. And so, what we need is a 1962 John F. Kennedy type of tax cut that hits the middle and low middle class immediately with disposable income. And until these types of things eventuate, I don't see corporate earnings and the economy coming back too quickly.

BAY: Given that somewhat bearish outlook, what should investors be doing here?

BLACK: Well, firstly, if they have fresh money, they may just want to sit on the sideline in cash equivalents. I always like to say it's better to be a couple of days late than to stand in front of the tidal wave.

Otherwise, you do what we try to do at Delphi, which is buy value stocks. Companies -- not the Oracles, not the Ciscos or the Dells, which are still 20 to 30 times expected earnings, but buy companies where there are good fundamentals, like energy prices, perhaps regional banks or some insurance companies, where you can buy them at seven and eight P/Es.

BAY: Give us some specific names, if you would, for example…

(CROSSTALK)

BLACK: OK, in the energy field -- OK, in the insurance company -- Meridian is selling at seven times earning, it's a municipal bond insurer. Commerce Group here in Webster, Mass. is eight times earning. IPC Holdings, which is on 24.4 percent by AIG is selling below book, it's still only 8 1/2 times earning, it's a Bermuda re- insurer.

This way, you're not going to get clobbered by fundamentals sinking quickly, and also you are not overpaying for the thrill of the game.

BAY: Scott Black, thanks for joining us. Thanks for that advice.

BLACK: Thank you.

BAY: Coming up on MONEYLINE: the bond market is getting a major boost from the recent sell-off in equities, but how long will this strength last? We'll talk bonds next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK) CHERNOFF: In tonight's "Sector Report": bonds. Treasury prices slipped today, but the bond market has been thriving, as stock prices have been in the tank. The indexes for treasuries, municipal and corporate bonds are all up this year, as investors have been scrambling for the safety of fixed income returns.

For more on the sector, we're joined by right now by Bill Sullivan, he's fixed income strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. Bill, great to see you.

WILLIAM SULLIVAN, MORGAN STANLEY DEAN WITTER: Yes, good evening, Allan.

CHERNOFF: OK, so we did see a move out of bonds today as the stock market rose. Let's say that the market keeps rising, the stock market next week. What will happen to the bond market?

SULLIVAN: Oh, that's a real challenging environment for fixed income securities, and especially treasuries. There's no doubt the bond market has benefited from a flow of funds out of equities into fixed income product for safety, liquidity and income purposes. If we get a bounce back, a convincing bounce back in the equity market, you are going to reverse that flow and there's going to be some mild upward pressures on interests rates.

CHERNOFF: Bill, how attractive are bonds right now for the individual investor? What sort of yields are we getting?

SULLIVAN: Extraordinary attractive outside the treasury area. In our retail desk, there's been particular interest from our customer base in high-grade corporates in the seven-to-10-year area. A fair range of return in that maturity sector is about 6 1/2 to 6 3/4 right now.

CHERNOFF: Which looks pretty good, compared to what the stock market has been doing.

SULLIVAN: Absolutely. There's a new focus by investors on asset allocation, risk diversification and -- hallelujah! -- capital preservation, and bonds fit the trick. We are having a record year in bonds, because of so much customer interest.

CHERNOFF: Bill, let's talk about the Fed briefly. Chairman Greenspan got a lot of heat this week. Many investors saying, the guy is behind the curve. Is he really?

SULLIVAN: Possibly yes, but keep in mind that the three rate drops totaling 150 basis rats represents aggressive accommodation in historical terms. And keep in mind, he left the window open for additional rate cuts before too long.

CHERNOFF: Three rate cuts since the beginning of the year.

SULLIVAN: Absolutely, 150 basis points in a matter of 2 1/2 months. That's an aggressive drop.

CHERNOFF: Bill Sullivan, thanks much.

SULLIVAN: Thank you.

CHERNOFF: Willow.

BAY: Coming up on "MONEYLINE," the evolution of the movie theater. Some radical changes may be on the horizon. We'll wrap up our special look at the business of Hollywood next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: All week we've been gearing up for Sunday night's Oscars by looking at the business of Hollywood. Earlier we examined a looming strike by writers. And tonight we look at another challenge: the peril facing the nation's theater chains. A digital revolution, which may leave some theater operators bruised and bloodied. But make no mistake, it's coming to a multiplex near you. Fred Katayama has the story.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

TOM HANKS, ACTOR: Anybody!

FRED KATAYAMA, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Like the Tom hanks' character in the Oscar-nominated film "Cast Away, " many theater operators are fighting to stay afloat. Several big movie exhibition chains like the parents of Loews', United Artists and General Cinemas filed for Chapter 11. They had built too many new megaplex theaters and took on too much debt as fewer people went to the cinema. They're busy closing down older theaters as they rework their finances. The stock of GC companies is down more than 90 percent from its 52-week high. So is Loews.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Since screen closures are tied to leases, you can only move as quickly as you can close down the facilities or get out of the leases, and that's kind of holding up the pace of the transition. I think it's going to take another 18 months to maybe 24, 30 months before we kind of see a light at the end of the tunnel.

KATAYAMA: Analysts say consolidation could shrink the 10 big theater operators down to five or six. Those remaining could engineer a revolution.

ANDREW LIPMAN, ENTERTAINMENT ANALYST: I think the industry is going to change more in the next five years than it's changed in the last 75.

KATAYAMA: He's referring to digitalization. Thirty theaters in the U.S. are experimenting with digital projectors. Digital copies of celluloid eliminate the hisses, pops, lines and hairs seen on film reels today. What's more, digital systems could liberate theater owners from showing not just movies, but live events, like boxing matches, Broadway shows and the Super Bowl. That would give exhibition companies new sources of revenue. Studios would use a satellite up link, as in this example, or fiber lines to transmit digitally-compressed movies to theaters. The movies are decompressed, then shown with a digital projector. The big issue: who'll pay for this? Digital projectors cost as much as $150, 000, five times the cost of current ones. Outfitting all domestic screens would cost anywhere from $3.5 billion to $5.5 billion.

(on camera): The theater operators say the studios should pay for the projectors, since they would benefit the most, saving about $1 billion a year in the cost of printing and transporting reels. The theater operators do not have the money.

(voice-over): Some analysts speculate digital cinema is a big reason telecom investors are jumping in. Gary Winnick, the founder of Global Crossing, has teamed up with other investors to buy a stake in Loews, while Philip Anschutz, the founder of Qwest Communications, has invested in UA and Regal Cinemas. Others are entering the digital scene. Transmission players like Boeing and Williams Communications and digital chip maker Texas Instruments. Last November, AMC theaters tied up with Walt Disney and TI, among others, to distribute the Miramax film "Bounce" using Boeing's satellite system. All this comes as broadband companies race to provide fast Internet connections that would allow consumers to watch digital movies on demand at home.

JOHN FITHIAN, NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF THEATRE OWNERS: When the studios release their movies, they send them to theaters first because theaters are the social experience. It's where kids can go out on a date. It's where you can hear if the person in your aisle is laughing or crying to the film and relate to your fellow human beings as you're watching a movie. We believe the movie theater experience will always stay first above entertainment experiences in the home.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP, "GLADIATOR")

RUSSELL CROWE, ACTOR: At my signal, unleash hell.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KATAYAMA: Those cinemas that survive the Darwinian battle, analysts say, could go fully digital in about five years. Fred Katayama, CNN financial news, New York.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CHERNOFF: Up next, "Ahead of the Curve." Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: Taking a look at some of what could make headlines on Wall Street next week. On Tuesday, Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan and Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill will peak to the National Association for Business Economics on the state of the economy. And more on the economy with new and existing home sales, durable goods, fourth- quarter GDP, and personal income and spending.

Plus watch for quarterly earnings from Walgreens, Palm and Micron Technology.

That is MONEYLINE for this Friday. I'm Willow Bay in Los Angeles.

CHERNOFF: And I'm Allan Chernoff. Good night from New York.

"CROSSFIRE" is next.

urn:contentItem:42NJ-T0Y0-009B-G244-00000-00Dow Climbs 182.75 to 9,687.53; Nasdaq Slides 10.19 to 1,918.49; President Bush Pushing for Tax Cuts2001-03-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:03ZLexisNexisCNN MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR 18:30Joe Lieberman, Todd Eberhard, Nathaniel CohnBusinessSHOW01032600V19Dow Climbs 182.75 to 9,687.53; Nasdaq Slides 10.19 to 1,918.49; President Bush Pushing for Tax CutsWillow Bay, Allan Chernoff, Greg Clarkin, Peter Viles, Lisa Leiter, Terry Keenan, Steve Young, Casey Wian, Myron Kandel, Susan Lisovicz

After plunging into bear market territory just days ago, the Dow has staged a remarkable comeback. Today the index jumped 182 points, or nearly 2 percent, from the session low on Thursday. The key question now for investors is, is this Dow rally for real.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

WILLOW BAY, CNN ANCHOR: The Dow pushes higher once again.

ALLAN CHERNOFF, CNN ANCHOR: This is MONEYLINE for March 26, 2001.

Another encouraging session for beaten-up blue chips. But why were tech stocks left behind?

BAY: While there's still plenty of gloom and doom, some Wall Street pros continue to be downright bullish: Are they off target?

CHERNOFF: The economic slump: a hot topic for a president determined to cut taxes.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GEORGE W. BUSH, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I believe the economy has slowed down and we better do something about it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CHERNOFF: We'll ask a Capitol Hill heavyweight what he thinks we should do about it: Senator Joseph Lieberman.

BAY: And, getting the smackdown in the battle for ratings: Will the networks K.O. XFL?

ANNOUNCER: Live from coast to coast, this MONEYLINE.

BAY: Welcome to MONEYLINE. I'm Willow Bay in Los Angeles.

CHERNOFF: Hi Willow; hi everyone. I'm Allan Chernoff in New York.

BAY: We begin tonight with the blue chip bounce on Wall Street. After plunging into bear market territory just days ago, the Dow has staged a remarkable comeback. Today the index jumped 182 points, or nearly 2 percent, from the session low on Thursday. The index has soared nearly 600 points. No rally for the Nasdaq today, which lost 10 points to end at 1,918. And the S&P was up 12 at 1,152, a gain of more than 1 percent.

CHERNOFF: The key question now for investors: Is this Dow rally for real? Over the past year, the Nasdaq has had more than its share of so-called "bear market rallies," essentially short term pops with no follow-through.

Greg Clarkin looks at whether the Dow's recent comeback is built to last.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

GREG CLARKIN, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): The news was uplifting to the bulls. Back-to-back gains for the blue chips for the first time in more than two weeks. A triple-digit rally that pumped life back into some of the casualties of the recent sell-off. But is it for real or just another false start? Investors and analysts have been scrambling to try to find an answer.

Many Wall Street pros say last week's sell-off on the Dow, which drove the blue chips into bear market territory at one point, left many Dow stocks dramatically undervalued, levels low enough to prove irresistible to buyers.

TRACY EICHLER, UBSPAINEWEBBER: What we are seeing on the Dow and the S&P today actually seems to be sideline money coming in. Where, last week we saw a short covering into the Nasdaq indices; and tonight we are hearing from our floor brokers that they are actually seeing more money coming into those indices.

CLARKIN: A look at the Dow's biggest winners shows a rebound in last week's big losers: United Technologies, Boeing, Merck, Philip Morris, and Wal-Mart all gained.

But beyond bargain hunting, analysts say there's still a long way to go before they are convinced that this rally can be sustained. The corporate profit picture needs to improve and the economy needs to rebound.

RICHARD CRIPPS, LEGG MASON: We could have a very significant rally here, 10 to 15 percent. The question of it being sustained or not is really going to have to do with the investors gaining confidence that earnings growth is going to -- is near the bottom and that it will resume at some point in the future and what that growth rate will be.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CLARKIN: As for short term indicators, Wall Street is watching the advance decline line and volume figures very closely. Now, winning stocks easily beat out losing stocks today, but the volume was considered light, and analysts say that needs to pick up if this rally is to build any kind of momentum -- Allan.

CHERNOFF: Greg, do you think that we are seeing a sentiment shift here?

CLARKIN: Nobody is willing to call that just yet. They say they want to see a shift in the fundamentals first before they jump out to there. CHERNOFF: Greg Clarkin, thank you.

Well, 25 of the Dow 30 closed higher today. In addition to the winners that Greg did mention: GM, Home Depot and IBM were all higher. But other tech blue chips, Microsoft and Intel, ended lower.

Nasdaq losers also included QLogic, PMC-Sierra -- hit following a profit warning -- Veritas Software, Dell and Apple computer.

BAY: Nearly all of those stocks are well off their highs, victims of a fierce bear market sell-off that's become headline news across the nation. But there's one pocket of America where bullish sentiment is still alive and well: Wall Street. Peter Viles reports.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

PETER VILES, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): The news media is turning out one ominous headline after another, but major Wall Street analysts are still writing a bullish story. A bit less bullish perhaps. Today J.P. Morgan's Doug Cliggott reduced his year-end fair value target for the S&P 500 from 1,400 to 1,300. But that's still a 12.8 percent gain from today's close.

Lehman's Jeff Applegate also cut his target from: 1,600 to 1,400. But that is still a gain of 21 percent. Al Goldman is also bullish in the face of bearish headlines; he sees the S&P at 1,400 at year end.

AL GOLDMAN, A.G. EDWARDS: It's positive, believe it or not, that the front page of "Time" Magazine, "U.S. News & World Report" feature articles in the "New York Times" and the local paper had nothing but great big growling bears. By the time that the media starts to cover it that extensively, usually the worst of the bear market is over.

VILES: Wall Street is still dominated by Super Bowls: Abbey Joseph Cohen of Goldman and Joe Battipaglia of Gruntal both the S&P 500 go to 1,650, a gain of 43 percent. Christine Callies of Merrill Lynch sees a 41 percent gain. Tom Galvin of C.S. First Boston, 31 percent.

But what if they are all wrong?

Bill Fleckenstein doesn't make predictions, but he says that the S&P could easily revisit its 1997 lows in the 700s; regardless of what major strategists predict.

BILL FLECKENSTEIN, FLECKENSTEIN CAPITAL: I think that you can expect Wall Street to kind of ride it out and be wrong. I have been in the business for 20 years and I can only remember one time when the majority of Wall Street analysts were bearish and it was at the lows in 1984, they were all bearish just before the market turned.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VILES: Fleckenstein's argument is simple. S&P 500 valuations, at 22 times last years's earnings, are still well above the levels typically seen during the bear markets. And it is quite possible that earnings will fall this year.

CHERNOFF: But a lot of those bulls don't seem very concerned. Peter Viles, thank you.

Aside from tech profit concerns, investors today were also assessing the latest economic news; this time from the housing market. Sales of both new and previously-owned homes declined in February. Fewer buyers were willing to step up in the face of an ailing economy and a swooning stock market. Lisa Leiter reports from Chicago.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

LISA LEITER, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Last year, business was never better for realtor Elizabeth Ballis. Strong demand and short supply of homes on the market. What a difference six months makes.
