CHERNOFF: Coming up on MONEYLINE, a two-day rally for the Dow. Can the rebound continue? Some market perspective from CNN's financial editor Myron Kandel and from money manager Todd Eberhard. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CHERNOFF: Can the Dow maintain it's upward momentum? Joining me now, CNN's financial editor Myron Kandel, and Todd Eberhard, president of Eberhard Investment Associates.

Myron, what are you saying? To keep on moving on the Dow?

MYRON KANDEL, CNNFN FINANCIAL EDITOR: Oh, yes. You know, Thursday when the Dow hit its low, I said, that was it.

CHERNOFF: Down 380 points.

KANDEL: OK. And since then, to today's close, the Dow is up 6.3 percent just over two days. That's a major rally. Obviously, it's not going to go straight up. But I disagree with Todd just a bit. He said we may have hit a low, may be not the low. I think it's the low.

CHERNOFF: Calling an absolute bottom there. KANDEL: Right.

CHERNOFF: Very gutsy. Todd, what do you say?

TODD EBERHARD, EBERHARD INVESTMENT ASSOCIATES: I like the way that you looked at me. I hope that you are right; I would love to sit on your camp and say that it was the low. We could test it again, unfortunately. I hope that we do not. The rally this fast back is sometimes indicative, at least in the last year of a quick sell-off and I hope that that doesn't happen. But I do think you should start getting involved, as I said.

KANDEL: 580 points. We have a bit of room to test the low without getting down that far. I think that obviously we'll do a little testing but we won't go anywhere near where we were last Thursday.

CHERNOFF: Now Myron, you realize that a lot of the pros on Wall Street are saying that it could suffer more damage. And the Nasdaq has been looking more strong and the Nasdaq, mainly, that's higher, the Down may be dragging down.

KANDEL: I disagree. I think that the Dow goes higher and Nasdaq trails along.

CHERNOFF: Because people are looking for safer stocks? Trying to stay away from a lot of the big tech names?

KANDEL: I think that they got really battered in those big tech names and they will come back, but not all at once. They will do better in the Dow.

CHERNOFF: Todd, safer to go through the PMG, for example?

EBERHARD: That's one we talked about a long time ago. It held up well; got beaten up on some earnings; has still held up dramatically well over a lot of the Nasdaq's positions. But it's one of those things where I have to think that the people on Wall Street; a lot of pros are correct. The Nasdaq got so beaten up and we saw a hold there where the Dow got beaten up. I think we'll see a rebound. And the percentage terms that the Nasdaq is easier to go up more because it's so low.

KANDEL: Nasdaq will go up definitely, but I think the Dow will lead the way in the immediate future.

CHERNOFF: Well, I think that on your side, Myron, is the fact that you have a contrarian view, the majority of strategists on the Street are saying just the opposite of what you are saying. So, probably a check in your column.

KANDEL: I like to be in that camp.

CHERNOFF: Myron, thank you very much. Todd, I appreciate it.

EBERHARD: Thank you. CHERNOFF: Willow.

BAY: Up next, what is the future of the XFL? We'll go behind the ratings drop.

Plus, "ahead of the curve" -- some of what you need to know tonight, ahead of tomorrow's trading. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: The league that was supposed to shake up a football-crazed country may soon be smacked down. The head of NBC Sports reportedly warned the much heralded XFL will have to bring in more viewers to get another shot beyond this season. Susan Lisovicz has the story.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SUSAN LISOVICZ, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): If you hype it, they will come. And viewers did, for the first XFL game, which organizers said would revolutionize football.

But despite microphones in players' helmets, and cameras in cheerleaders' locker rooms, ratings for the World Wrestling Federation's offshoot into football have plunged 80 percent since, prompting NBC Sports chief Dick Ebersol to tell the "Washington Post" "evidence through the regular season was not promising for renewal." NBC put up half of the $100 million in launch costs and originally said it was committed to two years.

STEPHEN BATTAGLIO, INSIDE.COM: It doesn't deliver on either level, in terms of sports or entertainment. The WWF and Vince McMahon promised they would do an old-fashioned, smash mouth type of football. You also thought that there would be stories developed; the way that they do on wrestling programs. The big difference is that you don't know the outcome is the way you do on wrestling shows.

LISOVICZ: The most recent weekend measured by Nielsen shows seven NCAA basketball games, some of them daytime programs, finishing ahead of NBC's prime time XFL broadcast, which ranked 10th.

NEAL PILSON, PILSON COMMUNICATIONS: I think they are going to think about Saturday afternoons to the extent they can fit in games. I think they may have to think about PAX, which they control as another over the air network, they may have to move some of the games to their cable affiliates.

LISOVICZ: The WWF calls the XFL a work in progress.

LINDA MCMAHON, CEO, WORLD WRESTLING FEDERATION: As we look forward to the end of this season, we think some of the changes to the play that we've instituted are being met with good feedback from our fans.

LISOVICZ: The most telling feedback right now: the continuous erosion in XFL's ratings.

Susan Lisovicz, CNN financial news, New York.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CHERNOFF: Willow, there's no doubt that there's a season for every sport and right now it's basketball season.

(LAUGHTER

BAY: Amen, Allan!

That's MONEYLINE for this Monday. I'm Willow Bay in Los Angeles.

CHERNOFF: And I'm Allan Chernoff. Good night from New York. "CROSSFIRE" is next.

urn:contentItem:493H-4H60-009B-G0H0-00000-00Dow Declines 113.74 to 10,977.00; Nasdaq Tumbles 48.90 to 2,215.10; President Prepares for His First Overseas Trip2001-06-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:03ZLexisNexisLOU DOBBS MONEYLINE 18:30Richard Grasso, Ned Riley, Hugh Johnson, Ray HartBusinessSHOW060800CN.V19Dow Declines 113.74 to 10,977.00; Nasdaq Tumbles 48.90 to 2,215.10; President Prepares for His First Overseas TripLou Dobbs, Tim O'Brien, Peter Viles, Jan Hopkins, Bruce Francis, Lucia Newman, Fred Katayama, Lisa Leiter, Steve Young

A technical breakdown Friday shut down the world's largest equities exchange for more than an hour. The New York Stock Exchange confusion rattled many investors already contending with quarterly warnings from big tech companies, including Juniper, 3Com and Handspring. Prices ended the session sharply lower.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

LOU DOBBS, CNN ANCHOR: Tonight, the president prepares for his first overseas trip, seeking support for his missile defense plan.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GEORGE W. BUSH, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We must have the capacity to shoot that missile down.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: On Wall Street, not just one opening bell…

(BELL RINGING)

DOBBS: … but two. The big board halts trading for more than an hour after a high-tech breakdown. The shutdown and warnings from high-tech companies combine to send stock prices tumbling.

And in Cuba, American business gathers, preparing for the lifting of the U.S. trade embargo. We'll go live to Havana.

ANNOUNCER: Live, from the heart of New York City, this is LOU DOBBS MONEYLINE. Here now, Lou Dobbs.

DOBBS: Good evening.

A chaotic session on Wall Street -- a technical breakdown shuts the world's largest equities exchange for more than an hour. The New York Stock Exchange confusion rattled many investors already contending with quarterly warnings from big tech companies, including Juniper, 3Com, and Handspring. And prices ended the session sharply lower. We'll have much more on the market retreat and the big board breakdown.

But first, President Bush prepares for his first trip across the Atlantic as commander in chief. President Bush saying that he will use his European trip to press for a fundamental rethinking of western defense strategy in the Post-Cold War world.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BUSH: Our United States and our allies ought to develop the capacity to address the true threats of the 21st century. The true threats are biological and informational warfare. The true threats are the fact that some rogue nations who can't stand America, our allies or our freedoms or our successes, will try to point a missile at us, and we must have the capacity to shoot that missile down.

DOBBS: And ahead of the president's trip, Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld met with NATO officials in Brussels, looking to sell that missile defense plan. Rumsfeld used satellite photos, videotape and other intelligence materials to argue that emerging threats from Libya, North Korea and other nations require abandoning the 29-year- old Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty. It will be a tough sell, with some NATO officials concerned that the missile shield would set off a new arms race.

And Russian Defense Minister Sergei Ivanov, who also met with Rumsfeld today, said the alleged threat to the United States from long-range missiles is "entirely hypothetical." Tim O'Brien has more from Washington now on the challenges facing the president on his inaugural European trip.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

TIM O'BRIEN, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): The trip is much more than merely an opportunity for President Bush to take the measure of his European counterparts. He'll be expected to have answers to difficult questions on a wide range of issues, like his proposed missile shield. Europeans are not persuaded it is needed, or that it would work, or that the time is right to walk away from the ABM Treaty the U.S. signed in 1972.

JONATHAN CLARKE, CATO INSTITUTE: So they'll be saying to the president, can have a few years before going to that next stage.

O'BRIEN (on camera): And what if the president says no?

CLARKE: Well, then there will be some blood on the floor.

O'BRIEN (voice-over): The president will have his first meeting with Russian President Putin, who has publicly taken issue with missile shield idea. With nearly $2 1/2 trillion going back and forth across the Atlantic each year, trade is also a huge issue, and the European Union also has differences with the United States.

FRANK VARGO, NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF MANUFACTURERS: The United States wants to sell something, you say, "new, improved." In Europe that's not the way you sell things, so they're much more suspicious about genetically modified grains and things like this.

O'BRIEN: In the aftermath of Mad Cow Disease, Europeans are particularly suspicious of growth hormones in American beef. The president's efforts aimed at imposing new barriers on steel imports, although helpful to the ailing U.S. steel industry, are also certain to be challenged. Europeans are also angry over President Bush's rejection of the 1997 Kyoto protocol on global warming. The U.S., with only 5 percent of the world's population, is by some estimates, responsible for more than 25 percent of the pollution that leads to global warming.

IVO DAADLER, BROOKINGS INSTITUTION: The president has now said that this is a problem. The Europeans are going to ask, OK, what are you going to do about it?

(END VIDEOTAPE)

O'BRIEN: Mr. Bush is all but certain to face stiff opposition to much of what he has come to represent. As the new American president tries to reassure and to persuade, the other 18 heads of state will also be taking the measure of the man -- Lou?

DOBBS: Tim, in terms of the national missile defense system, there is really very little that Putin or any of the other heads of state can do about it, should the United States want to move ahead. Is that not correct?

O'BRIEN: That is correct, and that's why there's a great deal of concern that the president negotiate with these foreign leaders. Right now the negotiations are there, the consultation is there, but there is still a great deal of concern that the president may still choose to act unilaterally.

DOBBS: And I think it might be good if pointed out on this as well, Tim, that the Senate also made it clear it would not ratify the Kyoto Treaty, even had Mr. Bush or for that matter, Mr. Clinton decided to support it.

O'BRIEN: There's a great deal of problems with the Kyoto Treaty and global warming. In fact, 25 percent of the pollution that leads to global warming, as we've seen, has been attributed to the United States. So there's a big issue there. What will the United States do about it? What is the president's answer? Right now, it's wait and see.

DOBBS: OK, Tim, thank you very much. Tim O'Brien reporting from the White House.

Well, another issue making headlines across the Atlantic tonight: the future of the British pound sterling, falling to 15-year lows against the dollar. That, after the Labour Party pulled off another landslide victory in the British election. The markets are betting that the Labour government will opt to join the Euro currency and peg the pound sterling to the Euro at a weaker exchange rate. The pound closed today at $1.38 in New York trading.

Back in Washington, the White House today announced plans to name Tennessee banker Susan Bies to fill one of the vacancies on the Federal Reserve board of governors. Bies is now an executive at First Tennessee National. She's worked there since 1979. She holds a doctorate in economics from Northwestern. She's taught economics at Wayne State University and once served as economist at the St. Louis Fed. She would be the only woman on the Fed board, as well as the only person with real-life banking experience. There are currently two vacancies on the Fed, and longtime Governor Edward Kelley recently announced his plans to retire.

Coming up next on MONEYLINE, the New York Stock Exchange breaks down for the first time in years. We'll ask the chairman and the chief executive officer of the New York Stock Exchange what went wrong and why.

Dick Grasso joins us. An American business gathered in a nation where they're not allowed to do business. We'll have a live report from Havana, Cuba.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: Well, for more now on today's breakdown at the New York Stock Exchange, the trouble began at the opening bell. A botched software upgrade corrupted trading at about half the big board's more than 3,000 stocks, and it 10:10 a.m. Eastern, the New York Exchange decided to halt all trading. It's the first shutdown in nearly three years. Trading resumed at about 11:35, but some stocks didn't trade until late in the session.

Peter Viles has our report -- Pete.

PETER VILES, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Lou, an embarrassing day for the New York Stock Exchange. All 3,500 of the stocks that trade here -- all shut down, halted for more than an hour. And all because of a software problem, a computer problem that was self-inflicted.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

VILES (voice-over): An eerie scene -- trading halted at the New York Stock Exchange. The Exchange opened on schedule at 9:30 this morning, but hundreds of stocks did not. At 10:10, the Exchange shut down all trading, Twenty minutes later, Chairman Richard Grasso explained the decision.

RICHARD GRASSO, CHAIRMAN & CEO, NYSE: Half our floor was operating seamlessly and as smooth as any typical day. The other half of our floor was not receiving our electronic traffic, and we felt it was important for us to interrupt the entire market.

VILES: The glitch came from the overnight installation of new software, which caused problems at eight of the exchange's trading posts, and put traders in the dark.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We, effectively, were out of business on New York issues that we wanted to participate in.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: There was basically no information, so a lot of upset traders. A lot of very upset traders.

VILES: After 85 minutes, trading resumed at 11:35, a rare second opening bell of the day. But even then, there were glitches. About 10 percent of the exchange's stocks did not trade until midafternoon.

GRASSO: We will spend the balance of this weekend, and well into next week, diagnosing, as my partner just said, what the problem was, where we, in our fault recovery processes, did not meet our zero- tolerance measure for uptime, and we will make the changes necessary.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VILES: Among the traders we talked to today, a fair amount of sympathy for the exchange. Traders pointing out, as you did, Lou, that this has not happened in three years; there hasn't been a shutdown in three years, and the last one lasted only an hour. Traders also pointed out that if you work with large computer systems, and most of us do, you're aware that even the best computer systems occasionally do have a glitch and do go off-line, however briefly -- Lou.

DOBBS: And when you're handling the kind of volume as the Big Board is, it's really remarkable that it doesn't happen more often, I think.

Seven hundred and sixty million shares -- that obviously, Pete, affected volume today.

VILES: Sure, volume on average runs around 1 billion, 2, a day. In some issues, a very dramatic drop-off. IBM traded about 6 million shares yesterday, traded less than 3 million shares today -- Lou.

DOBBS: All right, Pete, thanks very much. Peter Viles from Wall Street.

Well, the Big Board promotes itself as an exchange keeping up with the digital world. The commercials they put out have a futuristic look, and mention the $2 billion dollars invested in technology. And they end with the tagline: "The world puts its stock in us." Today the claims of reliability and high-tech prowess put to the test.

Joining us from the New York Stock Exchange, it's chairman and chief executive officer Richard Grasso.

Dick, I know this has to be a tough day for you. This software that you put in, whose software was it?

GRASSO: Well, Lou, first thank you for inviting me.

The software really is self-engineered. The change that we made overnight, and I think it's important, Lou, for your viewers to understand that over the last three years we've had 1,000 systems releases into our network.

Last night we released a new program into half our systemic capacity, it failed. What also failed, unfortunately, is our ability to recover without having to interrupt the marketplace…

DOBBS: Were you…

GRASSO: … the software though, Lou, I think it's fair to say, is basically the stock exchange's software. It's not any one vendor that's responsible for this.

DOBBS: You had to shut down trading for roughly an hour and 20 minutes. You made that decision, as I understand it, because the retail side -- small investors, individual investors, would have been at a disadvantage. Is that correct?

GRASSO: That's correct, Lou. The network delivers, about 90 percent of our orders to the trading floor, and a very, very high percentage of those orders are small investor orders. It's important to remember that half our floor was operating, business as usual and, in fact, the other half, which was suffering under that faulty software release that we put in overnight could, indeed, have continued to trade with alternative delivery, but…

DOBBS: Dick, let me ask you -- I know your people are working over the weekend…

GRASSO: They are.

DOBBS: … and into next week. You're highly confident that this problem is going to be solved by the opening of trading Monday?

GRASSO: Lou, the public customer comes first. We must protect their interests. The small order was not being delivered. We reverted back to the old system.

By the opening of trading on Monday, we will basically be back to the same reliable system that didn't have a minute's worth of down- time in the last three years.

DOBBS: Dick, thanks for joining us, Dick Grasso at the end of what has been a very tough day, particularly for the chairman of the Big Board. Thanks.

GRASSO: Thanks for having me Lou.

DOBBS: The Big Board breakdown buffeted investors on a day when they didn't need much turbulence. Several technology companies over the past 24 hours have reported warnings on sales, profits, or both, and that helped send the Nasdaq down today more than 2 percent. The Dow broadly lower; all but five of the Dow 30 ending lower.

Jan Hopkins has our report from the New York Stock Exchange.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JAN HOPKINS, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): One trader said the computer glitch that paralyzed the New York Stock Exchange, quote, "took us all out of our game today," end quote.

Frustration pushed many other trading rooms to the sidelines, resulting in the lightest volume on the New York Stock Exchange so far this year.

MICHAEL MURPHY, FIRST UNION SECURITIES: We were here trading listed stocks, if need be. No one came and asked us to do so. And there are other places where, if people needed to get things done, they probably could, and I didn't see people trying to access those markets, so I think it was a quiet day, and there was no panicking out there, and just another reason for someone to go home early, I think.

HOPKINS: The Dow Industrials tumbled 113 points to close at 10,997, just 13 points below where the index began the week. Honeywell, JP Morgan Chase, Hewlett-Packard, United Technologies and Boeing led the decline.

The Nasdaq Composite slipped 48 points to 2,215 on the fourth- lightest volume of the year. But the Nasdaq ended the week with a 3 percent gain. Friday's warning from networking equipmentmaker Juniper Networks sent shivers through the tech sector, highlighting a tug-of- war that's been raging all week.

BILL BURKE, ROBERTSON STEPHENS: You have the bullish camp of people who think the worst is behind us -- doesn't mean that things are going to turn around over the next three to six months, but the worst might be behind. And then obviously you have deteriorating fundamentals, still, with certain stocks, and that's the bearish camp.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HOPKINS: Investors looking for a more stable market may have to wait until we're finished with the earnings preannouncement period. Until then, analysts say, expect more choppiness ahead -- Lou.

DOBBS: Jan, this had to be quite a day down at the Big Board. How did people feel as they were walking out to begin their weekends after all of the down market and a closed market?

HOPKINS: Well, it was kind of a mixed picture. Some were sympathetic to the exchange's problems, and others were angry that business was really interrupted during the day -- Lou.

DOBBS: All right, Jan, thank you very much -- Jan Hopkins.

Will, just ahead, a cable TV kingpin parts ways with a software powerhouse: the story behind what scrambled the deal between AT&T and Microsoft. And a new challenge to making money providing service to the Internet: entrepreneurs who promise wireless Web access, and the price is zero. Also, cold weather in the Midwest has put farmers in a bind: the financial impact of unusually cold weather in the Midwest next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: Just as the cable TV industry prepares for a major trade show in Chicago next week, a potential rift exposed between two big players. AT&T has decided not to deploy the next generation of software that Microsoft is scrambling to develop.

Bruce Francis has the story.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BRUCE FRANCIS, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Microsoft's biggest cable customer is zapping the software giant's cable TV software. AT&T says it will now use an earlier version of interactive TV services based on existing cable boxes. That will indefinitely delay the deployment of software by Microsoft, which invested $5 billion in AT&T just over two years ago.

Microsoft's cable TV software has been plagued by delays, and a list of features.

RICHARD DOHERTY, THE ENVISIONEERING GROUP: It is a big blow to Microsoft's schedule, because they had been showing some wonderful features of Microsoft TV, that third parties are going to take advantage of, of TV commerce, of news links, of Web links, and all this developer efforts right now have go to a plan B, or a plan C.

FRANCIS: AT&T says consumer trials led them to choose the scaled-down system, but some experts believe tight capital played a role as well. In addition to standard cable TV, AT&T's upgraded system looks like this. Customers will be able to get a limited version of video on demand and e-mail and Web access via a phone connection.

But lightning fast connections to Web, via a cable modem and the next generation services that go with it will have to wait. That is a potential boon for Liberate, whose software is being used by AT&T in its successful trial.

TODD RAKER, CS FIRST BOSTON: I think that this is just kind of a public confirmation that the Microsoft solution has not worked, so I view this as a positive development for Liberate.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

FRANCIS: And it is not just cable infrastructure that is giving Microsoft a hard time. Lately, cable programming has been a challenge, too. CEO Steve Ballmer recently said that if he had to do it all over again, he would not have invested in cable channel MSNBC -- Lou.

DOBBS: That would have made a lot of lives simpler, wouldn't it?

FRANCIS: Certainly would have, sir.

urn:contentItem:4945-NC60-009B-G4HW-00000-00Dow Declines to 8,801.53; Nasdaq Advances to 1,374.432002-07-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:03ZLexisNexisCNN LOU DOBBS MONEYLINE 18:00Bill Tauzin, William Cohen, Edward AbingtonBusinessSHOW071100CN.V19Dow Declines to 8,801.53; Nasdaq Advances to 1,374.43Jan Hopkins, John King, Tim O'Brien, Kitty Pilgrim, Kelli Arena, Brent Sadler, Greg Clarkin, Kathleen Hays, Peter Viles, Casey Wian, Paul Begala, Robert Novak

The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined today to 8,801.53, losing 11.97 on the day. The Nasdaq composite advanced to 1,374.43, gaining 28.42 on the session.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

JAN HOPKINS, GUEST HOST: Tonight, the most specific information yet about a possible terrorist threat inside the United States. Al Qaeda suspects are being tracked in big cities all over the country.

Isolated and under siege, Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat insists he can still do business with President Bush. We'll hear why Arafat says he's a vital part of the peace process.

WorldCom moves closer to bankruptcy. The biggest ever. Congress timely sees the company's books. Tonight, the man leading that investigation, Congressman Billy Tauzin, is our guest.

The market (UNINTELLIGIBLE) is back, but the worry remained. Tonight, the fallout from the first big scandals rocking Wall Street in an era of mass stock ownership.

And the scorching heat in California is sparking fears of more rolling blackouts this summer. What, if anything, is being done to prevent another energy crisis?

ANNOUNCER: This is Lou Dobbs' MONEYLINE for Thursday, July 11. Sitting in for Lou Dobbs, Jan Hopkins.

HOPKINS: Good evening.

We begin tonight with a White House, once again, defending the president for his business dealings. This time, President Bush is under fire for accepting more than $180,000 in loans, loans he received when he sat on the board of Harken Energy. It's just this kind of deal that the president criticized two days ago.

Democrats tonight are accusing the president of hypocrisy.

John King has a report.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JOHN KING, CNN SENIOR WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): President Bush once benefited from a practice he now says should be illegal because of concerns about corporate corruption.

Back in 1986 and 1988, Mr. Bush received two low-interest loans from Harken Energy. Mr. Bush was a company director at the time and used loans totaling more than $180,000 to buy 105,000 shares of Harken stock. Such loans are legal and not uncommon, were reported to federal regulators, and repaid by Mr. Bush back in 1993.

But the president now says such insider loans should be illegal because he believes the scandals at Enron and WorldCom show the practice is being abused.

ARI FLEISCHER, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: More than 10 years ago, this was a common practice, and, in this case, the president did everything he was supposed to do with your loans, reinvest it in the company so your company can grow, disclose it publicly, a far cry from what's happened today.

KING: Democrats see it as hypocrisy.

REP. DICK GEPHARDT (D), HOUSE MINORITY LEADER: It is hard to lead when you haven't done the things that you're asking others to do.

KING; Democrats see political gain in a corporate corruption debate that reminds voters both the president and vice president are former CEOs and suggest the president's party is too cozy with big business.

PETER HART, DEMOCRATIC POLLSTER: This is one issue that seems to galvanize Democrats and also forces Republicans to be able to take on the special interests which they have been helping for the last several years.

KING: Republicans say the president's popularity now is more important than anything in his business past.

BILL MCINTURFF, REPUBLICAN POLLSTER: People in the country aren't saying, "Oh, my gosh. The president filed a late SEC report, and the president used to own a company, and the president this." What they're saying is, "What's he going to do to fix it?" This is a country that is really tired of people in Washington fixing blame.

KING: Wall Street's reaction worries the White House much more than any criticism from the Democrats.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

KING: And that late rally on Wall Street today offered some solace to the White House. But the Dow Jones Industrial Average still off a little more than 6 percent since the president traveled to Wall Street earlier this week.

That speech was designed to calm investor jitters. The biggest worry here at the White House is that, if the markets don't rebound, investor anxiety becomes voter anxiety, and the president's party suffers come November -- Jan.

HOPKINS: John, do you think the president surprised by all of the reporting on his past dealings with getting corporate loans after he took this on as an issue in that speech earlier this week?

KING: Well, the White House insists they are not surprised, and if the president is not surprised, then his top aides are not surprised by all these questions, Jan.

They have been but caught a little bit off guard, if you will, to the questions of will the president release the entire SEC file, ask the SEC to do that, as some Democrats have charged.

So they say, no, but their reaction sometimes to the questions suggests maybe a little bit.

HOPKINS: And in terms of the markets, is the White House starting to get concerned about its effect on the economy?

KING: Well, it certainly is, and the White House argument would be this, that you cannot expect one speech from the president to cause a market rebound. They hope, over time, a psychology sets in that the president is serious about this, the Congress is serious about this, and that new reform steps will be taken.

The White House says, you know, the markets were having trouble before the speech, the markets are having trouble after September 11, there are other factors at stake here, but make no mistake about it they know that it's the president's own personal standing in the polls and the Republican Party's chances this November have a lot to do with how voters take a look at the economy and whether the president is doing anything about it.

HOPKINS: Thanks very much.

John King at the White House.

The corporate ethics debate took center stage in the Senate today. One senator after another sought to amend the so-called Sarbanes bill, while others called for an immediate vote.

Tim O'Brien has our story.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

TIM O'BRIEN, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Senators have already agreed the Securities and Exchange Commission will get more money and more power.

But still not enough under current proposals to satisfy Senator Carl Levin. The Michigan Democrat proposed giving the commission the authority to impose large civil fines without first having to go to court.

SEN. CARL LEVIN (D), MICHIGAN: They are not in a position then to do what other enforcement agencies can do in the face -- in the face -- of some of the worst deception that this country has ever seen, the deception which is now unfolding in too much of corporate America.

O'BRIEN: The unrest on Wall Street led some senators to call for an end to the debate. For Phil Gramm of Texas, a vote couldn't come soon enough.

SEN. PHIL GRAMM (R), TEXAS: The sooner we put together a bill that will represent a compromise, the more certainty there will be on Wall Street and the quicker we will rebuild equity values in America and rebuild confidence in our market.

O'BRIEN: Gramm, who opposes key features of the Sarbanes bill, is expected to vote in favor of it and allow the measure to go to a conference committee to be reconciled with a much milder bill passed by the House last April.

Senator John McCain predicted Republicans are prepared to compromise.

SEN. JOHN MCCAIN (R), ARIZONA: The Oxley bill passed when the temperature was much lower than it is today, so I do have some confidence that we will see a better result from the conference.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

O'BRIEN: The expectation is that the Senate will give final approval to the Sarbanes bill early next week, and then the most intense debate, the debate in the conference committee, will begin -- Jan.

HOPKINS: Early next week? Possibly tomorrow?

O'BRIEN: We thought tomorrow.

HOPKINS: I mean, are they in that much of a rush?

O'BRIEN: We thought tomorrow, but the scheduling -- there's more debate than we thought. It's going to be at the very earliest Monday, and some say it could be Wednesday. And the real debate, what really counts, will be in that conference committee, and no one can guess right now how that's going to turn out.

HOPKINS: I guess all the members of the Senate want to be on the record against what's going on, right?

O'BRIEN: They certainly do, and they certainly are, and there was some thought, because the House version is so different from the Senate version, that this debate would be long and acrimonious.

But there's pressure on everybody to get something done. So there's going to be some measure coming out, and it will probably be swift.

HOPKINS: Thanks.

Tim O'Brien in Washington.

WorldCom appears to be on the verge of bankruptcy. The telecom company canceled its dividend payment to shareholders of its MCI tracking stock.

Separately, the U.S. Attorney in New York will take over the SEC lawsuit brought against WorldCom by its counterpart in Mississippi. The Mississippi attorney owned WorldCom shares. The House Energy and Commerce Committee continues its investigation of WorldCom.

That committee gave the company a deadline of today to submit detailed financial reports.

Joining us now from Washington is the committee's chairman, Congressman Bill Tauzin of Louisiana.

So did the company meet the deadline?

REP. BILL TAUZIN (R), LOUISIANA: Yes, they did. As of this afternoon, I think we received about five huge boxes of documents. At least we believe that it contains the documents we have requested from WorldCom.

HOPKINS: Have you had a chance to look at the documents? And what are they saying to you?

TAUZIN: Well, investigators are going through them as we speak, but I can give you some news. I mean, we have learned something rather dramatic just this week.

What we have learned from some of the lawyers doing the internal investigation inside WorldCom is that Scott Sullivan -- you'll recall the fired CFO of the company, the guy in charge of financial affairs of the company -- admitted to those lawyers that the chairman of the company, Bernie Ebbers, did, in fact, know that millions of dollars -- hundreds of millions of dollars had been moved into those -- into capital debt rather than expensing it as ordinary debt of the corporation.

So this is the first evidence we have at least the CFO is saying to attorneys within the corporation that his boss, the CEO of the company, actually knew that the books were being cooked.

HOPKINS: Now, did Sullivan say that it was Ebbers that made him do it?

TAUZIN: We don't know that as a fact. All we know now is that Sullivan is saying that his boss, the CEO, was at least aware that the books were being cooked.

HOPKINS: Now this appears to be fraud. Where does this information go?

TAUZIN: Well, obviously, this information ends up with the Justice Department at some point. It's part of an internal investigation, part of what we're learning through our committee investigation.

But, in the end, we make a report to the Justice Department of our findings, as well as, I'm sure, the internal investigators will make a similar report.

HOPKINS: What are you looking for? I mean, is it fraud that you're looking for?

TAUZIN: Well, you know, our job is to try to find out what went wrong so that we can make sure that the reforms that are being recommended here in Congress are adequate, so we can make sure that the recommendations of the executive office and its recent executive order are sufficient and then to make sure those reforms are carried out.

So understanding what went wrong at WorldCom, just as we've tried to understand what went wrong at Enron, are important parts of the story and, therefore, lead us to the right solution, we hope.

HOPKINS: What have you found about Enron?

TAUZIN: Well, we found a number of things at Enron. We found that the accounting firm, Arthur Andersen, which appears again -- over and over again at most of these companies that are failing, was the only one of the big five accounting firms that allowed its local partners, the ones that did the local auditing, to actually overrule the national headquarters in terms of its rulings.

The national quality review boards of all the accounting firms usually issue mandatory rulings upon their auditors in the field. Arthur Andersen was the only one that allowed its local auditors to do whatever they thought was right, in effect, gave them a free hand to work with an executive that might have wanted to cook the books.

And I think we're begging to see a pattern now at Enron, at WorldCom, at Global Crossing, at Qwest, and a whole bunch of corporations that have gotten into deep trouble. We're beginning to see a combination of executives who felt like they could get away with aggressive accounting or cooking the books, hiding debt, inflating income, all for the purpose of driving up their stock shares, and then, secondly, accountants who were free, apparently, in Arthur Andersen to make decisions to allow them to do that when no other major accounting firm would allow that to happen.

HOPKINS: From what you've seen now, do you think that there are some people that are going to go to jail as a result of this?

TAUZIN: Oh, absolutely. And, actually, I think the sooner some major corporate criminal goes to prison, I think the faster investor confidence is going to rebuild in this country.

What we've seen, basically, is that greed unchecked by fear has been at work in some of these big corporations and that the investors and the pension holders have been the big victims, the workers of the companies. We've got to put some fear back in the equation.

People have to believe that they're being watched and that, when they do something wrong, just like any common criminal who steals, that they go to a real jail, not a country club jail, and that their ill-gotten gains have to be returned to the shareholders and the real owners of the corporation, the American people.

HOPKINS: One of the companies that you've been investigating is ImClone. Martha Stewart has been implicated in this case. Are you looking into Martha Stewart and her stock sales?

TAUZIN: Well, we have -- we've subpoenaed the records of her broker. In our conversations with him and his attorney, we have requested his phone records because it's important for us to know the timing of when the phone calls were made from him to the various clients he had who sold stock the day before the ImClone stock crashed because of the decision by the Food and Drug Administration.

The timing of the phone calls will tell us and will tell investigators a great deal about whether or not this was insider trading, whether or not it was ordinary trading, if you will, in advance of some bad news. We…

HOPKINS: And you can't tell yet?

TAUZIN: Well, there's a lot of suspicion. I mean, the coincidences keep piling up, which makes you believe that somebody was telling somebody some bad news the day before it really happened, and so getting the phone records will tell us a great deal.

So the broker involved here, who has so far refused to turn over those phone records, has now been subpoenaed to do so.

HOPKINS: Thanks very much.

Billy Tauzin, representative of Louisiana.

Thanks for joining us.

TAUZIN: Thank you.

HOPKINS: A comeback for the markets today. The Dow Industrials battled back from a triple-digit loss on good news from Eastman Kodak and Wal-Mart. The Nasdaq overcame losses as well, closing with strong gains.

Kitty Pilgrim has the story.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

KITTY PILGRIM, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): It's not just the market anymore. It's starting to get personal. The glimpse of the ticker done sideways not wanting to really see the damage.

Today was one of those days, that low stomach-dropping fear, the Dow down 200 points at midday before the long climb back up to close just above 8,800. The NASDAQ with an extremely volatile day, but some buying in stocks like Intel helped it gain more than 2 percent to close up 28 points at 1,374.

LEAH MODIGLIANI, MORGAN STANLEY: These are very difficult times, and it's painful. But I actually think that prices are getting more reasonable, and, if you're a long-term investors, it's probably getting to be a good time to buy.

PILGRIM: The volatility was all the more frightening because of the context. So far this week, the Dow down more than 6 percent, the NASDAQ down 5 percent, the S&P 500 down 6 percent, and the Russell 2000 small caps down 5-1/2 percent.

And market performance has been so bad this year, some families admit the financial statements have been going into the kitchen drawer unopened. They just don't want to see it.

Since hitting highs reached in early 2000, the Dow Jones Industrial Average has lost 25 percent of its value, and the NASDAQ has dropped a stunning 73 percent.

SAM STOVALL, STANDARD & POOR'S: I think that even though the markets had been very, very negative, they have been just oversold both on a numbers basis as well as a sentiment basis, and I think that, in general, we're at the beginning of the end for the down slide.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

PILGRIM: Well, some took comfort in the fact that at the last hour of trading, all was not lost, and others said, because of the extremely heavy volume, it showed conviction and that the comeback was a keeper despite a harrowing day -- Jan.

HOPKINS: Good end to the day.

Thanks, Kitty.

Turning tonight to the MONEYLINE quick vote, what is your rating on stocks -- buy, sell, or hold? Please cast your vote at cnn.com/moneyline. We'll have results for you later in the broadcast.

After being dark for a couple of years, the national debt clock is running again.

The clock is located in New York Times Square. It flickered to life this morning registering a debt -- national debt of $6.1 trillion. It immediately began ticking higher at rate of $30 a minute. The stock -- or the clock was shut down two years ago when the government was flush with budget surpluses.

Now the White House is projecting a $106-billion deficit. The government's borrowing limit has been raised to $6-1/2 trillion. That clock was erected in 1989 by real-estate developer Seymour Durst.

Still to come on MONEYLINE, top Cabinet members go to Capitol Hill to talk about homeland security, as government sources say that dozens of al Qaeda suspects are being watched in some of America's biggest cities.

Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat is defiant. He tells CNN no one can set aside the choice of the Palestinian people.

And the blame game over California's energy market escalates as power companies battle the West's latest heat wave.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

HOPKINS: Government sources today gave the most specific information yet about FBI operations to track al Qaeda operatives within the United States. News came as Attorney General John Ashcroft and other Cabinet members went to Capitol Hill to talk about homeland security.

Kelli Arena has more -- Kelli.

KELLI ARENA, CNN JUSTICE CORRESPONDENT: Jan, in some America's biggest cities, including Seattle, Chicago, Detroit, and Atlanta, sources tell CNN groups of suspected al Qaeda operatives are being closely watched by the FBI. Now there are fewer than 100 under surveillance, but the threat is serious.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN ASHCROFT, ATTORNEY GENERAL: Today, the United States is at war with a terrorist network operating within our borders. Al Qaeda maintains a hidden but active presence in the United States, waiting to strike again.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ARENA: And as the United States moves to protect its borders, the attorney general says that terrorist organizations are adapting.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ASHCROFT: As we limit the access of foreign terrorists to our country, we recognize that the terrorist response will be to try and recruit U.S. citizens and permanent residents to carry out their attacks.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ARENA: The statements come as sources tell CNN investigators are pretty much convinced there is another attack being planned by al Qaeda, although there is no specific intelligence about a target or a date -- Jan.

HOPKINS: And that's the same as we've been hearing all along?

ARENA: Yes, it is.

HOPKINS: Kelli Arena.

Thank you.

My next guest says that house lawmakers have changed many of the elements in the original plan for the Department of Homeland Security.

Former Defense Secretary and MONEYLINE regular Bill Cohen joins us now.

Welcome back, Bill.

WILLIAM COHEN, FORMER DEFENSE SECRETARY: Good evening.

HOPKINS: My question, actually, first is would one department track al Qaeda operatives in the United States better than the way the system is now?

COHEN: Well, much depends upon the agency involved. One of the things that's taking place now through these hearings is to really give an opportunity for members who represent the various agencies and who have developed expertise in their jurisdictional boxes, so to speak, an opportunity to see what would take place, would security actually be improved by transferring it in whole or in part to this new agency.

Now you have to remember that this Department of Homeland Security was basically created by four people in the executive department with very little consultation by other members of the Cabinet and certainly none -- no consultation with members of Congress, so this is a process whereby the need for either transferring in whole or part to the homeland security agency or department will be very important to flesh out.

My fear is that there will be a rush to failure, that they will be so compelled by a symbolic gesture to finish by a certain date that they will put something together that really is not functionally very efficient or successful, and we'll see the equivalent of financial earnings restatements coming forth in the coming months and years.

So I think we should take a little bit of time and be careful how this is all put together.

HOPKINS: Well, the White House wants basically one huge umbrella organization. The House isn't so sure that that would work the best. What do you think?

COHEN: Well, again, it depends. That's why it's important to have these hearings. Ordinarily, you would say it would operate best under one department, but there may be the expertise that has been developed in a given agency that should not be transferred to the department, and so each committee will go through and make its recommendations.

Ultimately, the House will have its select committee under the aegis of Dick Armey who will come forward with a recommendation voted up or down by the House and then go over to the Senate for at least a similar type of process. But I think it's too early.

My caution would be: Do not rush this process. Make sure that we do it right rather than fast because we're bound to have a number of seams that are developed, and those seams can be exploited by the very terrorist groups you were talking about just a moment ago.

HOPKINS: The Treasury Secretary has put a price tag on all of this at about $3 billion over, say, 10 years. Is this too expensive?

COHEN: Well, nothing is too expensive in terms of coming to protect the American homeland. We can afford to do whatever is necessary.

The question becomes, in terms of this $37.4- or $37.5-billion department, whether it'll be more expensive than that and whether the so-called efficiencies achieved by consolidating all of these agencies under one umbrella will produce those savings.

There's a lot of skepticism on Capitol Hill whether there's enough money to do what the administration claims it is going to be able to do through the consolidation.

HOPKINS: Can we make the homeland secure? Is it possible?

COHEN: We can make it more secure, certainly, than it has been to date. We have seen a good deal of laxity, some indifference, some incompetence, and, frankly, that has to change. I think that attitude is changing.

You're seeing this administration now bring forward a plan, which, hopefully, galvanize the American people and all of the agencies working on behalf of the American people to protect the people much better than they have in the past.

HOPKINS: And are you surprised at all about the news that al Qaeda operatives are being tracked in various cities across the U.S.?

COHEN: Actually, I'm not. We have known for years now that there are terrorist groups inside the United States, and they tend to surface and our attention tends to peak whenever there is tension and potential conflict in the world.

We now know and have known for sometime there are terrorist groups here. We watch them closely. That is being done today, and I think that will intensify. But it doesn't come as a surprise at all.

HOPKINS: William Cohen, former defense secretary and a MONEYLINE regular.

Thanks for being with us.

COHEN: Thank you, Jan.

HOPKINS: Coming up next on MONEYLINE, Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat says he is not concerned about President Bush's call for a new Palestinian leadership. We'll have an exclusive report.

A massive typhoon sweeps across Japan flooding thousands of homes, cutting dozens of highways. We'll have details.

And how a continuing plunge in the markets could stop consumer spending and bring the U.S. economy to a halt.

All of those stories coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

HOPKINS: Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat remains defiant in the face of President Bush's call for a change in the Palestinian leadership. He told CNN in an exclusive interview that no one can bypass the Palestinian people and their choice of a leader.

Brent Sadler has the story from Ramallah in the West Bank.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BRENT SADLER, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): A top diplomatic house call on Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat.

(on camera): How are you going to get in?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Walk in.

SADLER: Climb over here?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, it is another way.

SADLER (voice-over): A two-man European Union delegation headed by Middle East envoy Miguel Moratinos crossing a no man's land to a place under siege.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I think they're asking you to go back.

SADLER: We stick close to the VIPs entering the outer ring of Mr. Arafat's. It's behind concrete-filled barrels and three floors of sandbagged windows that the EU's diplomatic business takes place with the leader Israel has cast aside and to whom the United States has turned bitterly cold. But the Europeans seem on a different track, and Mr. Arafat is adamant he has a mandate to lead.

YASSER ARAFAT, PRESIDENT, PALESTINIAN AUTHORITY: First of all, no one can bypass the Palestinian people and their choice and their election.

SADLER: It is now seven months into the on-off siege of his Ramallah headquarters. A dull routine has set in with signs of boredom.

Israel's surgical military strikes have obliterated most of the complex, leaving Yasser Arafat with just one room intact where he says he works day and night, sleeps on the floor with a mattress, and uses this rug to pray.

During an informal lunch, Mr. Arafat drinks soup and tells me he thinks Israel's Prime Minister Ariel Sharon is waging a personal battle against him using old siege tactics to collapse his power which are doomed to fail.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

SADLER: Mr. Arafat told me that those siege tactics, as he described them, were doomed to failure. He also said that he did not expect the Israeli reoccupation of seven of eight West Bank urban centers to end in the coming days.

He did, however, say that, despite the observe isolation, he was still able to make contact with the outside world. For example, he said he was speaking to United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan ahead of this weeks' quartet meeting in New York about the Middle East.

Back to you, Jan.

HOPKINS: So, Brent, he still is quite resolved to continue leadership and continue peace talks?

SADLER: Yes, indeed. Despite the continuing encirclement of his compound, you can't see it, but it's where those lights are behind me just a few hundred yards, he continues to operate, he says, working the phones. And also very important, he says, to really try and build on these contacts that began only this week between some of his new ministers and the reshuffled Cabinet and the Israeli Foreign Minister Shimon Peres. He also says it's imperative for the leadership to work towards implementing a 100-day plan of reforms, which he wants completed by the time legislative council elections are slated for the third week of January -- Jan.

HOPKINS: Thanks, Brent Saddler.

My next guest says that President Bush's Middle East policy has left the United States isolated, not the Palestinians. Edward Abington joins us now. He's a consultant to the Palestinian Authority and a former U.S. consul-general to Jerusalem.

What is your sense that President Bush is approaching this in the wrong way, trying to get rid of Mr. Arafat? Who else is going to replace him?

EDWARD ABINGTON, CONSULTANT TO PALESTINIAN AUTHORITY: Well, I think the problem is that we've made Arafat the issue rather than reform. The Palestinian people want reform, but by putting President Arafat out there as the issue, you undermine the reformers and the people that want to see political change among the Palestinians.

HOPKINS: And what you're saying is that the rest of the world, basically, disagrees with the U.S. and the Israeli position?

ABINGTON: Well, that's essentially the case. The Europeans are dealing with Arafat, as we've just seen. So are the modern Arab countries -- Egypt, Jordan, Saudi Arabia, the United Nations, the Russians, other countries. We essentially have painted ourselves in a corner, and we've made it much more difficult to achieve a very legitimate objective of reform of Palestinian institutions, and strengthening Palestinian governance by making Arafat the issue.

HOPKINS: Now today, we had word that the Israelis are putting on trial one of the Palestinian moderates, also a report yesterday that one of the peace activists within the Palestinian community had his office closed basically by the Israelis. Is Israel trying to get rid of all of the opposition?

ABINGTON: You have to ask the question whether the Sharon government when it calls for reform of Palestinian political institutions is just using that as an excuse to avoid dealing with the fundamental issues. I was just recently in Ramallah and Jerusalem, I returned there last week, and I found that the situation among Palestinians is the worst that I've seen in 30 years.

The -- one-third of the Palestinian population of the West Bank and Gaza is subsisting on food handouts from the international community, and the number is growing every single day. There is serious malnutrition among Palestinian children, as demonstrated by a recent AID survey, and I think that the situation is facing a humanitarian disaster.

The Israelis side, their economy is faltering. Neither party can get out of the current situation without a catalyst from the outside, and it's the United States that needs to provide that role.

HOPKINS: So you think that the U.S. should come back in, take a more active role, and change its position on Arafat?

ABINGTON: It's not so much changing the position on Arafat. I mean, we can't determine who the Palestinian people select as their leader. I would say encourage the process of political reform, which cannot take place and which cannot reach fulfillment so long as the Israelis are in reoccupation of the West Bank as they are today.

We have to set up a process where the Palestinians do things and the Israelis do things, and each moves towards deescalating the situation, but we've laid out a sequential process where getting rid of Arafat and Palestinian political reform has to take place under conditions that are nearly impossible. It can't succeed the way things are now.

HOPKINS: Ed Abington, former U.S. consul-general to Jerusalem and now a consultant with the Palestinian Authority. Thank you …

ABINGTON: Thank you very much.

HOPKINS: … for joining us.

Up next on MONEYLINE, a dramatic day in the markets ends with a late-day rebound. Greg Clarkin will have the full story.

We'll also tell you who today's investors are, whether they own stocks directly or indirectly, and if they're rookies or veterans.

And a huge storm causes chaos in the German capital and the surrounding region.

All that and more when MONEYLINE returns.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

HOPKINS: A dramatic turnaround on Wall Street today. The session began with intense selling. The Dow plunged more than 200 points at its low. As one trader put it early on, the bear train is running at full speed.

But in the end, the markets drastically cut their losses. The Dow was down only 12 points at the close. The Nasdaq was up 28. The S&P was up nearly seven.

Greg Clarkin has been following today's volatile session in he's here now -- Greg.

GREG CLARKIN, CNN CORRESPONDENT: And, Jan, this was a really wild afternoon. Traders telling us the key point was right about midday. Now the Nasdaq had hit its session low of 13.23. They said a snap-back rally more technical in nature was due, and that's exactly what we saw.

Now rumors were swirling today that some of the big tech companies will be out with positive news after the bell and Dell has done just that. Now Dell saying that earnings will be a penny better than expected. The stock is soaring in after hours trading after gaining during the day as well.

And Intel is up eight percent on rumors of positive news. Sun rose seven percent for the same exact reason, and it was a tough market for a new offering, Kirkland's found that out the hard way. The Tennessee home furnishings retailer fell on its first day of trading.

Now among the NYSE winners, Eastman Kodak, it said it would top earnings estimates and thanks to the benefits of its restructuring and shares of Wal-Mart managed to gain its earnings should also be better than expected thanks to strong sales.

But the dual fears of accounting tricks and profit weakness never really far from the markets today. Shares of Bristol-Myers Squibb sank on word the SEC is looking into its sales to see if they were inflated.

SAP is Europe's biggest software company. It got lucky today. The stock recovered with a tech rebound despite its warnings that sales would be well below expectations.

So again, this rally more technical in nature than anything else. The problems hammering away at the markets recently, really not going anywhere at all today, Jan.

HOPKINS: Maybe it was all of the attention on the market that caused the buyers to come out.

CLARKIN: That's that old theory, once the media starts focusing like they were today, who knows?

HOPKINS: Thanks, Greg Clarkin. We'll see what happens tomorrow.

The recent sell-off in the markets have wiped out more than a half a trillion dollars in market capitalization this week alone. Some economists now worry that the weakness in the stock market could threaten the economic recovery.

Kathleen Hays has that story -- Kathleen.

KATHLEEN HAYS, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Hi, Jan. In fact, this week economists at Goldman Sachs saying they no longer expect the Fed to start hiking interest rates November. Now they say the Fed won't start hiking rates until the second half of next year. They say they're getting much more pessimistic on the economy because of the decline in stocks.

In fact, Bill Dudley said that it normally at this stage of the business cycle, stocks are up at least 20 percent, but this time around, they're down more than 18 percent. He says the impact of falling stock prices is offsetting, in fact, last year's aggressive series of Fed rate cuts by actually tightening up financial conditions.

Steve Roach of Morgan Stanley, he's been bearish on the economy for sometime, but now more than ever now. Investors continue to grow more wary of U.S. markets. They'll demand higher rates or return. The whole U.S. assets, he says, in fact that means higher interest rates if that happens.

He says this would not only crimp business capital spending, but could cut into home building activity and consumer spending on durable goods -- that's big ticket items like cars. He says that alone could trigger the fear double dip.

Mark Vitner of Wachovia Securities says we're already seeing the impact of the stock markets drop on the consumer. At the height of the bubble, we all were spending more than twice the rate of growth of our after-tax incomes. Now spending is growing at a slower rate than income and of course, Jan, the worry is that if stocks don't find a bottom, the consumer could keep decelerating. So I guess the real implication for our viewers is they better just ignore this bad stock market and keep spending money to keep everything afloat.

HOPKINS: Well, and things did turn around today.

(CROSSTALK)

HOPKINS: Thanks, Kathleen.

The scandal over corporate ethics has been described as the first involving a new and potent class of Americans, mass investors. But half of all American households now own stock.

Peter Viles has this story.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

PETER VILES, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): The crisis of confidence in the stock market and corporate America has rapidly become a major political issue and it is introducing Washington to a potentially powerful class of voters, American investors, 49 million household strong.

PETER HART, DEMOCRATIC POLLSTER: It's no longer the upward income, up scale people. These are average, hard working people who are now invested in the market, and it's their life savings and it's their future and they're scared. They're nervous. They're uncertain because they don't think the rules of the game are fair anymore.

VILES: The most recent widespread survey of investors is three years old. It found that 78.7 million Americans owned stocks, either directly or through mutual funds. That's 48 percent of all households, a dramatic increase from just 19 percent in 1983.

JIM SPELLMAN, SECURITIES INDUSTRY ASSN: The average investor is middle age, in their mid 40s, baby boomer, earning about $65,000 a year. They gave about $70,000, $80,000 in the market and that represents about two-thirds of their total financial assets excluding their house.

VILES: For all the concerns over investors who have never lived through a bear market, the typical American investor is a seasoned investor. Fifty-four percent of all equity holders bought their first stock or mutual fund before 1990. Twenty-eight percent in the first half of the '90s.

Only 18 percent after 1995. An important point, though, roughly half of the people we're talking about do not own stocks directly. Eighty-five percent of those exposed to the stock market own mutual funds. Only 54 percent own stocks directly. Sixty-six percent of the total investing class own stocks or mutual funds through an employer- sponsored retirement plan such as a 401(k).

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VILES: And one more important point about where the power is in this investing class, these investors who really have the ability to force change. As individuals, Americans own roughly 38 percent of the stock market, but big institutions, pension funds and mutual funds that own stock on behalf of individuals are more powerful. They own roughly 42 percent of the market -- Jan.

HOPKINS: And we've been hearing some about people's cashing in their mutual funds, redemptions.

VILES: Redemptions on mutual fund, interesting thing in the statistics. Even though individuals and institutions are roughly the same size in what they own of the markets, individuals took a bigger hit in the big pull back that began in the middle of 2000. They lost more of their money than the institutions did, and the institutions basically are better, broadened out, better diversified. They didn't take the big hit that individuals did. So even though the institutions are more powerful, it's the individuals who are really feeling the pain.

HOPKINS: Thanks, Peter Viles.

VILES: Sure.

HOPKINS: Now a reminder to vote in tonight's MONEYLINE poll. What's your rating on stocks? Buy, sell or hold? Please cast your vote at cnn.com/moneyline. We'll have results for you coming right up.

And still to come on MONEYLINE, El Nino is back. Your -- for years after the last appearance in the United States, we'll tell you what to expect this time.

And when temperatures rise in the West, so do tempers. Finger pointing over California's energy shortage escalates.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

HOPKINS: El Nino is back, but this time forecasters say the weather phenomenon won't be as big or as bad. Four years ago, an earlier El Nino killed 24,000 people worldwide. Here in the United States, heavy rains and winter storms triggered mud slides in the West, snow in the desert and a wet winter in the East. Forecasters say the U.S. will begin to feel some of the El Nino effects this fall, but again, they say it won't be as bad.

A tropical storm in Japan has now killed five people. The deaths occurred as Chataan slammed into Japan's main island. Thousands of homes were flooded. Nearly 2,000 people evacuated. Seven bridges destroyed stranding thousands of travelers. Chataan has moved north to the island of Hocito (ph).

A freak storm in Germany killed seven people, including two teenagers. That storm lashed Berlin with winds of 90 miles an hour. More than 1200 trees were felled by the winds. Two teenagers died when a tornado swept through their camp. German officials say the storm is the worst in three decades.

And in this country, cooler weather is finally moving into California. But after several days of record setting temperatures, and energy alerts, many Californians were left with a sense of deja vu. A heat wave last year left many in that state without power and feeling powerless against soaring energy prices.

Casey Wian has the story from Los Angeles.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

CASEY WIAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): California lawmakers continue to point fingers at outsiders they accuse of manipulating the state's energy market, driving prices higher and forcing blackouts. The latest target, Perot Systems, which help designed the computer system for the state's electrical grid operator. Lawmakers say they've uncovered documents showing Perot Systems helped energy companies profit from loopholes in the system it helped designed.

STEVE PEACE, CALIFORNIA STATE SENATE: The three key players were Enron, Dynegy and Reliant. And then along comes this information with Perot System. You all seem to have something in common, 10-gallon hats in Texas. Can you tell me why it is that you Texans seem to be so effective at …

(CROSSTALK)

ROSS PEROT, PEROT SYSTEMS: Wait a minute. All the -- all the activity, sir, all the activity was being carried out by people. I think if you check their backgrounds, they came from this area. The facts are …

(CROSSTALK)

PEACE: I just want to know why you all keep winning.

PEROT: It's a good joke, but it's not (UNINTELLIGIBLE).

WIAN: Perot says his company never disclosed inside information, rather it was trying to point out flaws in California's newly deregulated electricity market, warnings the company says were largely ignored.

Meanwhile, California's energy market has stabilize since the blackouts of 2000 and 2001. Soaring temperatures have forced power grid officials to issue warnings and encourage conservation on two days this week, but there were no blackouts.

BILL KEESE, CALIFORNIA ENERGY COMMISSION: With what we have added and with what we anticipate coming in, we can handle a hotter than normal year.

WIAN: In the past year, power plants capable of supplying about two million homes have been completed in California. Conservation has reduced demand and the state has bailed out utilities by signing billions of dollars in long-term power contracts.

(on camera): State officials say they can not guarantee that California will make it through the summer without blackouts, but they are optimistic because of their ability to manage this week's heat wave.

Casey Wian, CNN Financial News, Los Angeles.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HOPKINS: Coming up next, more help for victims of the September 11 attacks against America. That story and more when we come back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ANNOUNCER: Tomorrow on Lou Dobbs MONEYLINE, the British population goes bust.

(MUSIC)

ANNOUNCER: A special report on how American and British music execs are banking together to bring the Brits back.

Plus a panel of Wall Street experts tells us how to make sense of the markets, tomorrow on LOU DOBBS MONEYLINE.

HOPKINS: The September 11th Fund will have spent more money to help victims of last year's terrorist attacks against America. Funds managers say another $200 million will be used to expand current programs, as well as support mental health counseling, provide employment assistance and health insurance assistance. The September 11th Fund has already spent $301 million helping more than 100,000 people.

Now the results of tonight's MONEYLINE "Quick Vote." What's your rating on stocks? Thirty percent said buy; 35 voted sell; and 35 said hold; pretty evenly divided.

"CROSSFIRE" begins in a few minutes. For a preview let's go to Paul Begala and Bob Novak in Washington -- Bob.

ROBERT NOVAK, CO-HOST, "CROSSFIRE": Jan, we're going to talk to a couple of members of Congress as to the accusations by the Democrats that George W. Bush and Dick Cheney are some kind of swindlers and embezzlers and maybe that is what is hurting the stock market so much.

PAUL BEGALA, CO-HOST, "CROSSFIRE": And then, Jan, (UNINTELLIGIBLE) expert in cursing. What the hell is going on in Pennsylvania? The damn cops arrested people for cursing. They'll have to come and get me. Personally, I just think it's a bunch of BS, Jan.

HOPKINS: Yes, I guess you are the expert. Thanks.

Today is World Population Day, a day established to focus attention on our expanding population. Since 1960, the population has more than doubled to six billion, but the breakdown of that population might surprise you.

If there were just 100 people on the planet, 57 is would be Asian; 21 European; 52 would be female; 48 male; 70 would be non- white; 70 non-Christian; 11 homosexual; 70 unable to read; one would own a computer; one would have a college education. That's out of 100.

Just under 50 years there will be more than three billion people, 100 years of age or older. There are currently -- that's a million rather -- currently there are 200,000.

And still to come, your thoughts on corporate corruption and "In Their Words."

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

HOPKINS: Let's take a look at your thoughts.

Tosh Iguchi writes: "For those who committed financial crimes, the punishment should be financial ruin rather than incarceration. Spending a few years in club fed playing tennis and watching movies is not much of a punishment."

Sam Summers in Buenos Aires, Argentina writes: "In today's Argentine newspapers it is reported that Jeff Skilling, the former CEO of Enron, is skiing in Bariloche, Argentina. Is that what President Bush had in mind when he promised to double the jail sentences for corporate transgressors? Skiing both in winter and summer?"

Larry England in Longview, Texas writes: "Who said that crime doesn't pay? The corporate obfuscation of Enron, Global Crossing and WorldCom and their CEOs with the help of their board of directors and Arthur Andersen shows maybe corporate crime does pay and pays very well."

Finally Earl in Tempi, Arizona writes: "Workers have poured billions into 401(k)s, some executives shamelessly engorged themselves on it in a way that would make the most gluttonous Roman emperor blush. Shame on them and shame on us for letting it happen. Executive compensation was the warning sign."

Thanks for telling us what's on your mind. You can e-mail us, moneyline@cnn.com, but please include your name and address.

Now, from your words to "In Their Words."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GEORGE W. BUSH, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Medicare does not cover most prescription drugs. That's reality. Too many seniors, because that's the case, because they're too costly and Medicare doesn't cover them, too many of our seniors are forced to choose between paying for their pills or paying basic bills, and that's not right in America.

COLIN POWELL, SECRETARY OF STATE: We cannot, we will not let the need to fight this war make us that different a society. We have to protect ourselves, but we must not put up tall fences, sprinkle broken glass on the tops, put a guard at the gate, and seal ourselves off from the rest of the world. We must not become gated America or they will have won.

SEN. JIM BUNNING (R), KENTUCKY: The owners saying that almost all the teams are losing money and yet we have owners that will go out and pay $25 million to a player for a year salary and for one player to think that they can change their team by the addition of one player is not very smart. And therefore, the economics of baseball have been pretty unstable since 1976 when the owners had no franchises.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HOPKINS: That's MONEYLINE for this Thursday evening. I'm Jan Hopkins sitting in for Lou Dobbs. Thanks for joining us. Good night from New York. TO ORDER A VIDEO OF THIS TRANSCRIPT, PLEASE CALL 800-CNN-NEWS OR USE OUR SECURE ONLINE ORDER FORM LOCATED AT www.fdch.com
