urn:contentItem:3X9T-5T70-009B-G38X-00000-00Dow Drops 94, to 10,843; Investors Brace for Employment Report1999-09-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:03ZLexisNexisCNN MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR 18:30 pm ETBusinessSHOW99090200V19Dow Drops 94, to 10,843; Investors Brace for Employment ReportStuart Varney, Willow Bay, Christine Romans, Bill Dorman, Greg Clarkin, Bruce Francis, Kelli Arena, Fred Katayama, Susan Lisovicz, Ceci Rodgers

Anxiety among investors gave way to late bargain buying on Wall Street, but investors remain nervous ahead of tomorrow's employment report. After plummeting early in the day, the Dow ended down 94 points to 10,843. The Nasdaq fell 16 points to 2,734. Bonds continued their swan dive, tumbling 20/32 of a point, with the yield up to 6.126 percent. The pace of productivity growth is slowing while labor costs are rising faster than they have in more than five years. The fear of another Fed Reserve Board rate hike has slammed stocks and bonds over the past week.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

STUART VARNEY, CNN ANCHOR: Tonight on MONEYLINE: tension hangs over Wall Street as the late-summer slump resumes ahead of tomorrow's report on jobs.

WILLOW BAY, CNN ANCHOR: Certain to study that report with an eagle eye: Alan Greenspan. One of his chief lieutenants today warning Greenspan's work might not be done.

VARNEY: And soft profits at America's No. 2 retailer leads to a hard fall on Wall Street. Does Sears have a comeback strategy?

ANNOUNCER: This is THE MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR. Reporting tonight from New York, Willow Bay and Stuart Varney.

VARNEY: Good evening, everyone. Welcome to MONEYLINE.

Another punishing day on Wall Street.

BAY: Blue chip stocks down again; five losing days out of the last six sessions. Twice today, the Dow was down more than 200 points, just a few points away from triggering a trading curb. The spark behind the sell off: more strong economic numbers and tough talk on inflation from one Fed governor. But by day's end, blue chip stocks had cut more than half their losses. Now, the market is bracing itself for tomorrow's report on jobs.

Christine Romans has more in today's "Street Sweep."

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

CHRISTINE ROMANS, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): High anxiety gave way to late bargain buying on Wall Street, but investors remain nervous ahead of tomorrow's employment report. After plummeting early in the day, the Dow ended down 94 points to 10,843. The Nasdaq fell 16 points to 2,734. But bonds continued their swan dive, tumbling 20/32 of a point, with the yield up to 6.126 percent.

Rattling the markets early today, hawkish comments from Fed governor Edward Kelley, who warned that the Fed remains on the inflation alert. Adding to the fear: a report showing a spike in labor costs. At least one analyst says Wall Street should be wary of the Fed's next move.

GAIL DUDACK, WARBURG DILLON READ: What people, I think, don't accept quite yet is that when you have a Federal Reserve or Central Bank in tightening mode with very high valuation, that's always been dangerous.

ROMANS: The fear of rising interest rates rattled financial stocks on the Dow, with American Express and J.P. Morgan hit hard. Other Dow losers today: GM, IBM and Johnson & Johnson.

The biggest Dow decliner was Sears, down 3 11/16 after the retail landmark slashed its profit forecasts. And scandal slammed the stock of Republic New York. Investors fear that an investigation into possible securities violations could threaten the bank's merger with HSBC.

Now investors are focused squarely on getting past tomorrow's jobs report; the big obstacle before the Labor Day getaway.

JAMES MCGUIRE, HENDERSON BROTHERS: I think Tuesday is going to be a whole new ballgame. I think there are people looking for perhaps investors to come back into the market, now that the interest rate picture may be a little clearer on Tuesday.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

ROMANS: The suspense will be over at 8:30 Eastern time tomorrow morning. The expectation? That the August unemployment rate edges down to 4.2 percent and about 200,000 new jobs were created. If the numbers are significantly stronger it could make for an interesting day on Wall Street -- Willow.

BAY: OK. Christine, like everyone else, we'll be watching closely. Christine Romans from the New York Stock Exchange.

VARNEY: Well, economic numbers out today clearly rattled investors. Those reports, along with a reality check from one Fed board member, added up to one disturbing message for investors: The Fed may not be done raising rates.

Bill Dorman looks at the inflationary pressures lurking in the economy.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BILL DORMAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): The gospel according to Alan Greenspan says keep a close watch on labor costs and worker productivity for signs of inflation. BAY: How likely is it that it will actually close?

CLARKIN: At this point, Willow, it's tough to say. There's still a lot of dust that has to settle here, and everybody involved from the banks' folks to the folks that play the stocks are saying that it's just too early really to see the severity of this investigation.

BAY: Greg Clarkin, thank you.

CLARKIN: Sure.

VARNEY: Some other stocks people were talking about today: Tech Data, for example, way down more than 7 points. The computer equipment distributor says price cutting in Europe is eating into profits. Regeneron Pharmaceuticals down more than 2. Procter & Gamble said it would stop helping Regeneron to develop its diet drug, Axokind (ph), because of negative test results. Lonestar Industries shot up more than 14 1/2. Germany's Dikerhoff is buying the cement maker for $1.2 billion, $50 dollars a share. Rambus down 4 3/4. Intel adopted a chip technology that's less powerful than Rambus and less expensive.

BAY: That trouble with Rambus cast a shadow over the rest of the communications chip sector today, even though many analysts called the Rambus sell-off an overreaction, and reiterated buys on the stock. Here's the damage: Broadcom down nearly 3 3/4. Conexant lost 3. PMC Sierra fell 2 7/8. And Galileo Technology off 1 1/4.

VARNEY: Up next, some of the day's other corporate headlines.

BAY: And how much were you worth at the tender age of 30?

VARNEY: Don't ask.

BAY: Who's who of America's young rich, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK) BAY: After the stock market closed, Pepsico said it expects to report lower income for its North American operations in the third quarter. Pepsi blamed lower case volume, but says earnings per share will be higher because of strength at its Frito-Lay and Tropicana units.

VARNEY: In other corporate headlines, Ford says August was just about as good as it gets. Like its rivals, the automaker reported very strong sales, up more than 8 percent.

The Justice Department approved Fleet's merger with Bank Boston, but there are very long strings attached. The bank must sell more than $13 billion in deposits at more than 300 branches. It's the largest divestiture ever for a bank merger.

BAY: A story now that's either depressing or inspiring, depending on how you look at it and how old you are. "Fortune" magazine has compiled a list of the richest young turks in corporate America: the 40 wealthiest people under 40.

Michael Dell, the 34-year-old wunderkind and CEO of Dell Computer, tops the list with $21 billion. He is followed by Amazon.com's Jeff Bezos, Gateway's Ted Waitt, Pierre Omidyar of eBay, and David Filo of Yahoo! The top five are all men, so now it's not just depressing if you're young or old. It's depressing for females.

And so is the rest of the list: 35 of them made their fortunes in technology. And this is sort of interesting, 11 never finished college.

VARNEY: There's a cute little editorial or comment there, Willow.

BAY: Just a little editorial aside. You don't mind here when we do that, not much.

VARNEY: Read the script.

(LAUGHTER)

BAY: Up next, a pioneer who made all these 30-something billionaires. A hint -- not Al Gore.

(LAUGHTER)

VARNEY: Very correct. But first, "Ahead of the Curve": some of what you need to know tonight before tomorrow's markets open.

BAY: MONEYLINE will be back in 40 seconds.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: Tomorrow's is the Friday before a long holiday weekend, but there could still be some real fireworks on Wall Street. That's because the government releases what's considered the most important economic report of the month: the employment report. Economists predict the unemployment rate would fall slightly to 4.2 percent and that corporate America created more than 200,000 new jobs. The bond trading pits will probably be hopping in the morning, but they'll close early, at 2:00 p.m. Eastern.

BAY: And don't miss MONEYLINE's special Friday feature: "The Bottom Line." This time we'll look inside American Airlines: labor issues, an alleged smuggling ring, and customer complaints. Should you own the stock?

That's tomorrow night at 6:30 Eastern.

VARNEY: All right. Finally tonight, a controversy over paternity that cannot be answered with a simple DNA test. Oh, no. Today is the 30th birthday of the Internet. At least some members of the digital elite claim it is. And not only is their debate over when it was born; there's no consensus on who deserves the title, father of the Internet.

Kelli Arena reports.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ARENA (voice-over): When you hear the name Thomas Edison, what comes to mind?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The lightbulb.

ARENA: How about Alexander Graham Bell?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Telephone.

ARENA: Fast forward more than 100 years. Who invented the Internet?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Joe Brown? We don't know.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: It's Bill Gates, I'm telling you.

(LAUGHTER)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Al Gore. Everybody knows that.

ARENA: As the saying goes, success has many fathers.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP, MARCH 9)

ALBERT GORE, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I took the initiative in creating the Internet.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ARENA: There are those who take the credit, and those who do the work.

LEONARD KLEINROCK, UCLA: I'm not the father. I'm a father, at best.

ARENA: But Leonard Kleinrock is known as the father of the Internet. Actually, he was part of a team that took the first step in getting a computer hooked to a router on September 2, 1969.

But the first time one computer actually talked to another took place on October 20th of that year: hence some confusion over the Internet's actual birthdate.

KLEINROCK: The general public didn't even know about it. What's more interesting is that it met with this deafening lack of response from my colleagues.

ARENA: Hardly the reception for what has revolutionized the communications world like nothing before.

VINT CERF, MCIWORLDCOM: We knew we needed to connect a lot of computers together in order to share the resources among the computer science departments that were funded by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency.

ARENA: With the Vietnam War raging, military planners worried that an enemy strike knocking out any key computer would cause havoc, and a decentralized network that let data flow in different directions seemed like the answer.

The Pentagon probably didn't have this in mind when it funded the Internet, but by all accounts, it was an effort well worth it.

Kelli Arena, CNN Financial News, Washington.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BAY: That's MONEYLINE for this Thursday. I'm Willow Bay.

VARNEY: And I'm Stuart Varney. Thanks for joining us.

Final write

By Nathaniel MeyersohnNEW YORK (CNNMoney)

NEW YORK (CNNMoney) -- Facebook's worst day in four years dragged the stock market down.

Facebook tumbled 7% on Monday, helping to pull the tech-heavy Nasdaq 1.8% lower and S&P 500 1.4%. It was the Nasdaq's worst day since February 8.

The Dow fell as much as 493 points. The average closed down 336 points, or 1.4%, and is back in negative territory for the year.

Big tech companies, including Facebook, Amazon, Netflix and Google, have powered the market's climb, but all four slipped Monday. The S&P's tech sector fell 2.1% and was the worst performing sector on the index.

Facebook is under pressure from lawmakers in both the United States and the UK after more than 50 million users' data ended up in the hands of data firm Cambridge Analytica.

"When you have real damage to a large enough company, that translates into the indexes as a whole," Brad McMillan, chief investment officer at Commonwealth Financial Network, said.

Democratic Senator Amy Klobuchar has called on Zuckerberg to appear before Congress to testify about "what Facebook knew about misusing data from 50 million Americans in order to target political advertising and manipulate voters." John Kennedy, a Republican senator from Louisiana, joined Klobuchar in calling for Zuckerberg to testify.

Investors worry that new regulations on Facebook or an exodus of users from the platform could slow down one of the world's most valuable companies and chill the tech sector's rise.

"Investors are questioning [Facebook's] growth potential. As a result, they are willing to take profits," said Sam Stovall, chief investment strategist at CFRA Research.

Facebook's losses had a cascading effect on the market. Wall Street's volatility index, known as the VIX, spiked 25%. CNNMoney's Fear and Greed Index, a measure of market sentiment, sunk deeper into extreme fear territory.

Wall Street is also weighing President Trump's next move on trade with China and the first Federal Reserve meeting with Chairman Jay Powell at the helm beginning Wednesday.

The White House confirmed to CNN last week that the administration is considering tariffs on at least $30 billion worth of imports from China. The move would be retaliation for alleged Chinese technology intellectual property theft. Trump has already imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum, setting off fears of a wider trade fight that could threaten the economy.

On Monday, 49 of the nation's largest retailers, including Walmart, Target and Costco, said new tariffs would hurt consumers.

"As you continue to investigate harmful technology and intellectual property practices, we ask that any remedy carefully consider the impact on consumer prices," the letter stated.

Investors are also preparing for the Fed to raise rates when it meets Wednesday for a two-day policy conference. CME Group predicts a 94% chance the Fed hikes rates by a quarter percentage point.

"We have a lot more uncertainty with respect to the Fed than we've had in years," McMillan said. "Everyone believes Chair Powell is similar to Chair Yellen, but we don't really know."

McMillan argued the Fed's path to gradually normalize interest rates, which have been at historical lows since the 2008 financial crisis, is a sign of the economy's strength.

"This is essentially the Fed endorsing the fact that the market is growing. I think the market reaction ultimately would end up being positive."

Stovall of CFRA Research is projecting the Fed will raise interest rates three times in 2018, but investors have left open the possibility of a fourth.

Higher interest rates bring down the value of stocks by making borrowing costs higher for companies. As rates climb higher, returns in the bond market can start looking more appealing than riskier stocks.

-CNNMoney's Matt Egan contributed to this story.

urn:contentItem:5XMY-5991-DYWP-900G-00000-00Do We Need a National Bureau of Privacy?2019-12-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:03ZLexisNexisCAPITAL COMMENTPg. 16Do We Need a National Bureau of Privacy?

A Georgetown professor wants to create a federal data-protection agency to better safeguard citizens' sensitive information

Web Hed: Is It Finally Time for a National Bureau of Privacy?

Web Dek: A DC professor is fighting to create a federal agency to protect your data.

The 9/11 terrorist attacks led to the creation of the Department of Homeland Security. The 2008 financial crisis inspired the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. Could the backlash against Big Tech result in a standalone government agency devoted to securing our digital data? Marc Rotenberg, a Georgetown Law professor and president of the Electronic Privacy Information Center, is helping lead a push to create that kind of federally funded watchdog.

Facebook, Google, and other Silicon Valley giants have long operated under the tech-friendly purview of the Federal Trade Commission, which doesn't even have the authority to enforce privacy obligations. Indeed, as consumers grow increasingly alarmed by abuses of private information and high-profile data breaches, the United States remains one of the few advanced Western democracies without a dedicated regulator. "A lot of people in Washington wake up and say, 'How do we protect our nation's security? How do we keep our drinking water clean?' " says Rotenberg. "But remarkably, there's really nobody playing that role on privacy."

A serious but chatty privacy-law junkie who works out of a Dupont Circle office, Rotenberg began backing this idea in 1990. Yes, nearly 30 years ago: Long before Mark Zuckerberg cooked up Facebook in his Harvard dorm room, Rotenberg was promoting greater safeguards for personal information, whether helping draft new privacy laws as counsel for Vermont senator Patrick Leahy or testifying in front of Congress about the benefits of a federal data-privacy agency. Obviously, the need has only grown more urgent as the digital age has dramatically increased the dangers associated with intrusive businesses and cybercriminals.

So what would such an agency look like? In Rotenberg's view, it would direct the government's efforts to identify threats to our data, investigate complaints from consumers, and ensure the fair use of tech algorithms. It would also serve as the nation's chief advocate for stronger data protections.

The idea has gained momentum in recent months, and Rotenberg has been advising the staffs of Congress members Anna Eshoo and Zoe Lofgren on legislation they recently introduced to create a data-protection agency. Despite the long odds that it will be enacted, Rotenberg says data-privacy concerns are-or at least should be-nonpartisan. "And that," he says, "is a reason to be optimistic."

-Luke Mullins

urn:contentItem:5V8S-KY91-JC6P-C2BP-00000-00Do We Need A New Federal Agency to Enforce Privacy Laws?2019-01-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:03ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONAL NEWSDo We Need A New Federal Agency to Enforce Privacy Laws?Kate PatrickInsideSources.com, Washington, D.C.

Jan. 25--Some consumer advocacy groups released their own privacy framework last week, criticizing the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) for failing to crack down on Big Tech and calling for a new data protection agency to enforce privacy laws.

Any new federal privacy law, the consumer groups argue, should also set up this new agency.

"The FTC lacks rulemaking authority," the groups stated. "The agency has failed to enforce the orders it has established (referring to Facebook's violation of the FTC's 2011 consent decree). The U.S. needs a federal agency focused on privacy protection, compliance with data protection obligations, and emerging privacy challenges. The agency should also examine the social, ethical, social, and economic impacts of high-risk data processing and oversee impact-assessment obligations."

The privacy framework also calls for increased transparency of algorithms used by social media giants like Facebook, search engines like Google and fintech companies, and seeks to limit government access to consumer data.

The consumer groups released the framework almost two months after the FTC testified before the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation and asked for greater rulemaking authority to crack down on Big Tech, the authority to fine tech companies for privacy violations, and more resources to tackle privacy issues.

Given the FTC's apparent willingness to hold tech companies accountable for misconduct, especially when involving consumer data protection, the American Enterprise Institute's Visiting Scholar Roslyn Layton thinks a new data protection agency is unnecessary and a waste of resources.

"FTC as a federal agency offers tremendous taxpayer value -- they handle literally millions and millions of consumer complaints every year," Layton told InsideSources. "The conversation should really be about strengthening the FTC, not punishing it."

Regarding the FTC's failure to enforce the 2011 consent decree, Layton thinks that is the Obama administration's fault for cozying up to Silicon Valley.

"There is a fair critique to say hey, they didn't enforce this consent decree on the big players, and I would attribute that to the Obama administration which was very close to the tech industry, that's how they came to power," she said. "That's always an issue, but that's part of why you have two parties on the commission."

Aram Sinnreich, chair of communication studies at American University, takes a different view. Because the FTC's primary responsibility is to regulate trade and competition, he said, a new agency is better suited to regulate privacy.

"Having a dedicated agency whose one sole purpose is policing the integrity of consumer citizen data is a great idea," he told InsideSources. "It would be less susceptible to regulatory capture and have less conflict of interest in terms of interpreting what its function is and hopefully less susceptible to the vagaries of political pendulum swings. So I love that."

Sinnreich thinks the FTC often fails to truly punish companies for wrongdoing, partly because industry leaders frequently become FTC commissioners and vice versa, confusing the objectives of the commission.

"Part of it has to do with political philosophies of trade that vary from administration to administration," Sinnreich said. "Sometimes you're going to have a more cautious, consumer-friendly administration and sometimes a more light-touch, business-friendly administration. That's an issue that needs to be separate from the area of data privacy and security, which is essential to a functional democracy."

Because consumer data protection and privacy issues are not trade issues, the FTC doesn't really have a responsibility to regulate them.

"It's not just about trade, it's about functional democracy, human rights, civil rights, free speech," Sinnreich said. "The issues that are raised by the flow of consumer data between state, commercial and criminal entities, are much broader than trade issues. It's the kind of challenge that's more appropriate for an independent agency to address."

At the same time, many tech companies' business models rely on the flow of consumer data -- including Facebook, Google, and fintech companies like SoFi and Kabbage, which use consumer data to provide and consolidate different kinds of loans. Because consumer data and the modern tech industry depend on one another, Layton argues, the FTC does have jurisdiction over consumer data protection.

"This notion that consumer interests and market interests are conflicted, that's not necessarily the case," she said. "Consumers have benefited tremendously as a result of the online economy, and there's multiple views on consumer interests."

Congress hasn't signaled whether it plans to set up a new agency to regulate consumer data protection or privacy, in fact, the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation unanimously confirmed that the FTC should be the primary enforcer of any future privacy laws.

Multiple senators including Brian Schatz (D-Hawaii) and Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) introduced data protection bills over the last few months, reinforcing FTC authority and strengthening consumer data privacy.
